PREFACE
This code of the City of Okmulgee, as supplemented, contains ordinances up to
and including ordinance 2220, passed April 15, 2025. Ordinances of the City
adopted after said ordinance supersede the provisions of this code to the
extent that they are in conflict or inconsistent therewith. Consult the City
office in order to ascertain whether any particular provision of the code has
been amended, superseded or repealed.
American Legal Publishing
Cincinnati, Ohio
ORDINANCES PENDING REVIEW FOR CODIFICATION
Listed ordinances have been passed, but they are pending review by the
publisher, and they may not amend the code of ordinances. Additionally,
ordinances listed in this section may not show the original ordinances in their
entirety. Please contact the office of the clerk if there are any questions
concerning any listed ordinances.

CHAPTER 1.01
CODE ADOPTION
SECTION:
1.01.010: Adoption
1.01.020: Title; Citation; Reference
1.01.030: Codification Authority
1.01.040: Ordinances Passed Prior To Adoption Of The Code
1.01.050: Reference Applies To All Amendments
1.01.060: Title, Chapter And Section Headings
1.01.070: Reference To Specific Ordinances
1.01.080: Effect Of Code On Past Actions And Obligations
1.01.090: Effective Date
1.01.100: Constitutionality
1.01.110: Sale Of Code
1.01.010: ADOPTION:
Pursuant to the provisions of 11 Oklahoma Statutes section 672.1, there is
adopted the "Okmulgee municipal code", as published by Book Publishing Company,
Seattle, Washington. (Ord. 1238 § 1, 1975)
1.01.020: TITLE; CITATION; REFERENCE:
This code shall be known as the OKMULGEE MUNICIPAL CODE and it shall be
sufficient to refer to the code as the "Okmulgee municipal code" in any
prosecution for the violation of any provision thereof or in any proceeding at
law or equity. It shall be sufficient to designate any ordinance adding to,
amending, correcting or repealing all or any part or portion thereof as an
addition to, amendment to, correction or repeal of this code. Further reference
may be had to the titles, chapters, sections and subsections of this code and
such references shall apply to that numbered title, chapter, section or
subsection as it appears in this code. (Ord. 1238 § 2, 1975)
1.01.030: CODIFICATION AUTHORITY:
This code consists of all the regulatory and penal ordinances and certain of
the administrative ordinances of the city codified pursuant to the provisions
of 11 Oklahoma Statutes section 672.1. (Ord. 1238 § 3, 1975)
1.01.040: ORDINANCES PASSED PRIOR TO ADOPTION OF THE CODE:
The last ordinance included in this code is ordinance 1226, passed June 10,
1974. The following ordinances, passed subsequent to ordinance 1226, but prior
to adoption of this code, are adopted and made a part of this code: ordinances
1226, 1227, 1228, 1229, 1230, 1232, 1233, 1234, 1235, 1236 and 1237. (Ordinance
1231 has been specifically repealed by ordinance 1233.) (Ord. 1238 § 4, 1975)
1.01.050: REFERENCE APPLIES TO ALL AMENDMENTS:
Whenever a reference is made to this code as the "Okmulgee municipal code" or
to any portion thereof, or to any ordinance of the city, reference shall apply
to all amendments, corrections and additions heretofore, now or hereafter made.
(Ord. 1238 § 5, 1975)
1.01.060: TITLE, CHAPTER AND SECTION HEADINGS:
Title, chapter and section headings contained herein shall not be deemed to
govern, limit, modify or in any manner affect the scope, meaning or intent of
the provisions of any title, chapter or section hereof. (Ord. 1238 § 6, 1975)
1.01.070: REFERENCE TO SPECIFIC ORDINANCES:
The provisions of this code shall not in any manner affect matters of record
which refer to, or are otherwise connected with, ordinances which are therein
specifically designated by number or otherwise and which are included with this
code, but such reference shall be construed to apply to the corresponding
provisions contained within this code. (Ord. 1238 § 7, 1975)
1.01.080: EFFECT OF CODE ON PAST ACTIONS AND OBLIGATIONS:
Neither the adoption of this code nor the repeal or amendments hereby of any
ordinance or part or portion of any ordinance of the city shall in any manner
affect the prosecution for violations of ordinances, which violations were
committed prior to the effective date hereof, nor be construed as a waiver of
any license, fee or penalty at the effective date due and unpaid under such
ordinances, nor be construed as affecting any of the provisions of such
ordinances relating to the collection of any such license, fee or penalty, or
the penal provisions applicable to any violation thereof, nor to affect the
validity of any bond or cash deposit in lieu thereof required to be posted,
filed or deposited pursuant to any ordinance and all rights and obligations
thereunder appertaining shall continue in full force and effect. (Ord. 1238 §
8, 1975)
1.01.090: EFFECTIVE DATE:
This code shall become effective on April 1, 1975. (Ord. 1238 § 9, 1975)
1.01.100: CONSTITUTIONALITY:
If any section, subsection, sentence, clause or phrase of this code is for any
reason held to be invalid or unconstitutional, such decision shall not affect
the validity of the remaining portions of this code. The council declares that
it would have passed this code, and each section, subsection, sentence, clause
and phrase thereof, irrespective of the fact that any one or more sections,
subsections, sentences, clauses or phrases had been declared invalid or
unconstitutional, and if for any reason this code should be declared invalid or
unconstitutional, then the original ordinance or ordinances shall be in full
force and effect. (Ord. 1238 § 10, 1975)
1.01.110: SALE OF CODE:
Copies of this code may be purchased at the office of the city clerk for
seventy five dollars ($75.00) each. Any title of this code may be purchased for
fifty cents ($0.50) per page. All amendments, repeals or additions may be
purchased at time of passage by the city council for fifty cents ($0.50) per
page, uncodified. Codified supplements may be obtained from the city clerk when
available for a fee of twenty five dollars ($25.00) per supplement. (Ord. 1552
§ 1, 1985)
CHAPTER 1.04
GENERAL CODE PROVISIONS
SECTION:
1.04.010: Definitions
1.04.020: Grammatical Interpretation
1.04.030: Prohibited Acts Include Causing, Permitting, Etc.
1.04.040: Construction
1.04.050: Repeal Not To Revive Any Ordinances
1.04.060: Ordinances In Effect In Outlying Real Property Of City
1.04.070: Oklahoma Municipal League; Membership Authorized
1.04.080: Stolen, Abandoned Or Unclaimed Property; Disposition
1.04.090: Stolen, Abandoned Or Unclaimed Property; Records
1.04.100: Reading Of Proposed Ordinances
1.04.110: Boundaries For The Wards Of The City
1.04.120: Retention Of City Owned Video
1.04.010: DEFINITIONS:
CITY: The city of Okmulgee, Oklahoma, or the area within the territorial limits
of the city of Okmulgee, Oklahoma, and such territory outside of the city over
which the city has jurisdiction or control by virtue of any constitutional or
statutory provision.
COMPUTATION OF TIME: The time within which an act is to be done. It shall be
computed by excluding the first day and including the last day; and if the last
day be Sunday or a legal holiday, that day shall be excluded.
COUNCIL: The city council of the city of Okmulgee, Oklahoma. "All its members"
or "all councilmen" means the total number of councilmen provided by the
general laws of the state of Oklahoma.
COUNTY: The county of Okmulgee, Oklahoma.
LAW: Denotes applicable federal law, the constitution and statutes of the state
of Oklahoma, the ordinances of the city of Okmulgee, and when appropriate, any
and all rules and regulations which may be promulgated thereunder.
MAY: Is permissive.
MONTH: A calendar month.
MUST AND SHALL: Are both mandatory.
OATH: Shall be construed to include an affirmation or declaration in all cases
in which, by law, an affirmation may be substituted for an oath, and in such
cases the words "swear" and "sworn" shall be equivalent to the words "affirm"
and "affirmed".
ORDINANCE: A law of the city; provided that a temporary or special law,
administrative action, order or directive, may be in the form of a resolution.
OWNER: Applied to a building or land includes any part owner, joint owner,
tenant in common, joint tenant or tenant by the entirety, of the whole or a
part of such building or land.
PERSON: Natural person, joint venture, joint stock company, partnership,
association, club, company, corporation, business, trust, organization, or the
manager, lessee, agent, servant, officer or employee of any of them.
PERSONAL PROPERTY: Includes money, goods, chattels, things in action and
evidences of debt.
PRECEDING AND FOLLOWING: Next before and next after, respectively.
PROPERTY: Includes real and personal property.
REAL PROPERTY: Includes lands, tenements and hereditaments.
SIDEWALK: That portion of a street between the curb line and the adjacent
property line intended for the use of pedestrians.
STATE: The state of Oklahoma.
STREET: Includes all streets, highways, avenues, lanes, alleys, courts, places,
squares, curbs, or other public ways in this city which have been or may
hereafter be dedicated and open to public use, or such other public property so
designated in any law of this state.
TENANT AND OCCUPANT: Applied to a building or land, includes any person who
occupies whole or a part of such building or land, whether alone or with
others.
TITLE OF OFFICE: Use of the title of any officer, employee, department, board,
or commission means that officer, employee, department, board or commission of
the city.
WRITTEN: Includes printed, typewritten, mimeographed or multigraphed.
YEAR: A calendar year.
All words and phrases shall be construed and understood according to the common
and approved usage of the language; but technical words and phrases and such
others as may have acquired a peculiar and appropriate meaning in the law shall
be construed and understood according to such peculiar and appropriate meaning.
(Ord. 1218 § 2, 1974)
1.04.020: GRAMMATICAL INTERPRETATION:
The following grammatical rules shall apply in the ordinances of the city:
   A.   Gender: The masculine gender includes the feminine and neuter genders.
   B.   Singular And Plural: The singular number includes the plural, and the
plural includes the singular.
   C.   Tenses: Words used in the present tense include the past and the future
tenses and vice versa, unless manifestly inapplicable.
   D.   Use Of Words And Phrases: Words and phrases not specifically defined
shall be construed according to the context and approved usage of the language.
(Ord. 1218 § 3, 1974)
1.04.030: PROHIBITED ACTS INCLUDE CAUSING, PERMITTING, ETC.:
Whenever in the ordinances of the city any act or omission is made unlawful, it
shall include causing, allowing, permitting, aiding, abetting, suffering, or
concealing the fact of such act or omission. (Ord. 1218 § 4, 1974)
1.04.040: CONSTRUCTION:
The provisions of the ordinances of the city and all proceedings under them are
to be construed with a view to effect their objects and to promote justice.
(Ord. 1218 § 5, 1974)
1.04.050: REPEAL NOT TO REVIVE ANY ORDINANCES:
The repeal of an ordinance shall not repeal the repealing clause of such
ordinance or revive any ordinance which has been repealed thereby. (Ord. 1218 §
6, 1974)
1.04.060: ORDINANCES IN EFFECT IN OUTLYING REAL PROPERTY OF CITY:
All ordinances of the city now in effect within the city are hereby extended to
all real property belonging to, or under the control of, the city outside the
corporate limits of the city, and shall be in full effect therein, insofar as
they are applicable. All ordinances of the city which shall go into effect in
the future, shall also apply to, and be in full effect within the boundaries of
all said outlying real property, insofar as they may be applicable. Any words
in any ordinance indicating that the effect of an ordinance provision is
limited to the corporate limits of the city shall be deemed to mean and include
also the outlying real property belonging to or under the control of the city,
unless the context clearly indicates otherwise. (Prior code § 366)
1.04.070: OKLAHOMA MUNICIPAL LEAGUE; MEMBERSHIP AUTHORIZED:
The city is authorized to procure the services of the Oklahoma Municipal League
and to have membership therein, and to appropriate funds to pay for such
services and membership. (Prior code § 367)
1.04.080: STOLEN, ABANDONED OR UNCLAIMED PROPERTY; DISPOSITION:
All stolen property recovered by the police department of the city shall be
turned over to the chief of police of the city. Lost or abandoned property
recovered by the police department of the city shall be turned over to the
chief of police of the city. The chief of police or a delegate shall return the
property to any person making satisfactory proof of title thereto. If such
property is unclaimed within ninety (90) days, then the chief of police or a
delegate may dispose of said property in the following manner:
   A.   The chief of police, after consulting with the city attorney, has
determined the property is no longer needed as evidence or for any other
purpose in connection with any litigation, then the chief of police or a
delegate shall file an application in the district court for Okmulgee County,
requesting authority to dispose of the property. Said application shall have
attached thereto a list of property having a fair market value in excess of its
face value and otherwise complying with state statute as to form, content, and
published notice.
   B.   The application shall specify:
      1.   Which property is proposed for donation to one or more not for
profit corporations,
      2.   Which property is proposed for sale at auction,
      3.   Which property is proposed for sale on the internet,
      4.   Which property is proposed to be kept by the city of Okmulgee for
use,
      5.   Which property is proposed to be disposed of by other stated means,
and
      6.   Which property is proposed to be destroyed; provided, that weapons
which are not destroyed or kept for use by the city of Okmulgee shall be sold
only to a person or entity holding a valid and current federal firearms
dealer's license.
   C.   Disposition will be in accord with the court order rendered on the
application. Regardless of the means of disposition, the chief of police shall
make a return to the court.
   D.   After payment of court costs and other expenses, the remainder of money
received from the sale of the personal property shall be paid to the city clerk
and deposited in the municipal fund. (Ord. 1869 § 1, 2006: Ord. 1364 § 1, 1979:
prior code § 368)
1.04.090: STOLEN, ABANDONED OR UNCLAIMED PROPERTY; RECORDS:
The chief of police shall cause an accurate record to be maintained to identify
the property, the date of its acquisition, the circumstances under which it was
acquired by the department, the circumstances of any subsequent disposal of
said property (including the date of the disposition, the purchaser, address
and amount of the sale if the property was sold). (Ord. 1869 § 2, 2006: Ord.
1364 § 2, 1979: prior code § 369)
1.04.100: READING OF PROPOSED ORDINANCES:
For the purpose of compliance with article II, section 17 of the Okmulgee city
charter that requires that every proposed ordinance be read, it shall be
sufficient that every proposed ordinance be reduced to writing and a copy
provided to each council member prior to the final passage of the ordinance;
provided that amendments to the proposed ordinance, if any, may be made by any
council member verbally and incorporated into the ordinance upon its adoption.
(Ord. 1806 § 1, 2002)
1.04.110: BOUNDARIES FOR THE WARDS OF THE CITY:
   A.   The boundaries of Ward 1 of the City of Okmulgee shall be all of that
contiguous land inside of the city limits and located generally north and east
of a line beginning at the northernmost edge of the city limits at its
intersection with the center median located on the right of way for Highway 75
(Wood Avenue), thence southerly along the center line of that road to the
intersection of E. Kennedy Street, thence easterly along the centerline of E.
Kennedy Street to the intersection of N. Osage Avenue, thence southerly to the
intersection of E. 6th Street, thence easterly along the centerline of E. 6th
to the intersection of Mission Road, thence northerly to the intersection of E.
4th Street, thence easterly along E. 4th Street to its intersection with the
eastern edge of the city limits.
   B.   The boundaries of Ward 2 of the City of Okmulgee shall be all of that
contiguous land inside of the city limits and located generally north and west
of a line beginning at the northernmost edge of the city limits at its
intersection with the center median located on the right of way for Highway 75
(Wood Avenue), thence southerly along the center line of that road to the
intersection of E. Kennedy Street, thence easterly along the centerline of E.
Kennedy Street to the intersection of N. Osage Avenue, thence southerly to the
intersection of E. 6th Street, thence westerly along the centerline of E. 6th
to the centerline of W. 6th and continuing westerly to the intersection of S.
Kern Ave., thence southerly along the centerline of S. Kern Avenue to its
intersection with W. 8th Street, thence westerly along the centerline of W. 8th
Street to its intersection with the western edge of the city limits.
   C.   The boundaries of Ward 3 of the City of Okmulgee shall be all of that
contiguous land inside of the city limits and located generally south and west
of a line beginning at the southern edge of the city limits at its intersection
with the centerline of the Railroad tracks as they exist on this date, thence
northerly along the center line of the railroad tracks to the intersection of
E. 20th Street, thence easterly along the centerline of E. 20th Street to the
intersection with S. Osage Avenue, thence northerly along the centerline of S.
Osage Avenue to the intersection with E. 12th Street, thence easterly along the
centerline of E. 12th Street to the intersection of S. Miami Avenue, thence
northerly along the centerline of S. Miami Avenue to the intersection of E.
10th Street, thence westerly to the intersection of S. Osage Avenue, thence
northerly along the centerline of S. Osage to the intersection of E. 6th
Street, thence westerly along the centerline of E. 6th to the centerline of W.
6th and continuing westerly to the intersection of S. Kern Ave., thence
southerly along the centerline of S. Kern Avenue to its intersection with W.
8th Street, thence westerly along the centerline of W. 8th Street to its
intersection with the western edge of the city limits.
   D.   The boundaries of Ward 4 of the City of Okmulgee shall be all of that
contiguous land inside of the city limits and located generally south and east
of a line beginning at the southern edge of the city limits at its intersection
with the centerline of the Railroad tracks as they exist on this date, thence
northerly along the center line of the railroad tracks to the intersection of
E. 20th Street, thence easterly along the centerline of E. 20th Street to the
intersection with S. Osage Avenue, thence northerly along the centerline of S.
Osage Avenue to the intersection with E. 12th Street, thence easterly along the
centerline of E. 12th Street to the intersection of S. Miami Avenue, thence
northerly along the centerline of S. Miami Avenue to the intersection of E.
10th Street, thence westerly along the centerline of E. 10th Street to the
intersection of S. Osage Avenue, thence northerly along the centerline of S.
Osage to the intersection of E. 6th Street, thence easterly along the
centerline of E. 6th to the intersection of Mission Road, thence northerly to
the intersection of E. 4th Street, thence easterly along the centerline of E.
4th Street to its intersection with the eastern edge of the city limits.
   E.   The council expressly finds that each of the wards are geographically
contiguous in each of their respective parts, have less than a two percent (2%)
variation in population as based on the most recent federal census, have
clearly delineated boundaries at all locations which are easily recognizable by
simple examination of the surface features of the land, and retains the
historic preference for quadrants as the general basis for ward boundaries.
(Ord. 1976, 2011)
1.04.120: RETENTION OF CITY OWNED VIDEO:
Video media recorded from normal daily surveillance cameras on city owned
facilities shall be stored and maintained for a period of ninety (90) days and
on or after the ninety first day shall be purged either manually or
automatically. Video involving active or anticipated investigations, legal
action or active or anticipated complaints may be stored separately and shall
be maintained in the custody of the city manager or his/her designee and shall
not be purged, deleted or destroyed without written authorization from either
the city manager or the city attorney.
Video media collected by city of Okmulgee police department in- car video
equipment shall be maintained for a period of ninety (90) days and on or after
the ninety first day shall be purged either manually or automatically. Video
involving physical arrests, pursuits or uses of force shall be attached
electronically to the police report and shall not be purged, deleted or
destroyed without written authorization from the chief of police. Video of
active or anticipated investigations, legal action or complaints may be
maintained separately by the chief of police and shall not be purged, deleted
or destroyed without his/her written authorization.
Video media collected by city of Okmulgee police department body worn video
equipment shall be maintained for a period of ninety (90) days and on or after
the ninety first day shall be purged either manually or automatically. Video
involving arrests, pursuits (vehicular or foot pursuits), or use of force shall
be attached electronically to the police report and shall not be purged,
deleted or destroyed without written authorization from the chief of police.
Video involving active or anticipated investigations, legal action or
complaints may be maintained separately in the custody of the chief of police
and shall not be purged, deleted or destroyed without his/her written
authorization. (Ord. 2059, 2015)
CHAPTER 1.08
RIGHT OF ENTRY FOR INSPECTION
SECTION:
1.08.010: Inspection Notice And Search Warrant
1.08.010: INSPECTION NOTICE AND SEARCH WARRANT:
Whenever necessary to make an inspection to enforce any ordinance or
resolution, or whenever there is reasonable cause to believe there exists an
ordinance or resolution violation in any building or upon any premises within
the jurisdiction of the city, any authorized official of the city may, upon
presentation of proper credentials, enter such building or premises at all
reasonable times to inspect the same or to perform any duty imposed upon him by
ordinance; provided, that except in emergency situations or when consent of the
owner and/or occupant to the inspection has been otherwise obtained, he shall
give the owner and/or occupant, if they can be located after reasonable effort,
twenty four (24) hours' written notice of the authorized official's intention
to inspect. The notice transmitted to the owner and/or occupant shall state
that the property owner has the right to refuse entry and that in the event
such entry is refused, inspection may be made only upon the issuance of a
search warrant by a duly authorized magistrate. In the event the owner and/or
occupant refuses entry after such request has been made, the official is
empowered to seek assistance from any court of competent jurisdiction in
obtaining such entry. (Ord. 1223 § 1, 1974)
CHAPTER 1.12
GENERAL PENALTY, FINES AND COSTS
SECTION:
1.12.010: Penalties And Fees
1.12.020: Attempts Punishable As Offense
1.12.030: Counseling Or Aiding Offense
1.12.040: Court Costs
1.12.050: Crimes And Offenses Are Misdemeanors
1.12.060: Establishment Of An Administrative Fee For Municipal Court
1.12.070: Establishment Of Police Department Training And Equipment Account
1.12.010: PENALTIES AND FEES:
   A.   Except in cases where a different punishment is now or may hereafter be
prescribed by ordinance, any person, firm, or corporation, who shall commit an
offense, or violate any section of this code or charter provision, or any
subsequent ordinance of the city, shall upon conviction be fined in an amount
not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00) plus court costs, the fees and
mileage of witnesses, if any, and any other fees, assessments or costs imposed
by Oklahoma Statutes to be collected by the Okmulgee municipal court,
including, but not limited to, a separate penalty assessment and a
fingerprinting fee. Provided, that the municipal court shall not impose a
penalty for any conviction that is in excess of the maximum penalty available
in district court upon conviction for the same offense.
   B.   Any person convicted of a misdemeanor offense, including misdemeanor
traffic offenses but excluding parking and standing violations, punishable by a
fine of ten dollars ($10.00) or more or by incarceration or any person
forfeiting bond when charged with such an offense, shall be ordered by the
Okmulgee municipal court to pay nine dollars ($9.00) to the city as a separate
penalty assessment for each offense as required under 20 Oklahoma Statutes
section 1313.2.
   C.   In addition to the separate penalty assessments imposed by subsections
B, D and E of this section, any person convicted of any offense, including
traffic offenses but excluding parking and standing violations, punishable by a
fine of ten dollars ($10.00) or more or by incarceration or any person
forfeiting bond when charged with such offense, shall be ordered by the
Okmulgee municipal court to pay a fingerprinting fee to the city in the amount
of five dollars ($5.00) for each offense as required under 20 Oklahoma Statutes
section 1313.3.
   D.   In addition to the separate penalty assessment imposed by subsection B
of this section and in addition to the fingerprinting fee imposed by subsection
C of this section, any person convicted of any offense, including traffic
offenses but excluding parking and standing violations, punishable by a fine of
ten dollars ($10.00) or more or by incarceration or any person forfeiting bond
when charged with such offense, shall be ordered by the Okmulgee municipal
court to pay a forensic science improvement assessment fee to the city in the
amount of five dollars ($5.00) for each offense as required under 20 Oklahoma
Statutes section 1313.4.
   E.   In addition to the separate penalty assessment imposed by subsection B
of this section, the fingerprinting fee imposed by subsection C of this section
and the forensic science improvement assessment fee imposed by subsection D of
this section, any person convicted of any misdemeanor offense, excluding
traffic offenses and parking and standing misdemeanor violations, but including
misdemeanor violations of 47 Oklahoma Statutes section 11-902 (driving under
the influence of alcohol or drugs), punishable by a fine of ten dollars
($10.00) or more or by incarceration or any person forfeiting bond when charged
with such misdemeanor offense, shall be ordered by the Okmulgee municipal court
to pay a medical expense liability fee in the amount of ten dollars ($10.00)
for each misdemeanor offense, to the city, as required under 20 Oklahoma
Statutes section 1313.7. The medical expense liability fee shall be in addition
to and not in substitution for any and all fines and penalties otherwise
provided for by law for such offense as provided in 20 Oklahoma Statutes
section 1313.7.
   F.   Any person, firm, or corporation, who shall:
      1.   Commit an offense, or violate any section of this code relating to
assault, battery, driving under a suspended driver's license, selling or
delivering alcohol to a minor, driving while intoxicated, leaving the scene of
an accident, eluding the police, pimping or prostitution, and
      2.   Having been previously convicted of a violation of the same
provision of this code within ten (10) years of the most recent allegation,
may be charged as a repeat offender, and shall upon conviction be fined in an
amount not less than four hundred dollars ($400.00) nor more than seven hundred
fifty dollars ($750.00) plus court costs, the fees and mileage of witnesses, if
any, and any other fees, assessments or costs imposed by Oklahoma Statutes to
be collected by the Okmulgee municipal court. However, the municipal court
shall not impose a penalty for any conviction that is in excess of the maximum
penalty available in district court upon conviction for the same offense. (Ord.
2004, 2013: Ord. 1936 § 1, 2009: Ord. 1867 § 1, 2006: Ord. 1849 § 1, 2004: Ord.
1840 § 1, 2003: Ord. 1786 § 1, 2001: Ord. 1761 § 1, 2000: Ord. 1513 § 1, 1984:
Ord. 1451 § 1, 1982: Ord. 1216 § 2, 1974)
1.12.020: ATTEMPTS PUNISHABLE AS OFFENSE:
Every person who attempts to commit an offense against the ordinances of the
city, and in such attempt does any act toward the commission of such offense,
but fails or is prevented or intercepted in the perpetration thereof, is guilty
of an offense, and shall be punished in the manner prescribed for the attempted
offense itself. (Prior code § 376)
1.12.030: COUNSELING OR AIDING OFFENSE:
When no punishment for counseling or aiding in the commission of a particular
offense is expressly prescribed by ordinance, every person who counsels or aids
another in the commission of such is guilty of an offense or misdemeanor, and
punishable in the same manner as the principal offender. (Prior code § 377)
1.12.040: COURT COSTS:
See section
2.80.200 of this code. (Ord. 1938 § 1, 2009)
1.12.050: CRIMES AND OFFENSES ARE MISDEMEANORS:
The commission of any crime, unlawful act, offense or any violation of any
section of any ordinance, code of ordinances of the city or city charter
provision or any subsequent ordinance or charter provision of the city, by any
person, firm or corporation, shall constitute the commission of, and is hereby
expressly declared to be, a misdemeanor and upon conviction shall be punishable
as a misdemeanor, including, but not limited to, any attempts, counseling and/
or aiding the commission of any crime, unlawful act, offense or violation of
any section of any ordinance, code of ordinances of the city or city charter
provision or any subsequent ordinance or charter provision of the city. (Ord.
1797 § 1, 2002)
1.12.060: ESTABLISHMENT OF AN ADMINISTRATIVE FEE FOR MUNICIPAL COURT:
There is hereby established a community service administrative fee or a
probationary fee, to be set by the court but not to exceed that allowed by
state statute or state court rule. Said fee may be imposed per each charge on a
deferred prosecution or on each conviction involving a deferred sentence or a
sentence to community service, and shall be paid by the defendant. Said fee may
be waived by the municipal judge or city attorney, but only in writing and only
in the interests of justice. (Ord. 1915 § 1, 2008)
1.12.070: ESTABLISHMENT OF POLICE DEPARTMENT TRAINING AND EQUIPMENT ACCOUNT:
There is hereby established a police department training and equipment account
to be funded annually by appropriations of available funds derived from a
portion of the monies actually paid and collected as community service
administrative fees equal to the sum of ten dollars ($10.00) per each
conviction or case. Funds appropriated to the police department training and
equipment account shall be used to pay the cost of training required by the
United States, the state of Oklahoma and/or the city and/or the cost of
equipment required by the United States, the state of Oklahoma and/or the city.
Funds appropriated to the police department training and equipment account
shall not be used to pay wages, supplements to wages or for instructor's pay.
Funds appropriated to the police department training and equipment account and
not encumbered prior to the end of any fiscal year, shall be available for
other purposes as may be determined by the city. (Ord. 1837 § 2, 2003)
CHAPTER 1.16
FINES AND COSTS; IMPRISONMENT
SECTION:
1.16.010: Failure To Pay Fine Or Costs; Credit; Action
1.16.020: Prisoners' Care And Feeding; Requiring Prisoners To Work; Credit For
Working
1.16.030: Prisoner Payment Of Costs Of Incarceration
1.16.010: FAILURE TO PAY FINE OR COSTS; CREDIT; ACTION:
If a defendant who is financially able refuses or neglects to pay a fine or
costs, or both, payment may be enforced by imprisonment until the same shall be
satisfied at the rate of forty dollars ($40.00) per day less the cost of
incarceration. If the defendant is without means to pay the fine or costs, the
municipal judge may direct the total amount due to be entered upon the court
minutes and certified to the district court of Okmulgee County, where it shall
be entered upon the district court judgment docket and shall have the full
force and effect of a district court judgment. Thereupon the same remedies
shall be available for the enforcement of the judgment as are available to any
other judgment creditor. (Ord. 1867 § 1, 2006: Ord. 1393 § 1, 1981: Ord. 1225 §
2, 1974)
1.16.020: PRISONERS' CARE AND FEEDING; REQUIRING PRISONERS TO WORK; CREDIT FOR
WORKING:
   A.   All prisoners confined to jail on conviction or plea of guilty, and all
indigent persons fined on conviction or plea of guilty, if their health
permits, may be allowed to work on the public streets, avenues, alleys, parks
or other public premises or property; prisoners imprisoned for the failure to
pay a fine or costs, or both, shall be credited at the rate of eighty dollars
($80.00) per day for each day worked; prisoners imprisoned to serve time shall
be credited with two (2) days for each day worked.
   B.   It shall be the duty of the chief of police, subject to the direction
of the city manager, to direct when and where the work shall be performed. It
shall be the duty of the head of the department in charge of the area or
property where the work is to be performed to supervise said prisoner and to
oversee such work, or the department head shall designate a subordinate to
supervise said prisoner and to oversee such work. If the department head
believes a guard is necessary, the chief of police shall provide a policeman to
serve as such guard. (Ord. 1867 § 1, 2006: Ord. 1393 § 2, 1981: prior code §
431)
1.16.030: PRISONER PAYMENT OF COSTS OF INCARCERATION:
   A.   The city attorney shall ask the court to require a person confined in
the city jail or county jail as a city prisoner for any municipal offense, to
pay the jail facility the costs of incarceration, both before and after
conviction, upon conviction or receiving a deferred sentence. Costs of
incarceration shall include booking, receiving and processing out, housing,
food, clothing, medical care, dental care and psychiatric services. The costs
for incarceration shall be an amount equal to the actual cost of the services
and shall be determined by the Okmulgee chief of police for the city jail, the
jail administrator of the county jail operated by the Okmulgee County criminal
justice authority or its successor(s) as the public entity responsible for the
operation of the county jail or by contract amount, if applicable. The cost of
incarceration shall be paid by the city prisoner to the city or to the Okmulgee
County criminal justice authority or its successor(s) as the public entity
responsible for the operation of the county jail, where the person is held
before and after conviction.
   B.   The costs of incarceration shall not be assessed if, in the judgment of
the court, such costs would impose a manifest hardship on the person, or if in
the opinion of the court the property of the person is needed for the
maintenance and support of immediate family.
   C.   In cases where a city prisoner is confined in the county jail for a
municipal offense, the city prisoner shall be deemed by the city to be confined
in the city jail for purposes of compliance with title 11, Oklahoma Statutes,
section 14-113. Payment of the cost of incarceration in such cases shall be
made by the city prisoner to the Okmulgee County criminal justice authority as
the public entity responsible for the operation of the county jail. To the
extent that the cost of incarceration of a city prisoner confined in the county
jail for a municipal offense is paid by a city prisoner to the Okmulgee County
criminal justice authority, the amount so paid shall offset and decrease the
amount of money, if any, owed by the city to the Okmulgee County criminal
justice authority for any cost of city prisoner incarceration.
   D.   The city attorney is authorized to ask the court to require a person
confined in the city jail or county jail as a city prisoner, for any municipal
offense, to pay the jail facility the costs of incarceration, on a case by case
basis or by way of a standing request in writing to include all cases.
   E.   At any time prior to sentencing, the convicted defendant may be
required to reimburse the jail facility for the costs of incarceration prior to
release from the facility. (Ord. 1831 § 1, 2003)
CHAPTER 1.20
ABSENTEE VOTING
SECTION:
1.20.010: Authorization; Laws Applicable
1.20.010: AUTHORIZATION; LAWS APPLICABLE:
Absentee voting shall be authorized in all city elections. The provisions of
state law set forth in title 26, Oklahoma Statutes, section 14-101 and
following, as may be amended, prescribing the regulations and procedures for
absentee voting, shall govern insofar as applicable. (Ord. 1358 § 1, 1979)

ARTICLE I. 1997 PLAN
1.70.010: EMPLOYEE RETIREMENT SYSTEM DEFINED CONTRIBUTION PLAN (1997):
Pursuant to the authority conferred by the laws of the state of Oklahoma, and
for the purpose of encouraging continuity and meritorious service on the part
of city employees and thereby promote public efficiency, there is authorized,
created, established, and approved and adopted, effective as of July 1, 1997,
the funded pension plan designated "employee retirement system of city of
Okmulgee, Oklahoma, defined contribution plan", (hereinafter called system), an
executed counterpart of which is marked exhibit A and exhibit B and attached to
the ordinance codified in this article as part of this article. (Ord. 1728 § 1,
1998)
1.70.020: ADMINISTRATION:
For the purpose of administering the system there is established a board of
trustees, which shall be the members of the council of city of Okmulgee,
Oklahoma, as now existing or as from time to time duly elected or appointed and
constituted. The powers and duties of the board of trustees shall be as set
forth in the system instrument attached to the ordinance codified in this
article as exhibit A. (Ord. 1728 § 2, 1998)
1.70.030: FUND:
A fund is provided for the exclusive use and benefit of the persons entitled to
benefits under the system. All contributions to such fund shall be paid over to
and received in trust for such purpose by the city treasurer, who shall be the
treasurer of the system. Such fund shall be pooled for purposes of management
and investment with similar funds of other incorporated cities, towns and
municipal trusts in the state as a part of the Oklahoma municipal retirement
fund in accordance with the trust agreement of the Oklahoma municipal
retirement fund, a public trust. The city treasurer shall hold such
contributions in the form received, and from time to time pay over and transfer
the same to the Oklahoma municipal retirement fund, as duly authorized and
directed by the board of trustees. The fund shall be nonfiscal and shall not be
considered in computing any levy when the annual estimate is made to the county
excise board. (Ord. 1728 § 3, 1998)
1.70.040: APPROPRIATIONS:
The city of Okmulgee is authorized to incur the necessary expenses for the
establishment, operation and administration of the system, and to appropriate
and pay the same. In addition, the city of Okmulgee, Oklahoma, is authorized to
appropriate annually such amounts as are required in addition to employee
contributions to maintain the system and the fund in accordance with the
provisions of the defined contribution plan. Any appropriation so made to
maintain the system and fund shall be for deferred wages or salaries, and for
the payment of necessary expenses of operation and administration to be
transferred to the trustees of the Oklahoma municipal retirement fund for such
purposes and shall be paid into the fund when available, through the city
treasurer, to be by him duly transferred to the Oklahoma municipal retirement
fund. (Ord. 1728 § 4, 1998)
1.70.050: EXECUTION:
The mayor and city clerk are each authorized and directed to execute (in
counterparts, each of which shall constitute an original) the system
instrument, and to do all other acts and things necessary, advisable and proper
to put the system and related trust into full force and effect, and to make
such changes therein as may be necessary to qualify the same under sections 401
(a) and 501(a) of the internal revenue code of the United States. The
counterpart attached to the ordinance codified in this article as exhibit A,
which has been duly executed as aforesaid simultaneously with the passage of
this article and made a part of this article, is ratified and confirmed in all
respects.
This council is authorized and directed to proceed immediately on behalf of
city of Okmulgee, Oklahoma, to pool and combine the fund into the Oklahoma
municipal retirement fund as a part thereof, with similar funds of such other
cities and towns, for purposes of pooled management and investment. (Ord. 1728
§ 5, 1998)
1.70.060: REPEALER:
Any ordinance inconsistent with the terms and provisions of this article is
repealed; provided, however, that such repeal shall be only to the extent of
such inconsistency and in all other respects this article shall be cumulative
of other ordinances regulating and governing the subject matter covered by this
article. (Ord. 1728 § 6, 1998)
1.70.070: SEVERABILITY:
If, regardless of cause, any section, subsection, paragraph, sentence or clause
of this article, including the system as set forth in exhibit A attached to the
ordinance codified in this article, is held invalid or to be unconstitutional,
the remaining sections, subsections, paragraphs, sentences or clauses shall
continue in full force and effect and shall be construed thereafter as being
the entire provisions of this article. (Ord. 1728 § 7, 1998)

ARTICLE II. 2002 PLAN
1.80.100: EMPLOYEE RETIREMENT SYSTEM, CITY MANAGER'S DEFINED CONTRIBUTION PLAN
AMENDED:
The employee retirement system, city manager's defined contribution plan, of
the city of Okmulgee, Oklahoma, is hereby amended as reflected on exhibit A
attached to the ordinance codified in this article, which is incorporated
herein and adopted by reference. These amendment shall become effective on July
1, 2001. (Ord. 1777 § 1, 2001)
1.80.110: EXECUTION:
The city clerk and mayor be and they are hereby authorized and directed to
execute the amended retirement system plan documents and to do all the other
acts necessary to put said amendment into effect and to maintain IRS
qualification of the plan. The executed amended document attached to the
ordinance codified in this article as exhibit A is hereby ratified and
confirmed in all respects. (Ord. 1777 § 2, 2001)
1.80.120: SEVERABILITY:
If, regardless of cause, any section, subsection, paragraph, sentence or clause
of this article, including the system as set forth in exhibit A attached to the
ordinance codified in this article, is held invalid or to be unconstitutional,
the remaining sections, subsections, paragraphs, sentences, or clauses shall
continue in full force and effect and shall be construed thereafter as being
the entire provisions of this article. (Ord. 1777 § 3, 2001)
1.80.130: REPEALER:
Any ordinance inconsistent with the terms and provisions of this article is
repealed; provided, however, that such repeal shall be only to the extent of
such inconsistency and in all other respects this article shall be cumulative
of other ordinances regulating and governing the subject matter covered by this
article. (Ord. 1777 § 4, 2001)
ARTICLE III. 2002A PLAN AMENDMENT
1.80.200: CITY MANAGER'S DEFINED CONTRIBUTION PLAN AMENDED 2002A:
The employee retirement system, city manager defined contribution plan of the
city of Okmulgee, Oklahoma, is hereby amended as shown on exhibit A economic
growth and tax relief act of 2001 amendment and required minimum distribution
amendment to the city of Okmulgee plan, which is attached to ordinance 1822 and
incorporated herein by reference. This amendment shall be effective as of July
1, 2002, and is hereby ratified and confirmed in all respects. (Ord. 1822 § 1,
2003)
1.80.210: MAYOR AND CITY CLERK AUTHORIZATION:
The mayor and city clerk are authorized and directed to execute the economic
growth and tax relief reconciliation act of 2001 amendment and required minimum
distribution amendment to the city of Okmulgee plan which is attached to
ordinance 1822 as exhibit A and to do all other acts necessary to put the
amendment into effect. (Ord. 1822 § 1, 2003)
1.80.220: REPEALER:
All ordinances in conflict herewith are hereby repealed. (Ord. 1822 § 1, 2003)
1.80.230: SEVERABILITY:
If any part, section or subsection of this article shall be held invalid or
unconstitutional for any reason, such holding shall not be construed to impair
or invalidate the remainder of this article notwithstanding such holding. (Ord.
1822 § 1, 2003)

CHAPTER 2.03
CITY COUNCIL MEETINGS
SECTION:
2.03.010: Regular Meeting Time
2.03.020: Place
2.03.010: REGULAR MEETING TIME:
The council of the city shall hold a regular meeting at five o'clock (5:00)
P.M. on every third Tuesday of every month; provided, that if such Tuesday
falls on a holiday, the regular meeting shall be held at that time of day on
the next day which is not a holiday. (Ord. 1906 § 1, 2007: Ord. 1614 § 1, 1987:
Ord. 1232 § 2, 1974)
2.03.020: PLACE:
Every meeting of the council shall be held in the council chamber in the city
hall unless, in case of an emergency, the mayor or the councilmen calling a
special meeting designate another place in the city for the holding of the
special meeting. (Prior code § 434)
CHAPTER 2.06
CITY MANAGER; POWERS AND DUTIES
SECTION:
2.06.010: Powers, Duties And Functions
2.06.010: POWERS, DUTIES AND FUNCTIONS:
The city manager shall have all the powers, duties and functions prescribed by
the charter, section 23, and any other sections thereof, or by ordinance. He
shall supervise and control, directly or indirectly, all administrative
departments, offices, agencies and employees appointed by himself or by his
subordinates; and within the limitations of the charter and ordinances, shall
have authority to assign duties and functions to them, and to regulate the
relationships among them. (Prior code § 435)
CHAPTER 2.09
AIRPORT DEPARTMENT
SECTION:
2.09.010: Public Works Director; Appointment; Supervision And Control
2.09.020: Powers And Duties
2.09.030: Wild Animal Control At The Airport
2.09.010: PUBLIC WORKS DIRECTOR; APPOINTMENT; SUPERVISION AND CONTROL:
There shall be an airport department, the head of which shall be the public
works director appointed by the city manager for an indefinite term, and
removable by the city manager. The public works director shall be an officer of
the city, and shall have supervision and control of the airport department. The
day to day business and operation of the airport department may be managed by a
supervisor or airport manager, appointed by the city manager for an indefinite
term and removable by the city manager. (Ord. 2006, 2013)
2.09.020: POWERS AND DUTIES:
It shall be the duty of the airport department to have charge of, control,
operate, repair, maintain, and improve the airport and all other aviation
facilities under the control of the city; and also to enforce and administer
all airport or aviation regulations of the city and, insofar as it may be
appropriate, of the federal and state governments and other duties prescribed
by ordinance or as directed by the city manager. (Ord. 1853 § 1, 2004)
2.09.030: WILD ANIMAL CONTROL AT THE AIRPORT:
   A.   From time to time, wild animals of various types will move onto and
make use of the habitat contained within the Okmulgee Regional Airport grounds,
particularly as to areas on the perimeter of the grounds that are used
primarily as flight path, or as buffer areas for sound and for obstructive
height control. On occasion, some of those animals will venture closer to the
runways, becoming a collision hazard to airplanes and other vehicles at the
airport. It would therefore be helpful to reduce the population of such
animals, with particular reference to large game birds and to deer, in order to
reduce the threat posed by a potential collision with these animals. Therefore,
commencing with the 2010-2011 state bow hunting season, the city manager is
hereby authorized to adopt hunting regulations for the governance of municipal
employees who may choose to bow hunt on the grounds of the Okmulgee Regional
Airport. Said municipal regulations shall be in addition to any and all
requirements under applicable state law. As the effectiveness of this effort
and the necessity for the effort to continue cannot be determined in advance,
the city manager may not adopt regulations of this nature or implement a
program based thereon, prior to July of the fiscal year in which such
regulations and program will be implemented and effective; therefore the
program and the regulations must be adopted solely on a year by year basis.
   B.   As a result of the program and regulations for control of the
population of wild animals on airport property, any employee carrying an actual
permit issued hereunder, a valid Oklahoma hunting license and a photo ID issued
by any state, local, federal or tribal government, may carry and may use a bow,
arrows, and associated archery equipment while within airport property; and
such use shall be exempt from any prohibition against carrying weapons or
discharging projectiles as to such archery equipment, other ordinances to the
contrary notwithstanding. (Ord. 1961, 2010)
CHAPTER 2.12
CENTRAL REPAIR DEPARTMENT
SECTION:
2.12.010: Public Works Director; Appointment; Supervision And Control
2.12.020: Duties Generally
2.12.010: PUBLIC WORKS DIRECTOR; APPOINTMENT; SUPERVISION AND CONTROL:

public works director appointed by the city manager for an indefinite term and

2, 2004)
2.12.020: DUTIES GENERALLY:
It shall be the duty of the central repair department to have charge of,
acquire, control, operate, repair, maintain and improve the fleet of vehicles

2004)
CHAPTER 2.13
COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT DEPARTMENT
SECTION:
2.13.010: Community Development Department; Composition
2.13.020: Duties Generally
2.13.010: COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT DEPARTMENT; COMPOSITION:
There shall be a department of community development, the head of which shall
be appointed by the city manager for an indefinite term and removable by the
city manager. The department of community development shall include planning
and zoning services, the building official, the code enforcement officer and
other inspectors. (Ord. 2017, 2014)
2.13.020: DUTIES GENERALLY:
The community development department shall see that all laws, ordinances and
other regulations related to building, plumbing, mechanical systems and
electrical systems, construction, subdivisions, zoning, nuisance abatement,
planning and historic preservation are properly enforced, except as may be
otherwise provided by applicable law or ordinance. The department of community
development shall have such powers, duties and functions as may be prescribed
by applicable law or ordinance or as may be directed by the city manager. (Ord.
2006, 2013)
CHAPTER 2.15
FINANCE DEPARTMENT
SECTION:
2.15.010: City Clerk; Appointment; Supervision And Control
2.15.020: City Clerk, Duties; Finance Director, Duties
2.15.010: CITY CLERK; APPOINTMENT; SUPERVISION AND CONTROL:
There shall be a department of finance, the head of which shall be, ex officio,
the city clerk appointed by the city manager for an indefinite term, and
removable by the city manager. The city clerk shall be an officer of the city,
and shall have, ex officio, supervision and control of the department of
finance. The day to day business and operation of the department of finance may
be managed and supervised by the finance director appointed by the city manager
for an indefinite term and removable by the city manager. (Ord. 1853 § 4, 2004)
2.15.020: CITY CLERK, DUTIES; FINANCE DIRECTOR, DUTIES:
   A.   The city clerk shall serve as clerk for the council of the city. The
city clerk shall keep the journal of the proceedings of the council and of any
of the duly constituted authorities of the city; enroll all ordinances and
resolutions passed by the council or by the trustees of any of the duly
constituted authorities of the city, in a book or set of books kept for that
purpose; have custody of documents, records and archives, as may be provided
for by law, charter or ordinance, and have custody of the seal of the city and
of the seals of any duly constituted authorities of the city; attest and affix
the seal of the city and the seals of any of the duly constituted authorities
of the city to documents as required by law, ordinance or as directed by the
city council and/or city manager; issue business licenses and permits and
ensure timely renewals of the same as may be provided for by law or ordinance;
provide public records and information to the public as may be requested in the
manner as may be provided for by law, charter or ordinance; and receive written
notice of tort claims filed with the office of the city clerk as provided by
law, keep a log or record of the same and administer the filed tort claims in a
manner consistent with Oklahoma law. The city clerk shall have the powers,
duties and functions as may be prescribed by applicable law, by the charter, by
ordinance or as may be directed by the city manager. The person who serves as
city clerk may be employed by the city to perform duties not related to his/her
position as city clerk.
   B.   The finance director on behalf of the city clerk ex officio, shall
collect or receive revenue and other money for the city, and shall deposit the
same daily with the city treasurer or for the city treasurer in an account or
accounts maintained by the city treasurer in a depository or depositories. The
finance director on behalf of the city clerk ex officio, shall maintain a
general accounting system for the city government. The finance director shall
have such other powers, duties and functions as may be prescribed by ordinance
or as directed by the city manager. (Ord. 1853 § 4, 2004)
CHAPTER 2.18
FIRE DEPARTMENT
SECTION:
2.18.010: Fire Chief; Appointment; Supervision And Control
2.18.020: Duties Generally
2.18.010: FIRE CHIEF; APPOINTMENT; SUPERVISION AND CONTROL:
There shall be a fire department, the head of which shall be the chief of the
fire department appointed by the city manager for an indefinite term, and
removable by the manager. The chief of the fire department shall, at all times
be an officer of the city and shall have the police powers, once CLEET
Certified, of a member of the police department, and shall have supervision and
control of the fire department. (Ord. 2190 § 1, 2023: Prior code § 442)
2.18.020: DUTIES GENERALLY:
It shall be the duty of the fire department, among others, to extinguish fires;
to rescue persons endangered by fire; to resuscitate and administer first aid
to persons injured in or about burning structures, or elsewhere in case of an
emergency, when it can be done without jeopardy of the public interest; to
promote fire prevention; and unless otherwise provided, to enforce all
ordinances relating to fires, fire prevention and safety of persons from fire
in theaters, stores and other public buildings. (Prior code § 443)
CHAPTER 2.21
HEALTH DEPARTMENT
SECTION:
2.21.010: Created; Health Officer And Superintendent Defined
2.21.020: Duties Generally
2.21.010: CREATED; HEALTH OFFICER AND SUPERINTENDENT DEFINED:
   A.   The county-city cooperative health department established in this
county, as provided in 63 Oklahoma Statutes section 1-207, shall serve as the
health department of this city, and be under the administrative supervision and
control of the city manager for city purposes, insofar as permitted by law.
   B.   The phrases "city superintendent of public health", "superintendent of
health", "superintendent of public health", "health officer" and other phrases
of the same meaning, wherever they occur in the ordinances of the city, shall
mean the administrative head, or director, of the cooperative health
department, unless otherwise clearly indicated by the context. He shall have
that status of head, or superintendent, of a city department of health insofar
as this is permitted by law, due recognition being given to his larger
responsibilities. (Prior code § 457)
2.21.020: DUTIES GENERALLY:
The cooperative department of health shall perform such duties, and have such
powers, as may be prescribed by ordinance, law, and the rules and regulations
of the state department of health. (Prior code § 458)

CHAPTER 2.33
POLICE DEPARTMENT
SECTION:
2.33.010: Police Chief; Appointment; Control
2.33.020: Department Duties Generally
2.33.030: Reserve Officers; Appointment; Duties And Requirements
2.33.040: Reward System Established For Information Provided To Law Enforcement
Leading To The Arrest And Conviction Of A Criminal Suspect Or Materially
Assisting In The Investigation Of The Commission Or Attempted Commission Of A
Crime
2.33.010: POLICE CHIEF; APPOINTMENT; CONTROL:
There shall be a police department, the head of which shall be the chief of
police appointed by the city manager for an indefinite term, and removable by
the manager. The chief of police shall be an officer of the city, and shall
have supervision and control of the police department. All policemen shall be
officers of the city. (Prior code § 440)
2.33.020: DEPARTMENT DUTIES GENERALLY:
It shall be the duty of the police department to apprehend and arrest on view
or on warrant and bring to justice all violators of the ordinances of the city;
to suppress all riots, affrays and unlawful assemblies which may come to their
knowledge, and generally to keep the peace; to serve all warrants, writs,
executions and other processes properly directed and delivered to them; to
apprehend and arrest persons violating federal or state law as provided by law,
and to turn them over to proper authorities; and in all respects to perform all
duties pertaining to the offices of policemen. (Prior code § 441)
2.33.030: RESERVE OFFICERS; APPOINTMENT; DUTIES AND REQUIREMENTS:
In addition to regular full time police officers, reserve police officers may
be appointed by the chief of police. Reserve officers shall have the same
powers, duties and functions of regular full time officers. A reserve officer
shall serve on a part time basis and shall perform his duties only while on
authorized duty and for not more than twenty five (25) hours per calendar week.
The chief of police shall only have authority to appoint as reserve officers
persons who meet the minimum requirements, and who possess the qualifications,
of 70 Oklahoma Statutes section 3311, as may be amended. (Ord. 1411 § 1, 1981)
2.33.040: REWARD SYSTEM ESTABLISHED FOR INFORMATION PROVIDED TO LAW ENFORCEMENT
LEADING TO THE ARREST AND CONVICTION OF A CRIMINAL SUSPECT OR MATERIALLY
ASSISTING IN THE INVESTIGATION OF THE COMMISSION OR ATTEMPTED COMMISSION OF A
CRIME:
   A.   There is hereby created an Okmulgee Reward System to be administered by
the Okmulgee Police Department, under the authority of the Chief of Police, for
the purpose of providing a method of disbursing cash awards, referred to as a
reward, to persons giving valuable information resulting in the arrest and
conviction of an accused person or materially assisting in the investigation of
the commission or attempted commission of a crime as determined by the Okmulgee
Police Department.
   B.   The Okmulgee Police Department shall implement such procedures and
regulations as are necessary to carry out the purposes of this act. Such
procedures shall include a method for determining the amount of reward to be
offered for information on a crime or series of crimes and which such crimes
shall have a reward offered to assist in their solution. The City Manager shall
set the maximum award per person and/or per event, and have final approval in
payment of the reward.
   C.   Any person seeking to collect all or part of a reward offered under the
provisions of this section shall submit the following information, and such
other information as the Chief may determine to be necessary, to the Chief of
Police :
      1.   The crime which was committed;
      2.   The name of the victim of the crime;
      3.   The name of the person arrested and convicted; and
      4.   A written statement from the investigating officer providing details
of the extent of the cooperation provided toward the resolution of the matter.
   D.   The Okmulgee Police Department and the City of Okmulgee shall make such
additional requirements as deemed necessary to assure proper disbursal of the
reward funds. Any person regularly employed as a peace officer, district
attorney or assistant district attorney, City of Okmulgee or its public trusts,
Okmulgee City Councilor, or any member of immediate family of such person shall
be prohibited from receiving any cash award from said fund.
   E.   Information about the claimant, the information supplied, the
investigation, the payment, approval of fund payment and any other identifying
information under this ordinance is confidential and not subject to disclosure
for any purpose except under the terms of 12 O.S. § 2510, and as amended, or
other court order under state or federal law.
   F.   All information regarding the request for reward, payment or non-
payment of a reward and the investigation shall remain a confidential record of
the investigation and is not subject to disclosure by an Open Records Request
to the City of Okmulgee.
   G.   All funds associated with the Reward System for Information on Criminal
Activity shall be paid through funds designated in the annual budget for the
City. (Ord. 2205 § 1, 2023)

CHAPTER 2.36
RECREATION BOARD
SECTION:
2.36.010: Created; Director Appointment And Duties (Rep. by Ord. 1809 § 2,
2002)
2.36.020: Duties Generally (Rep. by Ord. 1809 § 3, 2002)
2.36.030: Created; Terms
2.36.040: Meetings And Officers
2.36.050: Purpose And Function
2.36.010: CREATED; DIRECTOR APPOINTMENT AND DUTIES:
(Rep. by Ord. 1809 § 2, 2002)
2.36.020: DUTIES GENERALLY:
(Rep. by Ord. 1809 § 3, 2002)
2.36.030: CREATED; TERMS:
There is hereby created a recreation board which consists of five (5) members
appointed by the city council. Each council member and council member at large
shall nominate one person to the recreation board to be confirmed by the
council, and the board member shall serve for the same period of time as the
appointing council member's term of office, unless removed by the council.
Board members shall be qualified electors of the city and shall serve without
compensation. (Ord. 1912 § 1, 2008)
2.36.040: MEETINGS AND OFFICERS:
The board shall meet at city hall on a regular schedule of their choosing,
provided that they shall meet on a roughly monthly schedule. At the first
meeting following the start of the fiscal year for the city (July through
June), the board shall elect a chairperson and such other officers it deems
necessary or convenient. Any three (3) members may also call special meetings
of the board. All meetings of the board are subject to the Oklahoma open
meetings act. (Ord. 1926 § 1, 2008)
2.36.050: PURPOSE AND FUNCTION:
The purpose of the recreation board is to serve as an advisory group. The board
may consider the park and recreation needs of the city, its citizens and
inhabitants, make recommendations concerning these needs to the city council,
city manager and public works director or his or her designee. (Ord. 1809 § 4,
2002: Ord. 1193 § 5, 1972)

public works director appointed by the city manager for an indefinite term and
removable by the city manager. The public works director shall be an officer of
the city and shall have supervision and control of the warehouse inventory
department. The day to day business and operation of the warehouse inventory
department may be conducted by an inventory control specialist appointed by the
city manager for an indefinite term and removable by the city manager. (Ord.
1853 § 9, 2004)
2.43.020: DUTIES GENERALLY:
It shall be the duty of the warehouse inventory department, among others, to
acquire, purchase, order, stock, store, maintain and supply items of personal
property in inventory, needed and useful for other city departments in order to
take advantage of economies of scale and volume purchasing in order to lessen
the burdens of government, to stock items needed and useful which may be hard
to find items or items needed in quantity for immediate availability to prevent
delays and disruptions in service to the public and other duties as provided by
ordinance or as directed by the city manager. (Ord. 1853 § 9, 2004)
CHAPTER 2.44
WASTEWATER TREATMENT PLANT DEPARTMENT
SECTION:
2.44.010: Plant Operations Director; Appointment; Supervision And Control
2.44.020: Duties Generally
2.44.010: PLANT OPERATIONS DIRECTOR; APPOINTMENT; SUPERVISION AND CONTROL:

of the wastewater treatment plant department. The day to day business and

treatment plant of the city and the industrial pretreatment program of the city
and other duties as provided by ordinance or as directed by the city manager.
(Ord. 1853 § 10, 2004)

CHAPTER 2.47
UTILITY BILLING DEPARTMENT
SECTION:
2.47.010: Finance Director; Appointment; Supervision And Control
2.47.020: Duties Generally
2.47.030: Adoption Of The Red Flag Program
2.47.010: FINANCE DIRECTOR; APPOINTMENT; SUPERVISION AND CONTROL:
There shall be a utility billing department, the head of which shall be the
finance director appointed by the city manager for an indefinite term and
removable by the city manager. The finance director shall be an officer of the
city and shall have supervision and control of the utility billing department.
The day to day business and operation of the utility billing department may be
supervised by a supervisor appointed by the city manager for an indefinite term
and removable by the city manager. (Ord. 1853 § 13, 2004)
2.47.020: DUTIES GENERALLY:
It shall be the duty of the utility billing department to have charge of,
control, operate, repair, maintain and improve the utility billing system(s) of
the city and its duly created authorities, to ensure accurate and timely
billing for services rendered and other contractual and permit fees, to
purchase, acquire, install, repair, maintain, improve and read water meters of
the city, to activate and deactivate services and other duties as provided by
ordinance or as directed by the city manager. (Ord. 1853 § 13, 2004)
2.47.030: ADOPTION OF THE RED FLAG PROGRAM:
Whereas the federal trade commission has adopted identity theft rules which
require the creation of certain policies relating to the use of consumer
reports, address discrepancy, and the detection, prevention and mitigation of
identity theft, and these rules appear to impact certain operations of
municipalities such as the city of Okmulgee; and
Whereas, covered entities are required under 16 CFR section 681.2 to require
creditors, including utility companies, to adopt red flag policies to prevent
and mitigate identity theft with respect to covered accounts; and
Whereas the city of Okmulgee insofar as it offers water, sanitary sewer, solid
waste, and stormwater services appears to meet the definitions of federal
regulation and therefore is covered by this program and its requirements, so
that the city of Okmulgee is required to adopt this program on behalf of itself
and all of its public trusts; further the city of Okmulgee operates a municipal
court system which has accepted payment plans for the satisfaction of certain
penalties imposed at law, and such plans may contain some of the same types of
risks as to identity theft, at least to the extent that multiple payment
transactions may occur;
Therefore, the city of Okmulgee, acting through its city council hereby ordains
that the administrative rules entitled "identity theft prevention program"
dated April 9, 2009, attached to the ordinance codified herein, are hereby
adopted and approved effective this date. Provided that the city manager may
make periodic amendments to this program so long as the program remains in
compliance with the federal regulations covering the city of Okmulgee and so
long as the city manager makes a report of the program changes to the city
council not later than sixty (60) days after a proposed rule or program
amendment is announced. (Ord. 1934 § 1, 2009)
CHAPTER 2.48
COUNCIL HOUSE BOARD
(Rep. by Ord. 1984, 2012)
CHAPTER 2.51
MUNICIPAL EMPLOYEES
SECTION:
2.51.010: Number, Classes And Compensation
2.51.020: Bond Required; Amount
2.51.030: Appointments And Removals Generally
2.51.040: Officers To Continue Until Successors Are Elected Or Appointed And
Qualify
2.51.010: NUMBER, CLASSES AND COMPENSATION:
   A.   The council, by motion or resolution, may regulate the number and
classes of officers and employees in the various offices, departments and
agencies of the city government, and may determine or regulate the compensation
to be paid to officers and employees.
   B.   Neither the municipal judge nor any other officer or employee of the
city government may receive as compensation any fee of any kind except as may
be specifically provided by ordinance passed hereafter, and all fees and other
money collected for the city by an officer or employee shall be paid to the
city clerk to be deposited as provided by law. (Prior code § 468)
2.51.020: BOND REQUIRED; AMOUNT:
The city shall maintain a blanket surety bond covering all officials and
employees in an amount not less than one hundred thousand dollars
($100,000.00), and with a deductible not more than two thousand five hundred
dollars ($2,500.00). (Ord. 1465 § 1, 1983: prior code § 469)
2.51.030: APPOINTMENTS AND REMOVALS GENERALLY:
   A.   All appointments, elections, promotions, demotions, layoffs,
suspensions, and removals of officers and employees shall be done in the manner
prescribed by the city charter, not withstanding any provision in this code or
in any ordinance passed hereafter prescribing a different manner.
   B.   Any provision in this chapter regulating such method, which is in
conflict with any provision in any other chapter of this code, shall prevail
over such conflicting provision in the other chapter of this code.
   C.   Except as provided otherwise by the city charter, the power to promote,
lay off, suspend, demote and remove shall accompany the power to appoint or
elect; and the city manager or other appointing or electing authority at any
time may promote, lay off, suspend, demote or remove any officer or employee to
whom he or the other appointing or electing authority respectively may appoint
or elect a successor.
   D.   Acting officers and employees may be appointed as provided by section
51 of the city charter. (Prior code § 470)
2.51.040: OFFICERS TO CONTINUE UNTIL SUCCESSORS ARE ELECTED OR APPOINTED AND
QUALIFY:
Every officer who is elected or appointed for a term ending at a definite time,
shall continue to serve thereafter until his successor is elected or appointed
and qualifies unless his services are sooner terminated by resignation,
removal, disqualification, abolition of the office or other legal manner.
(Prior code § 471)
CHAPTER 2.60
PERSONNEL SYSTEM
SECTION:
2.60.030: Personnel Appeals Board; Appointment, Removal
2.60.040: Personnel Appeals Board; Duties
2.60.050: Classified And Unclassified Service
2.60.060: Political Activity
2.60.030: PERSONNEL APPEALS BOARD; APPOINTMENT, REMOVAL:
   A.   The city council shall appoint a personnel appeals board of three (3)
members, who are in sympathy with the merit system principle, for overlapping
six (6) year terms, the term of one member beginning at seven thirty o'clock
(7:30) P.M. on July 1 in every odd numbered year. The council shall appoint the
three (3) original members so that the term of one will expire at that time in
each of the first three (3) succeeding odd numbered years.
   B.   Any member of the board may be removed with cause at any time by a
majority vote of all members of the council. Vacancies on the appeals board
from whatever cause shall be filled by appointment by the city council for the
unexpired term. Each member shall serve until his successor is appointed and
qualified. The members of the personnel appeals board shall be qualified
freeholders of the city and shall serve without compensation. At the time
prescribed for the beginning of the term of a newly elected member or as soon
as practicable thereafter, the appeals board shall elect a chairman, a vice
chairman and a secretary. The secretary need not be a member of the board. The
board shall determine the time of its meetings, which are to be held in the
city hall, and the chairman or two (2) members may call special meetings of the
board. (Ord. 947 § 3, 1959)
2.60.040: PERSONNEL APPEALS BOARD; DUTIES:
The board shall hear appeals submitted by any regular employee in the
classified service relative to any suspension of more than ten (10) days,
demotion or dismissal, in accordance with rules of procedure approved by the
city council. The board shall submit a written statement of facts, findings and
recommendations to the city manager, who shall review such findings, facts and
recommendations and render a final decision on such suspension, demotion or
dismissal. (Ord. 1527, 1984: Ord. 947 § 4, 1959)
2.60.050: CLASSIFIED AND UNCLASSIFIED SERVICE:
   A.   All officers and employees of the city shall be divided into the
classified and the unclassified service. The following shall constitute the
unclassified service:
      1.   All members of the city council, the city manager and all other
personnel appointed, approved or confirmed by the council;
      2.   Part time personnel, including the city attorney, except such
temporary or part time personnel as may be placed in the classified service by
ordinance or personnel rules;
      3.   Members of boards and commissions and all other personnel who serve
without compensation.
   B.   All other officers and employees shall be in the classified service.
(Ord. 947 § 5, 1959)
2.60.060: POLITICAL ACTIVITY:
   A.   No person holding a paid position in the classified service shall seek
or accept election, nomination or appointment as an officer of a city of
Okmulgee political club or organization, or take an active part in, or make any
contribution or donation to, any city of Okmulgee political campaign, or serve
as a member of a committee of such club or organization or circle, or seek
signatures to any petition provided by any law, or act as a worker at the
polls, or distribute badges, pamphlets, dodgers or handbills of any kind
favoring or opposing any candidate for election to city of Okmulgee office;
provided however, that nothing in this chapter shall be construed to prevent
any such officer or employee from becoming or continuing to be a member of a
state or national political organization, or from attendance at a political
meeting, or from enjoying entire freedom from all interference in casting his
or her vote. An employee who wishes to accept or seek election, or appointment
to political office, shall review state law on dual office holding prior to
seeking or accepting such office.
   B.   Any wilful violation thereof or violation through culpable negligence
shall be sufficient grounds for the discharge of any officer or employee guilty
of such violation. Also, any officer or employee in the classified service may
be removed by the city manager. (Ord. 1955, 2010)
