2.63.010: ADOPTED:
Pursuant to the authority conferred by the City Charter, as amended, and by the
laws of the State of Oklahoma, and for the purpose of encouraging continuity
and meritorious service on the part of City employees and thereby promote
public efficiency, there is authorized, created, established, approved and
adopted, effective as of July 1, 1966, the funded pension plan designated
"employee retirement system of Okmulgee, Oklahoma", hereinafter called
"system", an executed counterpart of which is marked Exhibit A and on file in
the Office of the City Clerk. (Ord. 1084 § 1, 1966)
2.63.020: ADMINISTRATION; BOARD OF TRUSTEES:
For the purpose of administration of the system there is established a Board of
Trustees, which shall be the members of the City Council of the City, as now
existing or as from time to time duly elected or appointed and constituted. The
powers and duties of the Board of Trustees shall be as set forth in the system
instrument designated as Exhibit A, and filed in the Office of the City Clerk.
(Ord. 1084 § 2, 1966)
2.63.030: FUND; CONTRIBUTIONS AND VALUATION:
A fund is provided for the exclusive use and benefit of the persons entitled to
benefits under the system. All contributions to such fund shall be paid over to
and received in trust for such purpose by the City Treasurer, who shall be the
Treasurer of the system. Such fund shall be pooled for purposes of management
and investment with similar funds of other incorporated cities and towns in the
State of Oklahoma as a part of the Oklahoma Municipal Retirement Fund, in
accordance with a duly executed contract for such purpose which contract shall
be executed by the City Council as soon as feasible. The City Treasurer shall
hold such contributions in the form received, and from time to time pay over
and transfer the same to the Oklahoma Municipal Retirement Fund, as duly
authorized and directed by the Board of Trustees. The fund shall be nonfiscal
and shall not be considered in computing any levy when the annual estimate is
made to the County Excise Board. The fund and system shall be valued each year
for actuarial soundness by a qualified actuarial firm. (Ord. 1084 § 3, 1966)
2.63.040: FUND; APPROPRIATIONS:
The City is authorized to incur the necessary expenses for the establishment,
operation and administration of the system and to appropriate and pay the same.
In addition, the City is authorized to appropriate annually such amounts as are
required in addition to employee contributions, to maintain the system and the
fund on a sound actuarial basis in accordance with the respective annual
actuarial valuation. However, the amount so appropriated in any one fiscal year
of the City to maintain the system and Trust Fund shall not exceed fifteen
percent (15%) of the current annual salaries of all employees covered by the
system. Any appropriation so made to maintain the system and fund shall be for
deferred wages or salaries and for the payment of necessary expenses of
operation and administration, including separate annual appropriations to be
transferred to the Trustees of the Oklahoma Municipal Retirement Fund for such
purposes, and shall be paid into the fund when available, through the City
Treasurer, to be by him duly transferred to the Oklahoma Municipal Retirement
Fund. (Ord. 1266 § 1, 1975)
2.63.050: EXECUTION:
   A.   The mayor and city clerk are each authorized and directed to execute,
in counterparts, each of which shall constitute an original, the system
instrument, and to do all other acts and things necessary, advisable and proper
to put the system and related trust into full force and effect, and to make
such changes therein as may be necessary to qualify the same under sections 401
(a) and 501(a) of the internal revenue code of the United States. The
counterpart, on file in the office of the city clerk, which has been duly
executed as aforesaid simultaneously with the passage of this chapter and made
a part hereof, is ratified and confirmed in all respects.
   B.   The city council is authorized and directed to proceed immediately on
behalf of the city to negotiate a contract with other incorporated cities and
towns of the state of Oklahoma to pool and combine the fund into the Oklahoma
municipal retirement fund as a part thereof, with similar funds of such other
cities and towns, for purposes of pooled management and investment. The city
council shall manifest approval of such contract and the execution thereof by
the mayor and city clerk, by a formal resolution. (Ord. 1084 § 5, 1966)

CHAPTER 2.66
FIREMEN'S PENSION
SECTION:
2.66.010: Board Of Trustees Of Firemen's Relief And Pension Fund Created
2.66.020: Fund; Compliance With Law
2.66.030: Deduction From Firemen's Compensation
2.66.010: BOARD OF TRUSTEES OF FIREMEN'S RELIEF AND PENSION FUND CREATED:
There is created a board of trustees of the firemen's relief and pension fund
of the city, with membership, organization, powers, duties and functions as
prescribed by 11 Oklahoma Statutes 1951 section 361 et seq., 11 Oklahoma
Statutes supp. 1955 section 364a et seq., and as may be provided by any later
laws relating to the board. (Prior code § 472)
2.66.020: FUND; COMPLIANCE WITH LAW:
The firemen's relief and pension fund shall be operated in accordance with
state law relating to the fund, and pensions and other benefits shall be paid
as provided by state law. (Prior code § 473)
2.66.030: DEDUCTION FROM FIREMEN'S COMPENSATION:
   A.   From and after January 14, 1975, the city treasurer is authorized, and
it shall be the duty of the city treasurer, to deduct monthly from the salary
or wages of each member of the fire department of the city an amount equal to
four percent (4%) of the monthly salary or wages paid to such member of the
fire department. The four percent (4%) deduction shall be considered the
minimum deduction. The members of the fire department, by a majority vote of
its paid members, may vote to increase the amount of the deduction, and the
city treasurer shall deduct the authorized increase in deductions from the
salary or wages of each paid member of the fire department. The city treasurer
shall deposit monthly in the firemen's relief and pension fund the amount
deducted from the salary or wages of each member of the fire department.
   B.   From and after January 14, 1975, the city treasurer is directed to
deposit monthly or annually, upon agreement between the city and the
representatives of the fire department, in the firemen's relief and pension
fund of the fire department the following amounts of money:
      1.   Commencing on January 1, 1975, an amount equal to four percent (4%)
of the total salaries or wages paid the members of the fire department;
      2.   Commencing on January 1, 1976, an amount equal to four percent (4%)
of the total salaries or wages paid the members of the fire department; and
      3.   Commencing on January 1, 1977, and thereafter, an amount equal to
four percent (4%) of the total salaries or wages paid the members of the fire
department. (Ord. 1233 §§ 2, 3, 1974: prior code § 474)
CHAPTER 2.69
POLICE PENSION AND RETIREMENT SYSTEM
SECTION:
2.69.010: Board Of Trustees; Tenure; Duties
2.69.020: Subject To State Statutes
2.69.030: Amendments Or Alterations Of State Laws To Apply
2.69.040: Operation And Benefits; Compliance With State Law
2.69.050: Deduction From Salaries
2.69.060: Withdrawal From Agreements
2.69.070: Membership
2.69.010: BOARD OF TRUSTEES; TENURE; DUTIES:
The tenure in office of the board of trustees shall be continuous, and the
board of trustees as constituted immediately before December 28, 1964, under
and by virtue of this code shall continue and remain in their capacity as the
board of trustees under the state statute as herein adopted, and there shall be
no interruption in their responsibility or duties arising from and growing out
of the trusteeship. From and after December 28, 1964, the duties and
obligations of the trustees shall be delineated by state statute. (Ord. 1066 §
3, 1964)
2.69.020: SUBJECT TO STATE STATUTES:
The police pension and retirement system of the city hereafter shall be and now
is subject to the provisions, rules, regulations and requirements of the
statutes of the state of Oklahoma as set forth and provided in title 11,
sections 541 to 541W, both inclusive, and as amended or altered by the laws of
1963, sections 541.A to 541.S, both inclusive. (Ord. 1066 § 4, 1964)
2.69.030: AMENDMENTS OR ALTERATIONS OF STATE LAWS TO APPLY:
It is further provided that in the event of the alteration by amendment, repeal
or other modification of the police pension and retirement laws of the state of
Oklahoma herein adopted by the legislature, that the amendments or alterations
shall ipso facto upon their passage and adoption be applicable to and
controlling of the board of trustees of the Okmulgee pension and retirement
system. (Ord. 1066 § 5, 1964)
2.69.040: OPERATION AND BENEFITS; COMPLIANCE WITH STATE LAW:
The police pension and retirement fund shall be operated in accordance with the
requirements of state law relating to such a fund, and the pensions and other
benefits thereunder shall be paid as provided by state law. (Ord. 1066 § 6,
1964)
2.69.050: DEDUCTION FROM SALARIES:
From and after December 28, 1964, it shall be the duty of the city treasurer to
make deductions from salaries or wages of each member of the police department
of the city in the manner and in the amounts as required by law and as
determined under the law by the trustees. (Ord. 1066 § 7, 1964)
2.69.060: WITHDRAWAL FROM AGREEMENTS:
Any policeman who has served the police department of the city for a period of
more than one year, has contributed to the police pension and retirement system
fund for this period of time, and has served less than twenty (20) years in the
police department of the city or any other city or town in the state of
Oklahoma, having standards equivalent to those required in the city, and who
has entered into any agreement provided for under applicable state law adopted
by the city for the police pension and retirement system, may withdraw from
such agreement and shall be paid one-half (1/2) the amount of his contributions
to the fund of the city after deducting from the contributions all benefit
payments made him under the provisions of the applicable law or laws or
ordinances pertaining to the police pension and retirement system fund of the
city after which he shall not receive any of the benefits provided for under
applicable state law as set forth in sections
2.69.010 through 2.69.050 of this chapter. (Ord. 1080 § 1, 1966)
2.69.070: MEMBERSHIP:
All policemen in the employment of the city who qualify under the police
pension and retirement laws of the state to be members of the police pension
and retirement system shall be required to gain and hold membership in the
police pension and retirement system of the city. (Ord. 1343 § 1, 1978)
CHAPTER 2.72
FEDERAL OLD AGE AND SURVIVORS' INSURANCE
SECTION:
2.72.010: Extended To City Employees And Officers
2.72.020: Mayor Authority
2.72.030: Withholdings From Salary
2.72.040: Appropriations For Employer's Contributions
2.72.050: City To Keep Records
2.72.060: Exclusions; Those Covered By Other Systems
2.72.070: Exclusions; Those Compensated By Fees
2.72.010: EXTENDED TO CITY EMPLOYEES AND OFFICERS:
It is declared to be the policy and purpose of the city to extend at the
earliest date to the employees and officials thereof, not excluded by law or
this chapter, and whether employed in connection with a governmental or
proprietary function, the benefits of the system of federal old age and
survivors' insurance as authorized by the federal social security act and
amendments thereto, including public law 734, 81st congress. In pursuance of
this policy, and for that purpose, the city shall take such action as may be
required by applicable state or federal laws or regulations. (Prior code § 503)
2.72.020: MAYOR AUTHORITY:
The mayor and city clerk of the city are authorized and directed to execute all
necessary agreements and amendments thereto with the state department of public
welfare, as agent or agency, to secure coverage of employees and officials as
provided in section
2.72.010 of this chapter. (Prior code § 504)
2.72.030: WITHHOLDINGS FROM SALARY:
Withholdings from salaries or wages of employees and officials for the purpose
provided in section
2.72.010 of this chapter are authorized to be made in the amounts and at such
times as may be required by applicable state or federal laws or regulations,
and shall be paid over to the state or federal agency designated by these laws
or regulations. (Prior code § 505)
2.72.040: APPROPRIATIONS FOR EMPLOYER'S CONTRIBUTIONS:
There shall be appropriated from available funds such amounts at such times as
may be required by applicable state or federal laws or regulations for
employer's contributions, which shall be paid over to the state or federal
agency designated by the laws or regulations. (Prior code § 506)
2.72.050: CITY TO KEEP RECORDS:
The city shall keep such records and make such reports as may be required by
applicable state or federal laws or regulations. (Prior code § 507)
2.72.060: EXCLUSIONS; THOSE COVERED BY OTHER SYSTEMS:
There is excluded from this chapter any authority to make any agreement with
respect to any position or any employee or official now covered or authorized
to be covered by any other ordinance creating any retirement system for any
employee or official of the city. (Prior code § 508)
2.72.070: EXCLUSIONS; THOSE COMPENSATED BY FEES:
There is excluded from this chapter any authority to make any agreement with
respect to any position, or any employee or officials, compensation for which
is on a fee basis, or any position, or any employee or official not authorized
to be covered by applicable state or federal laws or regulations. (Prior code §
509)
ok820   2.80.TXT ()
CHAPTER 2.80
MUNICIPAL COURT
SECTION:
2.80.010: Applicability Of Provisions
2.80.020: Definitions
2.80.030: Jurisdiction
2.80.040: Judges
2.80.050: Prohibition On Change Of Venue
2.80.060: City Attorney As Prosecuting Officer
2.80.070: Court Clerk; Duties
2.80.080: Court Marshal; Duties
2.80.090: Bond Of Clerk
2.80.100: Fees, Fines And Forfeitures; Dispositions
2.80.110: Procedure; Judicial Notice Of Statutes And Ordinances; Writs And
Process
2.80.120: Rules For Conduct Of Court Business
2.80.130: Prosecutions By Verified Complaint; Style
2.80.135: Prosecutions By Verified Complaint; Means Of Verification
2.80.140: Arraignment; Fines In Lieu Of Appearance
2.80.150: Arrest; Release By Signing Citation; Bail Amount And Conditions;
Temporary Cash Bond
2.80.160: Failure To Appear According To Terms Of Bond; Forfeiture
2.80.162: Failure To Appear
2.80.164: Failure To Comply With Court Order
2.80.166: Failure To Comply With Written Promise To Appear With Juvenile
2.80.170: Suspension Of Judgment Or Costs; Reconfinement
2.80.180: Supervision Of Juveniles On Parole Or Probation
2.80.190: Contempt Of Court
2.80.195: Community Service In Lieu Of Fine Or In Conjunction With
Imprisonment; Violation Of Community Service Conditions
2.80.200: Court Costs
2.80.210: Prosecution For Same Offense In Another Court Prohibited
2.80.220: Writs Of Mandamus, Prohibition And Certiorari
2.80.230: Appeals
2.80.240: Schedule Of Fines In Lieu Of Appearance Bonds
2.80.010: APPLICABILITY OF PROVISIONS:
This chapter shall govern the organization and operation of the municipal court
as put into operation by resolution duly passed on January 13, 1981, and filed
in accordance with law as provided by 11 Oklahoma Statutes section 27-102. The
municipal court shall be a court not of record, as prescribed by 11 Oklahoma
Statutes section 27-101 and following. To the extent of conflict between any
provision of this chapter and the provisions of any other ordinance of this
city, the provisions of this chapter shall control. (Ord. 1397 § 3, 1981)
2.80.020: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this chapter unless the context requires a different meaning, the
following words shall mean:
CHIEF OF POLICE: The peace officer in charge of the police force of the
municipality.
CLERK: The court clerk of this municipality, including any deputy or member of
the office staff of the court clerk while performing duties of the court clerk
office; or any member of the municipality designated by the judge of the court
to act in that capacity from time to time.
COURT: The municipal court of this city.
GOVERNING BODY: The city council of the municipality.
JUDGE: The judge of the municipal court, including any acting or alternate
judge thereof.
MUNICIPALITY OR THIS MUNICIPALITY: The city of Okmulgee, Oklahoma.
THIS JUDICIAL DISTRICT: The district court judicial district wherein the
government of this municipality is located. (Ord. 1397 § 4, 1981)
2.80.030: JURISDICTION:
The municipal court shall have original jurisdiction to hear and determine all
prosecutions wherein a violation of any ordinance or charter provision of the
municipality is charged. (Ord. 1397 § 5, 1981)
2.80.040: JUDGES:
   A.   The judge of the court will have the qualifications set forth in
section 34 of the charter of the city of Okmulgee, and shall be appointed and
serve as therein provided.
   B.   In the event of disqualification of the judge in a particular case, or
in his absence or inability to act, the city manager may appoint some person,
duly licensed to practice in the state of Oklahoma, as acting municipal judge
of the court in place of the judge during his absence or inability to act or in
a case wherein the judge is disqualified. (Ord. 1397 § 6, 1981)
2.80.050: PROHIBITION ON CHANGE OF VENUE:
No change of venue shall be allowed from the municipal court, but the judge may
be disqualified under the same terms and conditions as are now provided by law
for courts of record. (Ord. 1397 § 7, 1981)
2.80.060: CITY ATTORNEY AS PROSECUTING OFFICER:
The city attorney shall be the prosecuting officer of the court. He shall have
full power to prosecute for the violation of any ordinance or charter provision
of the municipality, and shall have the power to prosecute and resist appeals
and proceedings in error and review from the court. (Ord. 1397 § 8, 1981)
2.80.070: COURT CLERK; DUTIES:
The city clerk, or a deputy designated by him, shall be ex officio clerk of the
court. The clerk shall:
      1.   Assist the judge in recording the proceedings of the court,
preparation of writs, processes, or other papers;
      2.   Administer oaths required in judicial or other proceedings before
the court;
      3.   Be responsible for the entry of all pleadings, processes, and
proceedings in the docket of the court;
      4.   Perform such other clerical duties in relation to the proceedings of
the court as the judge shall direct; and
      5.   Receive and give receipt for and disburse or deliver to the
municipal treasurer all fines, forfeitures, fees, deposits, and sums of money
properly payable to the court. Such funds and sums of money while in the
custody of the clerk shall be deposited and disbursed upon vouchers. (Ord. 1397
§ 9, 1981)
2.80.080: COURT MARSHAL; DUTIES:
The city council, upon the recommendation of the judge, may designate any
appropriate person who is a resident of the city to serve as marshal, and in
absence of such a designation, the chief of police shall be ex officio marshal
of the court. The marshal shall execute any writs and other process directed to
him, except as herein otherwise provided, and such duty may be performed by any
deputy marshal or by any member of the police force of the city, as the case
may be. (Ord. 1397 § 10, 1981)
2.80.090: BOND OF CLERK:
The clerk of the court shall give bond to the city council. The bond shall be
approved by the city council and shall be in an amount to be fixed by the city
council. The bond shall be in substance as follows:
I,                          , clerk of the Municipal Court of Okmulgee, State
of Oklahoma, and               , and              , his sureties, do jointly
and severally agree to pay on demand each and every person who may be entitled
thereto, all such sums of money as said clerk may become liable to pay, on
account of any moneys which may come into his hands, by virtue of his office.
 
Dated at               , this          day of           , 20     .
         
      (Signed)
(Ord. 1397 § 11, 1981)
2.80.100: FEES, FINES AND FORFEITURES; DISPOSITION:
All of the fines, fees and forfeitures which come into the municipal court
shall be paid by the clerk of the court to the municipal treasurer at least
twice each month. The treasurer shall credit such deposits to the fund
designated by the city council. The clerk shall make duplicate receipts for the
fees, fines and forfeitures collected by him, one of which shall be retained by
the treasurer together with a detailed statement of the items of all costs, the
style of the case in which they were paid, and the name of the party paying the
same. (Ord. 1397 § 12, 1981)
2.80.110: PROCEDURE; JUDICIAL NOTICE OF STATUTES AND ORDINANCES; WRITS AND
PROCESS:
The code of procedure in the court, except as may otherwise be provided herein,
shall be the same as is now provided by law for the trial of misdemeanors. The
court shall take judicial notice of state statutes and of ordinances and
charter provisions of the city. Writs and processes of the court may be issued
by the judge or clerk thereof to any proper officer. All writs and process of
the court shall be directed to the marshal or the chief of police or to some
other appropriate peace officer. A law enforcement officer of the municipality
issuing an arrest warrant may serve such warrant any place in the county. (Ord.
1446 § 1, 1982: Ord. 1397 § 13, 1981)
2.80.120: RULES FOR CONDUCT OF COURT BUSINESS:
The judge may prescribe rules, consistent with the provisions of this chapter,
for the proper conduct of the business of the court. (Ord. 1397 § 14, 1981)
2.80.130: PROSECUTIONS BY VERIFIED COMPLAINT; STYLE:
All prosecutions commenced in the municipal court shall be by complaint which
shall be verified before a judge, the court clerk, a deputy court clerk, or a
police officer. However, no warrant for arrest shall be issued until the
complaint has been approved by the city attorney or judge. All prosecutions for
the violation of municipal ordinances shall be styled:
The City of Okmulgee vs            (naming the person or persons charged)
(Ord. 1397 § 15, 1981)
2.80.135: PROSECUTIONS BY VERIFIED COMPLAINT; MEANS OF VERIFICATION:
Notwithstanding other provisions of law, when a law enforcement officer issues
a citation or ticket as the basis for a complaint or information, for an
offense against a municipal ordinance which is hereby declared to be a
misdemeanor, the citation or ticket shall be properly verified if:
   A.   The issuing officer subscribes the officer's signature on the citation,
ticket or complaint to the following statement:
      I, the undersigned issuing officer, hereby certify and swear that I have
read the foregoing information and know the facts and contents thereof and that
the facts supporting the criminal charge stated therein are true.
Such a subscription by an issuing officer, in all respects, shall constitute a
sworn statement, as if sworn to upon an oath administered by an official
authorized by law to administer oaths; and
   B.   The citation or ticket states the specific facts supporting the
criminal charge and the ordinance or statute alleged to be violated; or
   C.   A complainant verifies by oath, subscribed on the citation, ticket or
complaint, that he has read the information, knows the facts and contents
thereof and that the facts supporting the criminal charge stated therein are
true. For purposes of such an oath and subscription, any law enforcement
officer of the state, county or municipality of the state of Oklahoma issuing
the citation, ticket or complaint shall be authorized to administer the oath to
the complainant. (Ord. 1731 § 1, 1998)
2.80.140: ARRAIGNMENT; FINES IN LIEU OF APPEARANCE:
The arraignment shall be made by the court. The judge or city attorney shall
read the complaint to the defendant, inform him of his legal rights and of the
consequences of conviction, and ask him whether he pleads guilty or not guilty.
However, if the offense is one against the traffic ordinances of the city and
an accident resulted, the court shall not accept a plea of guilty. The city
council may prescribe a schedule of fines which the defendant may pay in lieu
of his appearance before the court and such payment shall constitute a final
determination of the cause against the defendant. (Ord. 1397 § 16, 1981)
2.80.150: ARREST; RELEASE BY SIGNING CITATION; BAIL AMOUNT AND CONDITIONS;
TEMPORARY CASH BOND:
   A.   Whenever a resident of the city is arrested for the violation of any
ordinance or charter provision, traffic or nontraffic, by a law enforcement
officer, the officer shall immediately release such person if he acknowledges
receipt of a citation by signing it unless it reasonably appears to the officer
that the person may cause injury to himself or others or damage property if
released or that the person will not appear in response to the citation. If
such person fails to appear in response to the citation a warrant shall be
issued for his arrest and his appearance shall be compelled.
   B.   Whenever a resident of the city is arrested by a law enforcement
officer for the violation of any ordinance or charter provision and is not
released by being permitted to sign the citation as provided in subsection A of
this section, he shall be admitted to bail either before or after arraignment,
or released on his own recognizance.
   C.   Whenever a nonresident of the city is arrested for a violation, other
than a traffic violation, by a law enforcement officer, the defendant shall be
eligible to be admitted to bail either before or after arraignment.
   D.   The city may require a person who is arrested for a municipal traffic
violation by a law enforcement officer to comply with the procedures provided
by law in 22 Oklahoma Statutes section 1114.1 for state traffic violations with
respect to the release of the arrested person and the methods of posting bail
shall apply:
      1.   Posting cash bail;
      2.   Depositing with the arresting officer a "guaranteed arrest bond
certificate"; or
      3.   Depositing with the arresting officer a valid license to operate a
motor vehicle which shall be recognized as an operator's license and shall
authorize the person's operation of a motor vehicle to the date of his hearing
but not to exceed twenty (20) days.
   E.   The amount and conditions of bail granted under subsections B and C of
this section shall be determined by the judge who shall prescribe rules for the
receipt of bail and for the release by recognizance. In the event of arrests at
night, or other emergency, or when the judge is not available, the chief of
police or his designated representative, and the city attorney, shall be
authorized by the judge under such conditions as shall be prescribed by the
judge to accept a temporary cash bond in a sufficient amount to secure the
appearance of the accused, but in no event shall the cash bond be more than the
maximum fine provided by ordinance for each offense charged. The chief of
police or his designated representative, and the city attorney are authorized
subject to such conditions as shall be prescribed by the judge to release a
resident of the city on his own recognizance. (Ord. 1397 § 17, 1981)
2.80.160: FAILURE TO APPEAR ACCORDING TO TERMS OF BOND; FORFEITURE:
If, without sufficient excuse, a defendant fails to appear according to the
terms and conditions of his bond, either for hearing, arraignment, trial or
judgment, or upon any other occasion when his presence in court or before the
magistrate may be lawfully required, the judge may direct that fact to be
entered upon the court minutes, thereby declaring the bond to be forfeited.
Without advancing court costs, the judge shall then cause the forfeiture to be
certified to the Okmulgee County district court, where it shall be entered upon
the district court judgment docket and shall have the same full force and
effect of a district court judgment. At such time as the forfeiture is entered
upon the district court judgment docket, the district court clerk shall proceed
in accordance with the provisions of 59 Oklahoma Statutes sections 1330 through
1333 and 1335. A surety shall have all remedies available under the provisions
of 22 Oklahoma Statutes section 1108 and 59 Oklahoma Statutes sections 1301
through 1340. Court costs shall be collectible from the proceeds of the bond.
If the city requires a person who is arrested for a city traffic violation by a
law enforcement officer to comply with the procedures provided in 22 Oklahoma
Statutes section 1114.1, then in the event, without sufficient excuse, a
defendant fails to appear, either for hearing, arraignment, trial or judgment
or upon any other occasion when his presence in court or before the magistrate
may be lawfully required, the judge may direct that fact to be entered upon the
court minutes, and direct the clerk to proceed as provided by 22 Oklahoma
Statutes sections 1114.4 and 1114.5. (Ord. 1397 § 18, 1981)
2.80.162: FAILURE TO APPEAR:
   A.   Any person, firm or corporation who is charged with a violation(s) of
the city charter, this code or any other ordinance(s) of the city and who,
having been duly issued a summons or having been arraigned and released on
recognizance, or having made a promise to appear for arraignment and/or for
trial, and fails to answer the summons or fails to appear in response to the
summons or violates such recognizance, or fails to honor a promise to appear
for arraignment and/or for trial, and does not voluntarily appear before the
court on the appointed date and time, regardless of the disposition of the
charge(s) for which the citation or complaint(s) was originally issued, shall
be guilty of a misdemeanor.
   B.   Any person, firm or corporation who shall violate the provisions of
this section shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction
thereof shall be punished by a fine of not less than one hundred dollars
($100.00) nor more than two hundred dollars ($200.00) plus fees and costs.
(Ord. 1815 § 1, 2003)
2.80.164: FAILURE TO COMPLY WITH COURT ORDER:
   A.   Any person, firm or corporation who is charged with a violation(s) of
the city charter, this code or any other ordinance(s) of the city and who,
having been duly ordered or directed by the court, whether verbally or in
writing, to pay a fine(s), administrative fee(s), court costs and/or the fees
and mileage of witnesses, if any, and/or any other fees, assessments or costs
imposed by Oklahoma Statutes to be collected by the Okmulgee municipal court,
to perform community service or perform any other lawful act or sentence
imposed by the court, or who has signed an agreement to make scheduled
payments, and who fails or refuses, in whole or in part, to pay a fine(s),
administrative fee(s), court costs and/or the fees and mileage of witnesses, if
any, and/or any other fees, assessments or costs imposed by Oklahoma Statutes
to be collected by the Okmulgee municipal court, on the appointed date(s) or
time(s) or as agreed to or when otherwise due, regardless of the disposition of
the charge(s) for which the citation(s) or complaint(s) was originally issued,
shall be guilty of a misdemeanor.
   B.   Any person, firm or corporation who shall violate the provisions of
this section shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction
thereof shall be punished by a fine of not less than one hundred dollars
($100.00) nor more than two hundred dollars ($200.00) plus fees and costs.
(Ord. 1815 § 2, 2003)
2.80.166: FAILURE TO COMPLY WITH WRITTEN PROMISE TO APPEAR WITH JUVENILE:
   A.   Any person who fails to voluntarily appear before the court with a
juvenile defendant on the appointed date and time, regardless of the
disposition of the charge for which the citation(s) or complaint(s) was
originally issued to the juvenile defendant, after having such juvenile
defendant released to his/her care and control pursuant to a signed promise to
appear with the juvenile, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor.
   B.   Any person who shall violate the provisions of this section shall be
deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof shall be punished by
a fine of not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than two hundred
dollars ($200.00) plus fees and costs. (Ord. 1815 § 3, 2003)
2.80.170: SUSPENSION OF JUDGMENT OR COSTS; RECONFINEMENT:
Whenever any person shall be convicted in the municipal court of violating a
municipal ordinance or charter provision, the judge, after sentence, may
suspend the judgment or costs or both and allow the person so convicted to be
released upon his own recognizance. Any person so released shall be required to
report at such times and to such person or officer as the judge shall direct.
The judge may cause a warrant to issue for any person so released if it shall
be made to appear to the judge that such person:
   A.   Has been guilty of the violation of any law after his release;
   B.   Is habitually associated with lewd or vicious persons; or
   C.   Is indulging in vicious habits.
Upon the issuance of the warrant the person shall be delivered forthwith to the
place of confinement to which he was originally sentenced and shall serve out
the full term for which he was sentenced, or become liable for the full amount
of the fine, or both. (Ord. 1397 § 19, 1981)
2.80.180: SUPERVISION OF JUVENILES ON PAROLE OR PROBATION:
In addition to the duties otherwise provided by law, the judge of each
municipal court, or some other person designated by the city council, shall be
required to supervise all juveniles who are either on parole or serving
probation terms or suspended sentences pronounced and adjudged by the court.
(Ord. 1397 § 20, 1981)
2.80.190: CONTEMPT OF COURT:
The judge of the court shall have power to enforce due obedience to orders,
rules and judgments made by him and may fine or imprison for contempt offered
to the judge while holding his court or to process issued by him in the same
manner and to the same extent as the district courts of Oklahoma. (Ord. 1397 §
21, 1981)
2.80.195: COMMUNITY SERVICE IN LIEU OF FINE OR IN CONJUNCTION WITH
IMPRISONMENT; VIOLATION OF COMMUNITY SERVICE CONDITIONS:
Whenever any person is convicted in municipal court for violation of a
municipal ordinance, the court may order the defendant to a term of community
service or remedial action in lieu of fine or in conjunction with imprisonment.
If the defendant fails to perform the required community service or if the
conditions of community service are violated, the judge may impose a sentence
of imprisonment, not to exceed the maximum sentence allowable for the violation
for which the defendant was convicted. (Ord. 1731 § 2, 1998)
2.80.200: COURT COSTS:
There are hereby established court costs in the amount of thirty dollars
($30.00) to be collected upon a plea of guilty or of no contest for each
prosecution in municipal court. Said fee may be waived by the municipal judge
or city attorney, but only in writing and only in the interests of justice.
Provided that these court costs shall not be collected in any case where the
costs are effectively preempted, in whole or in part, by applicable state law.
(Ord. 1938 § 1, 2009)
2.80.210: PROSECUTION FOR SAME OFFENSE IN ANOTHER COURT PROHIBITED:
When a defendant has been in jeopardy for the same or any lesser included
offense in a municipal court or district court, he shall not be prosecuted in
another court for the same or a lesser included offense. (Ord. 1397 § 23, 1981)
2.80.220: WRITS OF MANDAMUS, PROHIBITION AND CERTIORARI:
The district court of Okmulgee County shall have the same jurisdiction to issue
to the municipal court writs of mandamus, prohibition and certiorari as the
supreme court now has to issue such writs to court of record. (Ord. 1397 § 24,
1981)
2.80.230: APPEALS:
   A.   An appeal may be taken from a final judgment of the municipal court by
the defendant by filing in the Okmulgee County district court, within ten (10)
days from the date of the final judgment, a notice of appeal and by filing a
copy of said notice with the municipal court. In case of appeal, a trial de
novo shall be had.
   B.   Upon conviction, at the request of the defendant or upon notice of
appeal being filed, the judge of the municipal court shall enter an order on
the docket fixing an amount in which bond may be given by the defendant, in
cash or sureties for cash, in an amount of not less than one hundred dollars
($100.00) nor more than twice the amount of such fine. The clerk of the
municipal court shall take bond. Any pledge of sureties must be approved by the
municipal judge.
   C.   Upon appeal being filed the municipal judge shall within ten (10) days
thereafter certify to the clerk of the Okmulgee County district court the
original papers on the case. If the papers have been certified to the Okmulgee
County district court, the prosecuting attorney shall take the necessary steps
to have the papers certified to the district court within twenty (20) days of
the filing of the notice of appeal, and the failure to do so, except for good
cause shown, shall be grounds for dismissal of the charge by the district
court, the cost to be taxed to the municipality. The certificate shall state
whether or not the municipal judge was a licensed attorney in Oklahoma.
   D.   All proceedings necessary to carry the judgment into effect shall be
had in the district court.
   E.   An appeal from the final judgment or order of the district court in an
appeal may be taken to the court of criminal appeals in the same manner and to
the same extent that appeals are taken from original district court actions to
the court of criminal appeals. (Ord. 1872 § 1, 2006: Ord. 1751 § 2, 1999: Ord.
1397 § 25, 1981)
2.80.240: SCHEDULE OF FINES IN LIEU OF APPEARANCE BONDS:
   A.   The defendant may pay, in lieu of his/her appearance before the court,
the established and preset schedule of fines, together with prescribed court
costs unless waived by the court, and the fees, assessments and costs mandated
to be paid by the state of Oklahoma, and such payment of all of the foregoing
shall constitute the final determination of the cause against the defendant.
This schedule is also known as the "bond schedule" and represents the dollar
amount of bond, which is to be posted or paid by a defendant to ensure his/her
attendance in court at trial and may only be waived or modified by the court.
Said preset schedule of fines shall be established by resolution of the city
council, or in the absence of a resolution, by order of the municipal judge.
   B.   Notwithstanding any other provision of this schedule, the fine for all
moving traffic violations occurring in a school zone while school is in session
shall be five hundred dollars ($500.00).
   C.   Notwithstanding any other provision of this schedule, the fine for all
second and subsequent offenses occurring within six (6) months of the date of
the prior offense shall be five hundred dollars ($500.00).
   D.   Notwithstanding any other provision of this schedule, the fine for all
moving violations in a construction zone while workers are present shall be
five hundred dollars ($500.00). (Ord. 1880 § 1, 2006: Ord. 1762 § 1, 2000: Ord.
1720 § 1, 1997: Ord. 1512 § 1, 1984: Ord. 1447 § 1, 1982: Ord. 1397 § 26, 1981)
CHAPTER 2.90
BOARDS AND COMMITTEES
SECTION:
2.90.010: Applicability Of Provisions
2.90.020: Positions Limited
2.90.030: Absenteeism
2.90.040: Term Limitation
2.90.010: APPLICABILITY OF PROVISIONS:
The provisions of this chapter shall apply to all boards, commissions and
committees of the city, regardless of whether same is established by charter,
ordinance or resolution; except that the provisions of this chapter shall not
apply to the city council, which shall be governed exclusively by the
provisions of the city charter. (Ord. 1698 § 2, 1993)
2.90.020: POSITIONS LIMITED:
No person may serve at any time on more than one city board, commission or
committee. (Ord. 1698 § 3, 1993)
2.90.030: ABSENTEEISM:
Should any person serving on a city board, commission or committee be absent
from more than one-half (1/2) of all the meetings of the board, commission or
committee, regular or special, held within any period of four (4) consecutive
calendar months, said person shall thereupon cease to be a member of such
board, commission or committee, and such position shall be deemed vacant. (Ord.
1698 § 4, 1993)
2.90.040: TERM LIMITATION:
No person shall serve more than three (3) consecutive terms on the same board
or committee; providing, that any person serving on a board, commission or
committee of the city, as of the date of passage of the ordinance codified in
this chapter, shall be allowed to serve, if appointed, for an additional three
(3) terms after the expiration of said person's current term. (Ord. 1698 § 5,
1993)

CHAPTER 3.02
REVENUES AND EXPENSES
SECTION:

3.02.020: Dishonored Checks

(Ord. 1832 § 1, 2003)
3.02.020: DISHONORED CHECKS:
Payment which is tendered to the city through the use of a check, other than
the payment of a utility charge as provided in section
13.04.280 of this code, which check is dishonored for any reason, shall be
assessed the face amount of the check plus a returned check charge of twenty
five dollars ($25.00) at the time the check is available for pick up. Returned
checks shall be redeemed by cash, money order, or credit/debit card charge in a
form acceptable to the city, and must be presented in person. (Ord. 1927 § 1,
2008)
CHAPTER 3.04
PURCHASES AND SALES
SECTION:
3.04.010: Contractual Services Defined
3.04.020: Council Approval Of Purchases; When
3.04.022: Claims Payment Procedure
3.04.030: Competitive Bidding; Procedure
3.04.032: Preference For Purchases From Local Vendors
3.04.040: Competitive Bidding; Not Required
3.04.050: Surplus Or Obsolete Sales; Advertisement And Declaration
3.04.060: Surplus Or Obsolete Sales; Competitive Bidding Not Required
3.04.080: Alternate Bids And Proposals
3.04.100: City Manager Authorized To Declare Emergency Situation; Limitations
3.04.010: CONTRACTUAL SERVICES DEFINED:
"Contractual services", for the purposes of this chapter, means services
performed for the city by persons not in the employment of the city, and may
include the use of equipment or the furnishing of commodities in connection
with said services under express or implied contract. Contractual services
shall include travel, freight, express, parcel post, postage, telephone,
telegraph, utilities, rents, printing and binding, repairs, alterations and
maintenance of buildings, equipment, streets and bridges, and other services
performed for the city by persons not in the employment of the city. (Prior
code § 306)
3.04.020: COUNCIL APPROVAL OF PURCHASES; WHEN:
Every contract for or purchase of supplies, materials, equipment and
contractual services for more than thirty five thousand dollars ($35,000.00) by
the city manager shall require the prior approval of the city council; and
under no circumstances may he make such contract or purchase without first
obtaining the prior approval of the city council. (Ord. 2188, 2025: Ord. 1902 §
1, 2007: Ord. 1745 § 1, 1999: Ord. 1687 § 1, 1992: Ord. 1258 § 1, 1975: prior
code § 307)
3.04.022: CLAIMS PAYMENT PROCEDURE:
   A.   The city manager shall be responsible for the review and approval for
payment of claims for all expenditures of the city that are equal to less than
thirty five thousand dollars ($35,000.00). All such claims shall be submitted
monthly to the city council for approval. All claims shall be made on the
city's official form of purchase orders which are properly issued by the city's
purchasing agent who shall certify that the amount claimed is within the
approved budget for the line item account to be charged with payment. All
claims shall be properly completed and signed by the city's purchasing agent
and the department head initiating the purchase or expenditure prior to
approval by the city manager.
   B.   In order to expedite the payment of certain claims, the city manager is
authorized to review and approve claims that are equal to or less than thirty
five thousand dollars ($35,000.00) per month for periodic payments on a
contract that has been previously entered into by the city. Reports shall be
prepared not less than once each month listing all approved payments made for
the preceding month or portion thereof as may be appropriate, copies of each of
which shall be provided to each council member.
   C.   The city manager is further authorized to establish procedure for
payment of claims more often than once a month when and at such times as the
revenues, receipts and income actually received by the city are sufficient for
such purposes.
   D.   All payments on claims shall be made on regular schedules that shall
assure payment of properly submitted claims in a timely manner. The city
manager is authorized to make such exceptions to the payments on claims on
regular schedules as may be necessary to preserve the fiscal integrity of the
city.
   E.   In order to lessen the burdens of government, it is declared to be the
policy of the city, within the bounds of the law, to attempt to take advantage
of such early or prompt payment discounts and quantity purchase discounts as
may be practical when revenues, receipts and income actually received by the
city are sufficient for such purposes and which are appropriated within
budgeted line item accounts. To this end, the city manager is authorized and
directed to take advantage of such early or prompt payment discounts and
quantity purchase discounts as may be practical when revenues, receipts and
income actually received by the city are sufficient for such purposes and which
are appropriated within budgeted line item accounts. (Ord. 2218, 2025: Ord.
2035, 2014: Ord. 1902 § 2, 2007: Ord. 1779 § 1, 2001)
3.04.030: COMPETITIVE BIDDING; PROCEDURE:
Before the city manager makes any purchase of or contract for supplies,
materials, equipment and contractual services except as otherwise provided
below, he/she shall submit to at least three (3) persons, firms or corporations
dealing in, and able to supply, the same, or to a smaller number if there are
not three (3) dealing in and able to supply the same, a request for quotation
on what he/she proposes to purchase with specifications or invitation to bid,
to give them opportunity to bid, and/or publish notice of the proposed purchase
in a newspaper of general circulation within the city. All bids shall be sealed
and shall be opened in public at a designated time and place. He/she may
repeatedly reject all bids and submit a request or invitation to bid again to
the same or other persons, firms or corporations. He/she shall purchase from
the bidder whose bid is most advantageous to the city, considering price,
quality, suitability, availability, adaptability, date of delivery, past
performance, time available or required for performance, history and
acceptability of surety or bonding company, financial ability to perform,
possession of necessary tools and equipment, size of workforce dedicated to
perform work, ability to provide maintenance and service, preference for local
vendor, safety, warranties, terms and conditions, conformity with bid
specifications, number and scope of conditions attached, if any, etc.; and, if
necessary, shall cast lots in case of a tie to determine from whom to make a
purchase. The city reserves the right to require prospective bidders to
prequalify as responsible bidders prior to submitting bids. (Ord. 1836 § 1,
2003: Ord. 1745 § 1, 1999: prior code § 308)
3.04.032: PREFERENCE FOR PURCHASES FROM LOCAL VENDORS:
   A.   Policy Statement: The city is encouraged to make purchases from
businesses, industries and enterprises located and operated within the
territorial limits of Okmulgee County, Oklahoma, including especially those
located and operated within the territorial limits of the city of Okmulgee,
Oklahoma, whenever it is most advantageous to the city to do so.
   B.   Definitions: When used in this chapter, the following words and terms
shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section:
      ADVANTAGEOUS: Is defined in section
3.04.030  of this chapter.
      LOCAL VENDOR: Any person, firm, corporation, business, industry or
enterprise whose place of business is located and operated within the
territorial limits of Okmulgee County, Oklahoma.
      PUBLIC CONSTRUCTION CONTRACT: Any contract which exceeds thirty five
thousand dollars ($35,000.00) in amount awarded by the city for the purpose of
making any public improvement or constructing any public building or making
repairs to or performing maintenance to the same except as may be otherwise
provided by state law.
      PUBLIC IMPROVEMENT: Any beneficial or valuable change or addition,
betterment, enhancement or amelioration of or upon any real property, or
interest therein, belonging to the city, intended to enhance its value, beauty,
or utility or to adapt it to new or further purposes. This term does not
include the direct purchase of materials, equipment or supplies or any personal
property to be used within the project.
   C.   Public Construction Contracts: In competitive bidding situations
involving public construction contracts, the city shall award contracts to the
lowest responsible bidder whose bid is most advantageous to the city. For
purposes of this subsection, the term "lowest responsible bidder" shall include
a local vendor(s) who submitted the lowest responsible bid(s) and whose bid(s)
is within five percent (5%) of the bid of the lowest responsible bidder who is
not a local vendor on such contracts which exceed thirty five thousand dollars
($35,000.00).
   D.   Contracts Other Than Public Construction Contracts: For purchases not
involving public construction contracts, the city may give preference to
purchases from a local vendor(s) who submitted the lowest responsible bid(s) or
quote(s) which are determined to be most advantageous to the city when the
total cost of ownership is considered.
      1.   Ten percent (10%) of the bid or quote most advantageous to the city
of the lowest responsible bidder who is not a local vendor, on such contracts
of less than or equal to thirty five thousand dollars ($35,000.00); and
      2.   Five percent (5%) of the bid or quote most advantageous to the city
of the lowest responsible bidder who is not a local vendor, on such contracts
which exceed thirty five thousand dollars ($35,000.00). (Ord. 2218, 2025: Ord.
2007, 2013: Ord. 1836 § 2, 2003)
3.04.040: COMPETITIVE BIDDING; NOT REQUIRED:
The city manager may purchase the following without giving an opportunity for
competitive bidding:
   A.   Supplies, materials, equipment and contractual services the cost of
which does not exceed thirty five thousand dollars ($35,000.00) in a single
transaction;
   B.   Supplies, materials, equipment and contractual services which can be
furnished only by a single dealer, or which has a uniform minimum price
wherever bought;
   C.   Supplies, materials, equipment or contractual services purchased from
another unit of government at a price deemed below that obtainable from private
dealers, including government surplus;
   D.   Contractual services (natural gas, electricity, telephone service and
the like) purchased from a public utility at a price or rate determined by the
state corporation commission or other government authority;
   E.   Supplies, materials, equipment or contractual services when purchased
at a price not exceeding a price set therefor by the state purchasing agency or
any other state agency authorized to regulate prices for things purchased by
the state (whether such price is determined by a contract negotiated with a
vendor or otherwise);
   F.   Contractual services of a professional nature, such as engineering,
architectural, legal, accounting, and medical services or situations, when it
is determined that a request for proposals is appropriate, subject to the
public competitive bidding act of 1974, as amended;
   G.   Supplies, materials and equipment at a court sanctioned or governmental
sponsored or related public auction or sale when it is deemed that the goods
can be obtained at a price below that obtainable through competitive bidding.
(Ord. 2218, 2025: Ord. 1902 § 3, 2007: Ord. 1745 § 1, 1999: Ord. 1687 § 2,
1992: Ord. 1595 § 1, 1987: Ord. 1492 § 2, 1983: prior code § 309)
3.04.050: SURPLUS OR OBSOLETE SALES; ADVERTISEMENT AND DECLARATION:
No surplus or obsolete supplies, materials or equipment of a value of more than
two thousand dollars ($2,000.00) may be sold until the council has declared
them surplus or obsolete. Before the city manager sells any surplus or obsolete
supplies, materials or equipment, except as otherwise provided, he shall
advertise them for sale in a newspaper of general circulation in the city or in
such other manner as he deems necessary to adequately reach prospective buyers
to give them an opportunity to make bids. All bids shall be sealed and shall be
opened in public at a designated time and place, except when the sale is by
auction. The city manager may repeatedly reject all bids and advertise again.
He shall sell such supplies, materials or equipment to the highest responsible
bidder, and, if necessary, shall cast lots in case of a tie to determine to
whom to sell. (Ord. 1902 § 4, 2007: prior code § 310)
3.04.060: SURPLUS OR OBSOLETE SALES; COMPETITIVE BIDDING NOT REQUIRED:
The city manager may sell surplus or obsolete supplies, materials or equipment
the total value of which does not exceed two thousand dollars ($2,000.00) in a
single transaction, without giving an opportunity for competitive bidding.
(Ord. 1902 § 5, 2007: prior code § 311)
3.04.080: ALTERNATE BIDS AND PROPOSALS:
   A.   On all contracts and purchases required to be competitively bid, or
concerning which the city is seeking multiple proposals, the city may include
in its evaluation the following as a single bid for competitive bidding
purposes:
      1.   The state bid price on any item, solicited and published by Oklahoma
department of central services;
      2.   The bid price on any item actually solicited and published by any
state or national organization, alliance or pool of governmental agencies who
have joined together as a purchasing or solicitation group for the express
purpose of making governmental purchases; or
      3.   The low bid price on any item published by a bona fide, data
assembly organization, whose function is to assemble published data on state or
national governmental purchases; provided that a "bona fide, data assembly
organization" shall not include the industry councils of specific trades or
industrial categories.
   B.   When it is in the best interest of the city to do so, the requirement
to purchase by competitive bids may be satisfied by purchasing through one of
the agencies described in subsection A of this section without necessity of the
city conducting its own formal bidding process. (Ord. 2060, 2015)
3.04.100: CITY MANAGER AUTHORIZED TO DECLARE EMERGENCY SITUATION; LIMITATIONS:
Pursuant to the provisions of the Public Competitive Bidding Act of 1974, as
amended, 61 Oklahoma Statutes Section 130, in connection with "public
construction contracts" as that term is defined in Section 102 of said Act,
there is hereby delegated to the city manager, the authority to declare an
emergency situation which shall be limited to the conditions resulting from a
sudden unexpected happening or unforeseen occurrence or condition and situation
wherein the public health or safety is endangered, in which event the provision
of the said Public Competitive Bidding Act with reference to notice and bids
shall not apply, but such authority shall not extend to any contract exceeding
thirty-five thousand dollars ($35,000.00). (Ord. 2218, 2025: Ord. 1745 § 3,
1999)
CHAPTER 3.08
DEPOSIT OF FUNDS
SECTION:

3.08.010: AUTHORIZED DEPOSITORIES DESIGNATED:
The funds of the city shall be deposited or invested in an institution or
institutions that qualify as authorized investments of public funds under state
law, and: a) which are situated within the corporate limits of the city, or b)
which are affiliated under investment contracts, or deposit placement
agreements, or similar business alliances with institutions within the
corporate limits of the city. The funds received by the city shall be deposited
daily. (Ord. 1900 § 1, 2007: Ord. 1484 § 1, 1983: prior code § 311.1)
3.08.020: INSURANCE OR SECURITY:
The bank deposits of the city shall be protected and secured by the federal
deposit insurance corporation and its successors and/or protected and secured
under the security for local public deposits act, 62 Oklahoma Statutes, 1991,
section 517.1 and following. (Ord. 1768 § 1, 2000: Ord. 1530 § 1, 1984: Ord.
1484 § 2, 1983: prior code § 311.2)
3.08.030: WITHDRAWALS; AUTHORIZATION:
All withdrawals of the city's funds from the depositories shall be by order
issued as provided by state law, and only for authorized purposes and by proper
authority. (Prior code § 311.3)
3.08.040: COMMUNITY IMPROVEMENT CAPITAL FUND:
The city of Okmulgee is in the process of selling block 139 original town of
Okmulgee, Okmulgee County, Oklahoma, to the Muscogee (Creek) Nation. This
property was originally acquired through the sale of general obligation bonds
which had been voted by the citizens of the city of Okmulgee. This is based
upon the Oklahoma constitution, article X section 19 states in part:
...every ordinance and resolution passed by any ...city ...levying a tax shall
specify distinctly the purpose for which said tax is levied, and no tax levied
and collected for one purpose shall ever be devoted to another purpose.
(Emphasis added.)
As such, the proceeds of the sale of the real estate are legally bound to be
used for a substantially similar purpose in light of the current and future
needs of the city of Okmulgee. It is clear that this legal requirement and
limitation on the use of the proceeds makes it necessary to establish a capital
account for the preservation of the principal and income generated by this
money. At the present time, the appropriate use has not been determined, but it
is clear that the money must be used to acquire, preserve, repair and maintain
a significant public benefit to the community generally, and may not be used
for ordinary administration and operation. Until such time as the city council
has determined an appropriate use for this money, the money shall be deposited
in an account dedicated exclusively to hold these proceeds, and then invested
in a reasonable and prudent manner with the income similarly placed in the same
account and subjected to the same restrictions. (Ord. 1962, 2010)
CHAPTER 3.12
SALES TAX
