5.04.010: DEFINITIONS:
   A.   The definitions of terms used herein are the same as those set forth in
Oklahoma Statutes title 37A as adopted as of the date of this section and as
may be amended through the Legislature or interpreted through the courts.
   B.   As used in this chapter, "State license" shall mean the license, or
person or entity holding a license, issued under the terms of Oklahoma
Statutes, title 37A.
   C.   Words in the plural include the singular, and vice versa, and words
imparting the masculine gender include the feminine, and any reference to
Oklahoma Statutes title 37 contained within this Code shall hereby refer to
Oklahoma Statutes title 37A.
   D.   Alcohol as used in this chapter includes all alcoholic beverages except
alcohol produced for use as a motor fuel under permit of the State of Oklahoma.
(Ord. 2117, 2018)

5.04.030: PAYMENT; PENALTY; ANNUAL REPORT:
   A.   Any State licensee originally entering upon any occupation listed in
section
5.04.020 of this chapter shall pay the tax therefor at the Office of the City
Clerk on or before the date upon which he enters upon such occupation. Such
licensee shall provide a copy of his current State license before payment of an
Occupation Tax will be accepted. Thereafter, the licensee shall pay the tax
annually on or before July 1.
   B.   For the initial issuance of a license required under this section
issued on or after January 1 of the license year, the Occupation Tax subject to
this section shall be one-half (1/2) of the amount listed in section
5.04.020 of this chapter.
   C.   Any person who engages in any of the occupations taxed by this chapter
without paying such Occupation Tax imposed therefor in advance of such
operation is guilty of an offense against the City. Each day of such violation
shall constitute a separate offense.
   D.   The City Clerk shall make an annual report to the Alcoholic Beverage
Laws Enforcement (ABLE) Commission covering the fiscal year, showing the number
and class of licensees subject to the Occupational Tax and the amount of money
collected from such tax. (Ord. 2117, 2018: Ord. 1931 § 2, 2009)
5.04.040: TAX RECEIPT DISPLAY:
Any State licensee shall post his tax receipt in a conspicuous place in the
premises wherein he carries on his occupation. (Ord. 1931 § 2, 2009)
5.04.050: FAILURE TO PAY TAX; COURT ACTION:
All sums due from any person by reason of Occupation Taxes imposed by this
chapter and all penalties accruing from such person by reason of failure to pay
such tax shall be recoverable at the suit of the City brought against such
person in any court of competent jurisdiction. In any such suit, in addition to
the tax and penalties, the plaintiff shall recover interest, at the rate of ten
percent (10%) per year upon all sums due by way of tax and penalty from the
date of accrual thereof, and all costs of collection, judicial or otherwise,
including reasonable attorney fees, which shall be paid to the attorney,
representing the plaintiff in the suit, all to be determined by the court.
Prosecution for an offense against the City arising out of the failure to pay a
tax levied by this chapter, regardless of the outcome thereof or of its
continued pendency, shall not constitute a defense or a bar in any manner to
the collection of the tax and penalties, if any are due, as provided in this
chapter. (Ord. 1931 § 2, 2009)
5.04.060: CERTIFICATE OF COMPLIANCE; APPLICATION; FEE; INSPECTION; ISSUANCE:
   A.   Every applicant for a certificate of compliance with the Zoning, Fire,
Health and Safety Codes of the City required by 37 Oklahoma Statutes shall
apply at the Office of the City Clerk by:
      1.   Filing a written application on forms prescribed by that office; and
      2.   Paying to the City Clerk a verification and certification fee in the
amount of one hundred dollars ($100.00) at the time of filing the application.
   B.   Upon receipt of an application for a certificate of compliance and the
verification and certification fee, the City Clerk shall cause an investigation
to be made to determine whether the premises proposed for licensed operations
comply with the provisions of the zoning ordinances and any Health, Fire,
Building and other Safety Codes applicable to it.
   C.   The City Clerk shall act on all such applications within twenty (20)
days of receipt thereof.
   D.   Upon finding that the premises of an applicant for a certificate is in
compliance with all applicable zoning ordinances, a certificate of compliance
shall be issued to the ABLE Commission.
   E.   Upon finding that the premises for a certificate is in compliance with
all applicable Fire, Safety and Health Codes, a certificate of compliance shall
be issued to the ABLE Commission.
   F.   Certificate of compliance shall be signed by the City Clerk. (Ord. 1931
§ 2, 2009)
5.04.070: PENALTY:
Any person who engages in any business, profession, trade, or occupation, or
exercises any privilege, for which a license is required by this chapter,
without a valid license as thereby required, or who shall violate any provision
of this chapter, shall be guilty of an offense and, upon conviction, shall be
fined as provided in section
1.12.010 of this Code. Violation of this chapter shall also be grounds for
revocation or suspension of license granted. (Ord. 1931 § 2, 2009)
5.04.080: SALE, DISTRIBUTION OR CONSUMPTION ON CITY PROPERTY:
   A.   Subject to the requirements of this chapter, any person or legal entity
holding a valid lease or permit to use City property and otherwise in
compliance with 37 Oklahoma Statutes section 511E, may allow the sale or
dispensing of alcoholic beverages at a festival or event conducted on the
premises so long as the following criteria are met in the operation of the
festival or event:
      1.   All such sale or distribution of such beverages must be contained
within the confines of the building or within a temporary structure such as a
tent.
      2.   Repealed.
      3.   Repealed.
      4.   Individuals who are already intoxicated shall not be served
additional beverages containing alcohol.
      5.   Adequate provisions for the disposal of such drink containers shall
be provided by the holder of the permit or lease.
      6.   Area ingress and egress shall be restricted and controlled by means
of an enclosure consisting of walls, barricades, fences, partitions and/or
ropes so as to prevent the sale, distribution and consumption of low point beer
beyond or outside the confines of such enclosure.
      7.   No person under the age of twenty one (21) years shall be allowed in
the building area or within the tent where such beverages are sold or
distributed or consumed, unless accompanied by a parent or legal guardian.
      8.   The festival or event at which the sale, distribution or consumption
of such beverages occurs shall not exceed three (3) consecutive days' duration.
The applicant must have all County and State licenses prior to obtaining the
City's approval. The applicant's proposed operation and use thereof must comply
with all applicable rules, regulations, codes and ordinances of the City and
applicable Oklahoma law, including, but not limited to, food service
requirements as required by the City, Okmulgee County and the State of
Oklahoma. For any event lasting longer than three (3) hours, at least one
person who has been trained in responsible beverage sales and service by OSUIT
or an equivalent program must be on duty at all times that said beverages are
being sold, dispensed, or consumed.
      9.   The person or legal entity holding the permit or lease shall have a
manager on site whose responsibility it is to enforce the above criteria at all
times that such beverages are being sold, distributed or consumed.
   B.   An applicant seeking to sell or distribute such beverages shall include
such information written in its application for permit or lease of City
property. The applicant shall include a detailed map/drawing with its completed
application to include the following: identification of enclosure size with
dimensions; location of each proposed entrance and exit; the physical location
of the structure on the premises on which the license is to be issued; and the
physical location of the bar area within the enclosure from which the low point
beer is to be sold and distributed. Such sale or distribution shall only be
allowed if the City Clerk has reviewed and approved the application in a form
which includes such terms within the permit or lease.
   C.   The holder of the permit or lease shall be liable for the following:
      1.   Posting its permit in a prominent public place on the premises where
the stated beverages are sold, distributed or consumed.
      2.   Checking and verifying that no employee, agent or any other person
involved in the service of such beverages is allowed to sell, distribute,
barter or give any low point beer to any person under twenty one (21) years of
age, such verification to be by means of: a) a valid Oklahoma driver's license
or other valid photo identification issued by a governmental entity or within
the United States which contains proof of age or a valid passport or valid
driver's license containing proof of age and photo identification of another
country printed in the English language; or b) a valid international driver's
license containing proof of age and photo identification printed in the English
language.
   D.   Due to the nature of a special event, the restrictions contained in
section
5.06.090 of this title related to a required glass area and the restrictions of
section
5.06.110 of this title related to keeping doors closed shall not apply to an
enclosure authorized hereunder.
   E.   In addition to license revocation or suspension or any civil or
criminal remedies available for enforcement of this section, violation of any
portion of this section is hereby declared unlawful and a misdemeanor and the
event sponsor, its employees, agents, volunteers and any other person(s)
associated with the event, shall be punished and fined the same as other
violations of this Code. (Ord. 2042, 2014: Ord. 2030, 2014)
CHAPTER 5.06
LOW POINT BEER 1

  chapter 9.20 of this code.
5.06.010: DEFINITIONS:
LOW POINT BEER: Means and includes beverages containing more than one-half of
one percent (0.5%) alcohol by volume, and not more than 3.2 percent alcohol by
weight including, but not limited to, beer or cereal malt beverages obtained by
the alcoholic fermentation of an infusion of barley or other grain, malt or
similar products.
MEALS: Foods commonly ordered at lunch or dinner and at least part of which is
cooked on the licensed premises and requires the use of dining implements for
consumption. Provided, that the service of only food such as appetizers,
sandwiches, salads or desserts shall not be considered "meals".
MOTION PICTURE THEATER: A place where motion pictures are exhibited and to
which the general public is admitted, but does not include a place where
"meals", as defined by this section, are served, if only persons twenty one
(21) years of age or older are admitted.
PERSON: Means and includes an individual, a trust or estate, a partnership, an
association or a corporation.
RETAIL DEALER: Means and includes any person who sells any "low point beer", as
defined herein, at retail for consumption or use, and such definition includes
state and county fair associations, and special licenses may be issued for the
sale of "low point beer" as herein defined, by such associations, and to other
persons for the sale of such low point beer at rodeos, picnics, or other
organized temporary assemblages of people. The term "retail dealer" also
includes railways for the sale of such beverages, and licenses may be issued
for each dining car or railway train, which railways and dining cars shall pay
the same license fees as regular dealers. (Ord. 1931 § 2, 2009)
5.06.020: TWENTY ONE YEARS OF AGE REQUIREMENT:
   A.   It shall be unlawful for any person to sell, barter, or give to any
person under twenty one (21) years of age any low point beer.
   B.   It shall be unlawful for any person who holds a license to sell and
dispense low point beer for consumption on the premises, or any agent, servant,
or employee of the license holder, to permit any person under twenty one (21)
years of age unaccompanied by their parent or legal guardian to be admitted to,
or remain in, a separate or enclosed bar area of the licensed premises which
has as its main purpose the selling or serving of low point beer for
consumption on the premises. The provisions of this section shall not prohibit
persons under twenty one (21) years of age from being admitted to an area which
has as its main purpose some objective other than the sale or serving of low
point beer, in which sales or serving of the beverages are incidental to the
main purpose, as long as persons under twenty one (21) years of age are not
sold or served low point beer; however, the incidental service of food in the
bar area shall not exempt a licensee, agent, servant, or employee from the
provisions of this section.
   C.   It shall be unlawful for any person who holds a license to sell and
dispense low point beer for consumption on the premises, or any agent, servant
or employee of the license holder to permit any person under twenty one (21)
years of age to consume any low point beer on the licensed premises.
   D.   Any person violating the provisions of subsection A, B, or C of this
section shall upon conviction be guilty of a misdemeanor. (Ord. 1931 § 2, 2009)
5.06.022: CONSUMPTION BY PERSON UNDER AGE TWENTY ONE IN A PUBLIC PLACE:
   A.   No person under twenty one (21) years of age shall consume or possess
with the intent to consume low point beer. It shall be unlawful for any person
under twenty one (21) years of age to purchase or attempt to purchase low point
beer except under supervision of law enforcement officers. Any person violating
any of the provisions of this section shall be guilty, upon conviction, of a
misdemeanor and punished by a fine to be established by a resolution of the
city council or community service not to exceed twenty (20) hours. Provided,
the provisions of this section shall not apply when such persons are under the
direct supervision of their parent or guardian, but in no instance shall this
exception be interpreted to allow such persons to consume such beverages in any
place licensed to dispense low point beer as provided in 37 Oklahoma Statutes
section 163.11.
   B.   If the premises of a holder of a license to sell low point beer
contains a separate or enclosed bar area which has as its main purpose the sale
or serving of low point beer for consumption on the premises, no person under
twenty one (21) years of age shall enter, attempt to enter, or remain in the
area. The provisions of this subsection shall not prohibit persons under twenty
one (21) years of age from entering or remaining in an area which has as its
main purpose some objective other than the sale or serving of low point beer,
in which sales or serving of the low point beverages are incidental to the main
purpose, if the persons under twenty one (21) years of age are not sold or
served or do not consume low point beer anywhere on the premises; however, the
incidental service of food in the bar area shall not exempt persons under
twenty one (21) years of age from the provisions of this subsection. Any person
convicted of violating the provisions of this subsection shall be guilty of a
misdemeanor, and punished by a fine as established by resolution of the city
council.
   C.   Except as otherwise provided, an admission charge shall not be
considered in any calculation designed to determine the main purpose of an area
pursuant to subsection B of this section. For purposes of this section, an
"admission charge" shall mean any form of consideration received by an
establishment from a person in order for that person to gain entry into the
establishment or an area thereof.
   D.   The provisions of subsection C of this section shall not apply:
      1.   If only persons eighteen (18) years of age or older are permitted to
enter the licensed premises;
      2.   If the licensed premises are owned or operated by a service
organization or fraternal establishment which is exempt under section 501(c)
(19) or (10) of the internal revenue code; or
      3.   To a public event held in a facility owned or operated by any
agency, political subdivision or public trust of the state. (Ord. 1931 § 2,
2009)
5.06.030: HOURS OF OPERATION; ON PREMISES CONSUMPTION:
It is unlawful and a misdemeanor for any retail dealer of low point beer for
consumption on the premises, except those operating by virtue of a state mixed
beverage, caterer or special events license, to:
   A.   Sell or serve any "low point beer" as defined in this chapter between
the hours of two o'clock (2:00) A.M. and seven o'clock (7:00) A.M. excepting
Saturday nights when such beverages may not be sold, dispensed, served or
consumed on the premises between the hours of two o'clock (2:00) A.M. and
twelve o'clock (12:00) noon Sundays; or
   B.   Be open or to operate in any manner, or to allow any live entertainment
on the premises, or to allow or have in operation upon the premises any coin
operated amusement devices, or to have any customers upon the premises between
the hours of two fifteen o'clock (2:15) A.M. and seven o'clock (7:00) A.M. on
any day. (Ord. 1931 § 2, 2009)
5.06.040: LICENSE; FEES:
   A.   There is levied upon each retail dealer in low point beer consumption
on the premises an annual license fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) per location
where such retail business shall be conducted. There is levied upon each retail
dealer in low point beer for consumption off the premises an annual license fee
of twenty five dollars ($25.00) per location where such retail business shall
be conducted.
   B.   All such license fees shall be paid to the city clerk at the time of
issuance and in the manner prescribed in this chapter. (Ord. 1931 § 2, 2009)
5.06.050: LICENSE; REQUIRED:
If is unlawful and a misdemeanor for any retail dealer, whether permanent or
temporary, at any place within the incorporated limits of the city to sell,
distribute or dispense any low point beer without having first applied for and
having received a municipal license to sell, distribute or dispense low point
beer as required by this chapter. (Ord. 1931 § 2, 2009)
5.06.060: LICENSE; ISSUANCE CONDITIONS; EXPIRATION AND NONTRANSFERABILITY:
   A.   No municipal license to sell, distribute or dispense low point beer
shall be issued to any retail dealer by the city clerk without a satisfactory
showing that the applicant has obtained all state and county permits required
by law, and has in all other respects complied with the laws of Oklahoma
relating to the sale and distribution of low point beer. Nor shall any
municipal license to sell, distribute or dispense low point beer be issued to
any retail dealer in the city for consumption on the premises if the building
and/or structure in which the business is to be conducted does not satisfy all
the specifications set forth in sections
5.06.090 and 5.06.100 of this chapter.
   B.   All municipal licenses levied in this chapter shall expire on June 30
next following issuance. No municipal license shall be transferable to another
retail dealer or location. (Ord. 1931 § 2, 2009)
5.06.070: SALE, DELIVERY OR FURNISHING LOW POINT BEER TO INTOXICATED PERSON:
No holder of a retail license or permit to sell low point beer, or an employee
or agent of a holder of such a license or permit, shall knowingly, wilfully and
wantonly sell, deliver or furnish low point beer to an intoxicated person. Any
person violating the provisions of this section shall be guilty of a
misdemeanor and, upon conviction, shall be punished by a fine of not more than
two hundred dollars ($200.00) plus costs. Such violation shall be additional
grounds for revocation of any license or permit for the sale of low point beer
as provided by law. (Ord. 1931 § 2, 2009)
5.06.080: MINIMUM AGE REQUIREMENT FOR EMPLOYMENT WHERE LOW POINT BEER IS SOLD
OR DISPENSED:
   A.   It shall be unlawful and a misdemeanor for any person under eighteen
(18) years of age to be employed or permitted to work, in any capacity
whatsoever, in a place where low point beer is sold or dispensed for
consumption on the premises.
   B.   It shall be unlawful and a misdemeanor for any person under the age of
majority to be employed or permitted to work, in any capacity whatsoever, in
the separate or enclosed bar area of a place where the main purpose of the area
is the sale or consumption of low point beer. The provisions of this subsection
shall not apply to any area which has as its main purpose some objective other
than the sale or serving of low point beer, in which sales or serving of said
beverages are incidental to the main purpose; however, the incidental service
of food in the bar area shall not exempt a holder of a license to sell low
point beer for consumption on the premises from the provisions of this
subsection.
   C.   A parent, as regards the employment of his or her own child or
children, is excepted from the provisions of this section, provided that such
employment shall in no capacity whatsoever be related to the selling or
dispensing of such beverages.
   D.   The provisions of subsection A of this section shall not apply to any
business or establishment where sales of the beverages do not exceed twenty
five percent (25%) of the gross sales of the business or establishment. (Ord.
1931 § 2, 2009)
5.06.090: GLASS AREA REQUIRED:
   A.   From and after July 10, 1984, no license for a retail dealer in low
point beer (formerly referred to as "nonintoxicating beverages") for
consumption on the premises shall be issued unless the building or structure to
be used or occupied to sell, dispense or otherwise distribute such low point
beer has a clear glassed area of no less than seven (7) square feet located in
close proximity to the main entrance of such building or structure. The exact
design, construction and location of such clear glassed area must be approved
by the chief of police, or his/her designee, bearing in mind that it is the
purpose of such clear glassed area to provide a police officer or other
official, intent on entering the building or structure, with a clear
unobstructed view of the main interior area of the premises from without, from
an area in close proximity to the main entrance. Such clear glassed area shall
be maintained in a clear, unpainted, uncovered and unobstructed condition, so
as to permit clear visibility of the interior of such building or structure
from without the same.
   B.   Provided, that any building or structure from which low point beer
(formerly referred to as "nonintoxicating beverages") is being sold, dispensed
or otherwise distributed for consumption on the premises under a valid license
as of July 10, 1984, and not containing a clear glassed area at least as large
as that required by subsection A of this section, shall not be required to
construct a clear glassed area to comply with subsection A of this section;
provided, further, that if any such existing building or structure is enlarged,
extended or moved to a different location after July 10, 1984, it must be made
to comply with the clear glassed area required by subsection A of this section,
or any license shall be revoked and/or no new license issued until compliance
is achieved. Provided, further, that any building or structure from which low
point beer is being dispensed or otherwise distributed for consumption on the
premises under a valid license as of July 10, 1984, which contains a clear
glassed area exceeding that required by subsection A of this section, and for
which it is desired after July 10, 1984, to reduce the clear glassed area, the
design, construction and location of the reduced area must be first approved by
the chief of police, or his/her designee, and must comply with subsection A of
this section.
   C.   Provided further, that should any building or structure being operated
as a place where low point beer (formerly referred to as "nonintoxicating
beverages") is sold or otherwise dispensed for consumption on the premises,
operating under a valid license as of July 10, 1984, thereafter discontinue the
use of the premises for a continuous period of six (6) months, then, in that
event, no license shall thereafter be issued for operation of such building or
structure unless it is first made to comply with the provisions of subsection A
of this section.
   D.   In addition to license revocation or any civil remedies available for
enforcement of this section, violation of any portion of this section is hereby
declared unlawful and a misdemeanor and owners, operators and all agents of the
owners or operators shall be punished and fined the same as other general
violations of this code. (Ord. 1931 § 2, 2009)
5.06.100: LIGHTING:
All area of a building or structure wherein a retail dealer shall have low
point beer for consumption on the premises for sale or use by the retail
customers shall be lighted with incandescent or fluorescent lights providing a
minimum of eight (8) foot-candles of light at all locations within the area
during all hours that any person is in the premises. All owners and operators
and their agents or employees shall each be guilty of an offense and
misdemeanor for operation in violation hereof in addition to all civil remedies
available. (Ord. 1931 § 2, 2009)
5.06.110: DOOR TO BE CLOSED:
The doors of any building or structure occupied by a retail dealer of low point
beer for consumption on the premises, which front or face upon any public way
shall be kept closed when not being used for actual admission to, or exit from,
the building or structure during the hours of operation set forth in section
5.06.030 of this chapter. (Ord. 1931 § 2, 2009)
5.06.120: INTOXICATED PERSONS PROHIBITED FROM LOITERING:
From and after the passage and approval of this chapter, it is unlawful for any
retail dealer of low point beer within the corporate limits of the city, his/
her agents and employees, to permit, let, suffer or allow any intoxicated
person to loiter in or around his/her place of business. (Ord. 1931 § 2, 2009)
5.06.130: DRINKING IN PUBLIC PROHIBITED:
(Rep. by Ord. 2011, 2013)
5.06.140: LOW POINT BEER SALES PROHIBITED IN MOTION PICTURE THEATERS:
No retail license or permit to sell low point beer shall be issued for any
establishment that functions as a motion picture theater. If an establishment,
which has functioned for some other purpose, has been licensed to sell such
beverages and subsequently is operated as a motion picture theater, the license
or permit shall be revoked. (Ord. 1931 § 2, 2009)
5.06.150: RESTRICTION OF LOW POINT BEER PERMITS NEAR SCHOOLS OR CHURCHES:
It shall be unlawful and a misdemeanor for any place which has received a
permit or which has been licensed to sell low point beer and which has as its
main purpose the selling or serving of low point beer for consumption on the
premises to be located within three hundred feet (300') of any public or
private school or church property primarily and regularly used for worship
services and religious activities. The distance indicated in this section shall
be measured from the nearest property line of such public or private school or
church to the nearest perimeter wall of the premises of any such place which
has received a permit or which has been licensed to sell low point beer. The
provisions of this section shall not apply to places which have received a
permit or which have been licensed to sell low point beer for on premises
consumption prior to July 1, 1999, which was the effective date of 37 Oklahoma
Statutes section 163.27. If any school or church shall be established within
three hundred feet (300') of any place subject to the provisions of this
section after such place has received a permit or been licensed, the provisions
of this section shall not be a deterrent to renewal of such permit or license
if there has not been a lapse of more than sixty (60) days. When any place
subject to the provisions of this section which has a permit or license to sell
low point beer for on premises consumption changes ownership or the operator
thereof is changed, and such change results in the same type of business being
conducted on the premises, the provisions of this section shall not be a
deterrent to the issuance of a license or permit to the new owner or operator
if he or she is otherwise qualified.
If an establishment selling low point beer also is the holder of a mixed
beverage or beer and wine license issued by the Oklahoma alcoholic beverage
laws enforcement commission, the establishment shall be subject to the zoning
provisions of 37 Oklahoma Statutes section 518.3 rather than the provisions of
this section. (Ord. 1931 § 2, 2009)
5.06.160: REVOCATION OF LICENSE FOR VIOLATION:
   A.   The violation by any person of the provisions of section
5.06.020 or 5.06.080 of this chapter or any ordinance pertaining to the sale of
"low point beer", as defined in section
5.06.010 of this chapter, shall be sufficient grounds for revocation by the
judge of the municipal court of any permit held by such person authorizing the
sale of low point beer. The permit shall be revoked if the person is convicted
of a violation of the provisions of section
5.06.020 or 5.06.080 of this chapter after a prior conviction of the provisions
of section
5.06.020 or 5.06.080 of this chapter. No new permit shall be issued to such
person or to a relative of such person for a period of twelve (12) months after
such revocation. The permit shall be revoked if a servant, agent, employee or
representative of the permit holder is convicted of a violation of the
provisions of section
5.06.020 or 5.06.080 of this chapter after that person has been convicted of a
prior violation of the provisions of section
5.06.020 or 5.06.080 of this chapter within the previous twelve (12) months.
   B.   Each holder of a retail license or permit to sell and dispense "low
point beer", as defined in section
5.06.010 of this chapter, shall be held responsible for any violation of
section
5.06.020 or 5.06.080 of this chapter committed by a servant, agent, employee or
representative of the license or permit holder. (Ord. 1931 § 2, 2009)
5.06.170: PROHIBITION OF SALES FOR OFF PREMISES CONSUMPTION DURING CERTAIN
HOURS:
The sale of low point beer for off premises consumption is hereby prohibited
between the hours of two o'clock (2:00) A.M. and six o'clock (6:00) A.M. of the
same day. Any holder of a retail license or permit to sell low point beer, or
an employee or agent of a holder of such a license or permit, who sells low
point beer in violation of the provisions of this section shall be guilty of a
misdemeanor and, upon conviction, shall be punished by a fine to be established
by resolution of the city council. Such violation shall be additional grounds
for revocation of any license or permit for the sale of low point beer, as
provided by law. (Ord. 1931 § 2, 2009)
5.06.180: PENALTY:
Any person who engages in any business, profession, trade, or occupation, or
exercises any privilege, for which a license is required by this chapter,
without a valid license as thereby required, or who shall violate any provision
of this chapter, shall be guilty of an offense and, upon conviction, shall be
fined as provided in section
1.12.010 of this code. Violation of this chapter shall also be grounds for
revocation or suspension of license granted. (Ord. 1931 § 2, 2009)
5.06.190: SPECIAL EVENT LOW POINT BEER LICENSE:
   A.   Subject to the requirements of this chapter, any person or legal entity
holding a valid lease or permit to use city property and otherwise in
compliance with 37 Oklahoma Statutes section 511E, may allow the sale or
dispensing of low point beer at a festival or event conducted on the premises
so long as the following criteria are met in the operation of the festival or
event:
      1.   All such sale or distribution of such beverages must be contained
within the confines of the building or within a temporary structure such as a
tent.
      2.   Repealed.
      3.   Repealed.
      4.   Individuals who are already intoxicated shall not be served
additional beverages containing alcohol.
      5.   Adequate provisions for the disposal of such drink containers shall
be provided by the holder of the permit or lease.
      6.   Area ingress and egress shall be restricted and controlled by means
of an enclosure consisting of walls, barricades, fences, partitions and/or
ropes so as to prevent the sale, distribution and consumption of low point beer
beyond or outside the confines of such enclosure.
      7.   No person under the age of twenty one (21) years shall be allowed in
the building area or within the tent where such beverages are sold or
distributed or consumed, unless accompanied by a parent or legal guardian.
      8.   The festival or event at which the sale, distribution or consumption
of such beverages occurs shall not exceed three (3) consecutive days' duration.
The applicant must have all county and state licenses prior to obtaining the
city's approval. The applicant's proposed operation and use thereof must comply
with all applicable rules, regulations, codes and ordinances of the city and
applicable Oklahoma law, including, but not limited to, food service
requirements as required by the city, Okmulgee County and the state of
Oklahoma. For any event lasting longer than three (3) hours, at least one
person who has been trained in responsible beverage sales and service by OSUIT
or an equivalent program must be on duty at all times that said beverages are
being sold, dispensed, or consumed.
      9.   The person or legal entity holding the permit or lease shall have a
manager on site whose responsibility it is to enforce the above criteria at all
times that such beverages are being sold, distributed or consumed.
   B.   An applicant seeking to sell or distribute such beverages shall include
such information written in its application for permit or lease of city
property. The applicant shall include a detailed map/drawing with its completed
application to include the following: identification of enclosure size with
dimensions; location of each proposed entrance and exit; the physical location
of the structure on the premises on which the license is to be issued; and the
physical location of the bar area within the enclosure from which the low point
beer is to be sold and distributed. Such sale or distribution shall only be
allowed if the city clerk has reviewed and approved the application in a form
which includes such terms within the permit or lease.
   C.   The holder of the permit or lease shall be liable for the following:
      1.   Posting its permit in a prominent public place on the premises where
the stated beverages are sold, distributed or consumed.
      2.   Checking and verifying that no employee, agent or any other person
involved in the service of such beverages is allowed to sell, distribute,
barter or give any low point beer to any person under twenty one (21) years of
age, such verification to be by means of: a) a valid Oklahoma driver's license
or other valid photo identification issued by a governmental entity or within
the United States which contains proof of age or a valid passport or valid
driver's license containing proof of age and photo identification of another
country printed in the English language; or b) a valid international driver's
license containing proof of age and photo identification printed in the English
language.
   D.   Due to the nature of a special event, the restrictions contained in
section
5.06.090 of this chapter related to a required glass area and the restrictions
of section
5.06.110 of this chapter related to keeping doors closed shall not apply to an
enclosure authorized hereunder.
   E.   In addition to license revocation or suspension or any civil or
criminal remedies available for enforcement of this section, violation of any
portion of this section is hereby declared unlawful and a misdemeanor and the
event sponsor, its employees, agents, volunteers and any other person(s)
associated with the event, shall be punished and fined the same as other
violations of this code. (Ord. 2042, 2014: Ord. 2030, 2014)
CHAPTER 5.08
CAFES, RESTAURANTS, CONVENIENCE STORES SERVING FOOD AND ITINERANT FOOD VENDORS
SECTION:
5.08.010: Definitions
5.08.020: License; Required; Application
5.08.030: License; Compliance With Oklahoma State Health Department
5.08.040: License; Fees
5.08.050: Right Of Inspection
5.08.060: License; Revocation And Reinstatement
5.08.070: Compliance With Zoning Provisions
5.08.080: License; Nontransferable And Nonrefundable
5.08.090: Penalty
5.08.010: DEFINITIONS:
CAFE: An establishment in which food or drink is prepared for sale.
CONVENIENCE STORE: An establishment in which a variety of goods is offered for
sale including packaged food, prepared food, drinks, etc.
EMPLOYEE: Any person who handles food or drink during preparation or serving,
or who comes in contact with any eating or cooking utensils, or who is employed
in a room in which food or drink is prepared or served.
ITINERANT FOOD VENDOR: One operating for a temporary period in connection with
a fair, carnival, circus, festival, public exhibition, or similar gathering.
RESTAURANT: A restaurant, coffee shop, cafeteria, short order cafe, tavern,
luncheonette, sandwich stand, soda fountain, and all other eating or drinking
establishments as well as kitchens or other places in which food or drink is
prepared for sale.
UTENSILS: Includes any kitchenware, tableware, glassware, cutlery, utensils,
containers, or other equipment with which food or drink comes in contact during
storage, preparation or serving. (Ord. 1931 § 2, 2008)
5.08.020: LICENSE; REQUIRED; APPLICATION:
It is unlawful for any person who does not possess a current and unrevoked
license from the city of Okmulgee to operate a restaurant in this city. Said
license shall be posted in a conspicuous place. Only persons who comply with
the requirements of this chapter shall be entitled to receive and retain such a
license. Said license is not transferable to another person or location.
Application for a restaurant license shall be made in writing at the Okmulgee
community development department. The city shall cause strict inquiry and
investigation to determine compliance with other city and state requirements
concerning the operation of a restaurant. While application for the license may
be made prior to receiving a restaurant permit from the Oklahoma state health
department, the city license shall not be issued until applicant presents a
restaurant permit from the Oklahoma state health department. (Ord. 1931 § 2,
2008)
5.08.030: LICENSE; COMPLIANCE WITH OKLAHOMA STATE HEALTH DEPARTMENT:
Every person desiring a license to operate a restaurant in this city shall make
application to the Oklahoma state health department for a restaurant permit.
When the applicant has received a permit from the Oklahoma state health
department and provides a copy of the permit to the Okmulgee community
development department, applicant will be issued a city of Okmulgee restaurant
license. (Ord. 1931 § 2, 2008)
5.08.040: LICENSE; FEES:
There is levied upon each restaurant in the city an annual license fee of
twenty dollars ($20.00) per location where such retail business shall be
conducted. (Ord. 1931 § 2, 2008)
5.08.050: RIGHT OF INSPECTION:
The city manager, city building inspector, city code enforcement officer or
their designees shall investigate all restaurants as often as they shall deem
necessary for the adequate supervision thereof and they shall have the right to
enter all such places at any reasonable time for the purpose of making such an
investigation. Acceptance of a license shall constitute expressed consent to
such inspections. (Ord. 1931 § 2, 2008)
5.08.060: LICENSE; REVOCATION AND REINSTATEMENT:
   A.   A license for the operation of a restaurant may be temporarily
suspended by the city upon violation by the holder of any of the terms of this
chapter, or revoked after an opportunity for a hearing by the license review
board on serious or repeated violation.
   B.   Any restaurant the license of which has been suspended may at any time
make application for reinstatement of the license.
   C.   Within one week after the receipt of a satisfactory application,
accompanied by a statement signed by the applicant to the effect that the
violated provision or provisions of this chapter have been conformed with, the
city building inspector or his designee shall make a reinspection, and
thereafter as many additional reinspections as he may deem necessary to assure
himself that the applicant is again complying with the requirements, and, in
case the findings indicate compliance, shall reinstate the license. (Ord. 1931
§ 2, 2008)
5.08.070: COMPLIANCE WITH ZONING PROVISIONS:
No cafe, restaurant, convenience store serving food, itinerant food vendor or
similar business serving food shall be maintained in the city except in an area
zoned for that purpose. Applicants for a license for the operation of a
restaurant are responsible for obtaining the zoning classification for the
purposed property and including same on the application. (Ord. 1931 § 2, 2008)
5.08.080: LICENSE; NONTRANSFERABLE AND NONREFUNDABLE:
The license provided for in this chapter shall not be transferable nor give
authority to more than one person to conduct a business as a cafe, restaurant,
and convenience store serving food or an itinerant food vendor. Further, any
monies expended for a license are nonrefundable. (Ord. 1931 § 2, 2008)
5.08.090: PENALTY:
Any person, firm or corporation who engages in business without a license as
required by this chapter or violates any of the provisions of this chapter
shall be guilty of an offense and, upon conviction, shall be fined as provided
in section
1.12.010 of this code. Violation of this chapter shall also be grounds for
revocation or suspension of any license granted. (Ord. 1931 § 2, 2008)
CHAPTER 5.10
COIN OPERATED DEVICES
SECTION:
5.10.010: Definitions
5.10.020: Tax; Classification And Levy
5.10.030: Tax; Rates
5.10.040: License; Application And Display
5.10.050: Taxable Year Designated
5.10.060: Prohibited Devices Not Legalized
5.10.070: Revenue Placed In General City Fund
5.10.080: Penalty
5.10.010: DEFINITIONS:
The following words and phases, when used in this chapter, have the meanings
respectively given to them in this section:
COIN OPERATED AMUSEMENT DEVICE: Means and includes any and all mechanical
devices which, upon the payment or insertion of a coin, token or similar
object, causes or permits, or is the incentive for, the propelling or moving of
any ball or other gadget or object that produces or creates, or makes possible
the production or creation of, a game of skill, amusement, entertainment or
test of strength.
MUSIC DEVICE: Means and includes any and all mechanical devices which render,
cause to sound, or release music where the same may be heard by one or more
public patrons, and each separate loudspeaker, phonograph, jukebox or outlet
from which such music emits shall each be construed to be a separate "music
device" as herein defined; except in the case where the music emits from more
than one speaker transmitting from the same music producing mechanism, in which
case the several outlets or speakers in each place of business shall be
collectively considered one such music device.
MUSIC DEVICE, COIN OPERATED: Means and includes any such music device which is
operated, motivated, released or played by or upon the payment or insertion of
a coin, token or similar object, whether there is one or more boxes or devices
in the premises, for the reception of such coin, tokens or similar objects;
coin operated radio receiving set in hotel rooms or tourist cabins for the use
and benefit of the guest of such rooms or cabins shall be included in such
definition.
The terms "coin operated music device" and "coin operated amusement device" do
not include coin operated vending machines used exclusively for the purpose of
selling tangible personal property such as cold drinks, tobacco products,
candies, postage stamps, or other merchandise, or services such as pay
telephone booths, parking meters, gas and electric meters, or other
distribution of needful service. (Ord. 1931 § 2, 2009)
5.10.020: TAX; CLASSIFICATION AND LEVY:
Coin operated music and amusement devices within the corporate limits of the
city are classified for the purpose of taxation, and an annual license tax as
set out in section
5.10.030 of this chapter is levied with respect to each such device. (Ord. 1931
§ 2, 2009)
5.10.030: TAX; RATES:
Every person who owns and has available to the public for operation, or who
permits to be operated in or on his business premises, any coin operated music
or amusement device shall pay to the city for such privilege an annual license
tax of twenty dollars ($20.00). (Ord. 1931 § 2, 2009)
5.10.040: LICENSE; APPLICATION AND DISPLAY:
Any person owning a coin operated music device or coin operated amusement
device, or operating the premises where the same is to be operated or exposed
to the public within the city, may apply to the city clerk of the city for a
license for such device, and shall at the same time pay to the city clerk the
annual license tax levied in this chapter. The clerk, upon receipt of such
payment, shall issue a license for the type of device covered by such
application and payment. The license and application provided for in this
chapter shall contain the number of such devices covered by the application and
a description of such devices, the location of the place of business where the
same is to be operated, the name of the person owning said device, and the name
of the person conducting said business. Any number of machines or devices may
be included in one application. The license so issued shall be securely affixed
to the device covered thereby and plainly visible to and readable by the
public, except in cases of a coin operated music device consisting of a
loudspeaker or other outlet, affixed or located above the eye level. The
license may be conspicuously posted in the place of business in lieu of being
attached to such devices. (Ord. 1931 § 2, 2009)
5.10.050: TAXABLE YEAR DESIGNATED:
For the purpose of this chapter, the taxable year shall begin on July 1 and end
on the following June 30; the city clerk shall in each instance issue license
for the remainder of the taxable year upon payment of the tax. (Ord. 1931 § 2,
2009)
5.10.060: PROHIBITED DEVICES NOT LEGALIZED:
Nothing in this chapter shall be construed to legalize any devices that may be
prohibited by any of the statutes of the state; provided, that no license fee
paid to the city clerk under the provisions of this chapter shall be returned
to the applicant or owner, in the event it is later determined that the
operation of such devices is prohibited by the laws of the state. (Ord. 1931 §
2, 2009)
5.10.070: REVENUE PLACED IN GENERAL CITY FUND:
It is provided that the revenue derived herefrom shall be distributed to and
placed in the general fund of the city. (Ord. 1931 § 2, 2009)
5.10.080: PENALTY:
Any person who engages in any business, profession, trade, occupation, or
exercises any privilege, for which a license is required by this chapter,
without a valid license as thereby required, or who shall violate any provision
of this chapter, shall be guilty of an offense and, upon conviction, shall be
fined as provided in section
1.12.010 of this code. Violation of this chapter shall also be grounds for
revocation or suspension of license granted. (Ord. 1931 § 2, 2009)
CHAPTER 5.12
POOL, BILLIARD AND OTHER RECREATION HALLS
SECTION:
5.12.010: Defined
5.12.020: Classified
5.12.030: Class B Premises; Employing Persons Under Twenty One Years Unlawful
5.12.040: Class B Premises; Minors Prohibited
5.12.050: Class A Premises; Persons Under Twenty One Years Allowed
5.12.060: Use Of Coin Operated Devices
5.12.070: Gambling, Disorderly Conduct And Fighting Unlawful
5.12.080: Hours Of Operation
5.12.090: Licensing Board; Fee; License Renewal
5.12.100: License; Revocation
5.12.110: License; Nontransferable
5.12.120: Penalty
5.12.010: DEFINED:
For the purpose of this chapter, a "pool hall, billiard hall and other
recreation halls, including, but not limited to, domino parlors, car race
parlors and other recreation halls or places of entertainment", shall be
defined as any place, person, firm, association or corporation that offers the
use for hire of pool tables, billiard tables, domino tables, car raceways or
slot raceways or other recreational places. (Ord. 1931 § 2, 2009)
5.12.020: CLASSIFIED:
For the purpose of this chapter, pool halls, billiard halls and other
recreation halls including, but not limited to, domino parlors and car race
parlors or other recreation halls or other places of entertainment shall be
classified as follows:
   A.   Class A: Such places of recreation as set out in section
5.12.010 of this chapter in which no alcoholic beverages, including, but not
limited to, beer, malt, or fermented or distilled beverages, containing alcohol
shall be served, offered for sale, stored, maintained, drunk or consumed or
brought within the premises.
   B.   Class B: All such recreation halls or parlors as set forth in section
5.12.010 of this chapter which do not comply with the classifications of a
class A hall, specifically any such place that sells, offers for sale, permits
or allows the consumption of beverages containing alcohol upon the premises.
(Ord. 1931 § 2, 2009)
5.12.030: CLASS B PREMISES; EMPLOYING PERSONS UNDER TWENTY ONE YEARS UNLAWFUL:
It is unlawful for any owner, manager or operator to employ a person under
twenty one (21) years of age to work in a class B pool, billiard or other
recreation hall, including domino parlors, car race parlors and other amusement
parlors. It is also unlawful for any person under twenty one (21) years of age
to work in such class B halls. (Ord. 1931 § 2, 2009)
5.12.040: CLASS B PREMISES; MINORS PROHIBITED:
It is unlawful for any person in charge of a class B pool, billiard or other
recreation hall to permit a minor to resort to or loiter in such halls or to
play pool, billiards or other games therein, unless he is accompanied by a
parent or guardian. It is also unlawful for a minor to resort to or loiter in
such a class B hall or to play pool, billiards or other games therein unless he
is accompanied by a parent or guardian. (Ord. 1931 § 2, 2009)
5.12.050: CLASS A PREMISES; PERSONS UNDER TWENTY ONE YEARS ALLOWED:
It is lawful for persons under twenty one (21) years of age to be employed in,
or to use the facilities of, any class A recreation hall or parlor without
being accompanied by a parent or guardian, provided that if a person under
twenty one (21) years of age is employed in such class A parlor, then, and in
that event, there shall be an adult upon the premises in charge of, or
supervising the operations of, such recreation halls or parlors. (Ord. 1931 §
2, 2009)
5.12.060: USE OF COIN OPERATED DEVICES:
In all such recreation halls or parlors as herein defined, coin operated pool
tables, slot car raceways or domino tables may be used for the purpose of
obtaining materials with which to play pool, billiards or power for slot car
raceways or dominoes. (Ord. 1931 § 2, 2009)
5.12.070: GAMBLING, DISORDERLY CONDUCT AND FIGHTING UNLAWFUL:
It is unlawful for the owner, manager or operator of a pool, billiard or domino
parlor or other recreation hall to permit gambling, betting, operating a
lottery, disorderly conduct, loud or disturbing language, noise, or music,
profane language, or any other violation of the laws of the state of Oklahoma,
or of the ordinances of the city. It is also unlawful for the owner, manager or
operator of such a hall to permit therein fighting, boxing, wrestling, or other
contests of physical strength. (Ord. 1931 § 2, 2009)
5.12.080: HOURS OF OPERATION:
   A.   It is unlawful for the owner, manager, or operator of a class B pool
hall, billiard hall, or other recreation hall, to open, keep open or remain
open between the hours of twelve o'clock (12:00) midnight and seven o'clock (7:
00) A.M. on any weekday, or at any time on Sunday.
   B.   Any class A pool hall, billiard hall, or other recreation hall may be
operated on Sunday after the hour of twelve o'clock (12:00) noon. (Ord. 1931 §
2, 2009)
5.12.090: LICENSING BOARD; FEE; LICENSE RENEWAL:
   A.   There shall be a board of review for licensing of all class A and class
B pool halls, billiard halls, and recreation halls, including domino parlors.
The licensing board shall be the same board and use the same rules and
regulations and procedures as the licensing board for private clubs, licensed
and operating in the city limits.
   B.   After the licensing board has acted upon the application of any person
who desires to apply, and has approved the issuance of any license for said
place as either class A or class B recreation hall, as above defined, upon the
payment of the sum of twenty five dollars ($25.00) by the applicant, the city
clerk shall issue its license, which license shall be valid from July 1 to June
30 of each year.
   C.   All applicants for parts of a year shall pay the same fee as if the
same were for the full year.
   D.   Licenses due or to become due shall be processed by application through
the licensing board of review as above provided, and if a renewal of an old
license is required, then the same shall also be processed through the board of
review; provided, however, licenses currently in good standing shall be honored
until the same shall expire by its own terms, and renewal of any such license
shall then be made through the licensing board as provided in this section.
(Ord. 1931 § 2, 2009)
5.12.100: LICENSE; REVOCATION:
The licensing board of review or the city council, after adequate opportunity
for hearing, may revoke the license for the operation of a pool, billiard or
other recreation hall for any violation as hereinbefore specified or set out,
or may suspend such license for such time as deemed proper under the
circumstances. (Ord. 1931 § 2, 2009)
5.12.110: LICENSE; NONTRANSFERABLE:
No license herein provided for shall be transferred or assigned to any person
other than the licensee, nor shall the licensee permit any person to operate or
manage any pool hall, billiard hall, recreation hall, or domino parlor on any
license other than that license applied for by the operator. (Ord. 1931 § 2,
2009)
5.12.120: PENALTY:
Any person who engages in any business, profession, trade, or occupation, or
exercises any privilege, for which a license is required by this chapter,
without a valid license as thereby required, or who shall violate any provision
of this chapter, shall be guilty of an offense and, upon conviction, shall be
fined as provided in section
1.12.010 of this code. Violation of this chapter shall also be grounds for
revocation or suspension of license granted. (Ord. 1931 § 2, 2009)
CHAPTER 5.14
KENNELS AND PET SHOPS
SECTION:
5.14.010: Defined
5.14.020: Kennel Or Pet Shop License; Fee
5.14.030: Maintenance And Treatment Of Animals
5.14.040: Rabies Vaccination; Requirements And Conditions
5.14.050: Right Of Inspection
5.14.060: Compliance With Zoning Provisions
5.14.070: Nuisances Prohibited; License Revocation
5.14.080: License; Nontransferable And Nonrefundable
5.14.090: Penalty
5.14.010: DEFINED:
The terms "kennel" and "pet shop" include any establishment for the raising,
training, boarding or selling of dogs, cats, birds, mice, rats or other small
animals, or where five (5) of more dogs or cats are harbored or kept. (Ord.
1931 § 2, 2009)
5.14.020: KENNEL OR PET SHOP LICENSE; FEE:
It is unlawful to operate a kennel or pet shop within the city without first
securing a license therefor. The fee for such license shall be thirty dollars
($30.00), and said license shall expire on June 30 of each succeeding year.
(Ord. 1931 § 2, 2009)
5.14.030: MAINTENANCE AND TREATMENT OF ANIMALS:
Every place used as a kennel or pet shop shall be kept in a clean and sanitary
condition, and no refuse or waste material shall be allowed to remain therein
for more than twenty four (24) hours. All such animals shall be humanely
treated, and any animal having any disease shall be properly isolated and
treated. (Ord. 1931 § 2, 2009)
5.14.040: RABIES VACCINATION; REQUIREMENTS AND CONDITIONS:
The owner or operator of any kennel or pet shop shall not be permitted to
vaccinate dogs for rabies (see section
6.08.030 of this code). The keeping of dogs over the age of six (6) months
which have not been vaccinated is prohibited. The owner or operator of kennels
or pet shops shall file with the city clerk, as a condition precedent to
obtaining a license to operate the kennel or pet shop, an affidavit showing the
number of dogs over the age of six (6) months kept or possessed in the pet shop
or kennel, and show that each of the animals has been vaccinated for rabies,
and the time of such vaccination. (Ord. 1931 § 2, 2009)
5.14.050: RIGHT OF INSPECTION:
As a condition precedent to the issuance of any license for the operation of
any kennel or pet shop, the applicant for such license agrees that the utility
officer or any city police officer shall have the right of inspection of the
animals kept in, and the facilities of, the kennel or pet shop. (Ord. 1931 § 2,
2009)
5.14.060: COMPLIANCE WITH ZONING PROVISIONS:
As a part of the public policy of the city, kennels and pet shops for which a
license may be issued are declared to be a business, the location, operation,
and maintenance of which shall conform to and be controlled by the provisions
of title 17 of this code. (Ord. 1931 § 2, 2009)
5.14.070: NUISANCES PROHIBITED; LICENSE REVOCATION:
All kennels and pet shops shall be operated in such a manner with regard to
noise, odors, sanitation, and general condition as to not constitute a
nuisance, under provisions of other ordinances of the city. Any license issued
to operate a kennel or pet shop shall be subject to cancellation upon order of
the chief of police in the event it is determined that the operation being
carried on under such license amounts to and constitutes a nuisance. (Ord. 1931
§ 2, 2009)
5.14.080: LICENSE; NONTRANSFERABLE AND NONREFUNDABLE:
Licenses issued pursuant to the provisions of this chapter shall not be subject
to assignment, and license fees paid hereunder shall not be subject to refund,
in whole or in part, for any reason. (Ord. 1931 § 2, 2009)
5.14.090: PENALTY:
Any person who engages in any business, profession, trade, or occupation, or
exercises any privilege, for which a license is required by this chapter,
without a valid license as thereby required, or who shall violate any provision
of this chapter, shall be guilty of an offense and, upon conviction, shall be
fined as provided in section
1.12.010 of this code. Violation of this chapter shall also be grounds for
revocation or suspension of license granted. (Ord. 1931 § 2, 2009)
CHAPTER 5.18
PAWNBROKERS
SECTION:
5.18.010: Defined
5.18.020: Register Of Business; Required; Contents; Tickets
5.18.030: Register Of Business; Open To Inspection
5.18.040: Receiving Property From Minors
5.18.050: Hours Of Business
5.18.060: Penalty
5.18.010: DEFINED:
"Pawnbroker" means any person, firm or corporation who loans money by receiving
goods in pledge for loans at a rate of interest above that allowed by law, or
who deals in the purchase of personal property on the condition of selling the
same back again at a stipulated price, or who makes a public display at his
place of business of the sign generally used by pawnbrokers to denote their
business, that is, three (3) gilded or yellow balls, is declared to be a
pawnbroker. (Ord. 1931 § 2, 2009)
5.18.020: REGISTER OF BUSINESS; REQUIRED; CONTENTS; TICKETS:
   A.   Every pawnbroker shall keep at his place of business a register in
which he shall enter in writing a minute description of all property taken,
purchased or received by him, including any number that may be in or upon any
article, together with the time and name, and place of residence, giving street
and number if within the city, of the person leaving such property, also the
amount loaned, the interest charged, and the time when the loan falls due,
which register shall be kept clean and legible. He shall make such entry within
one hour after the receipt or purchase of such property.
   B.   Each entry shall be made in ink and shall not in any manner be
obliterated or erased.
   C.   To the person negotiating or leaving such property, he shall give a
plainly written or printed ticket, having upon it a full and perfect copy of
all the entries required by ordinance to be kept in such register, for which
copy no charges shall be made. (Ord. 1931 § 2, 2009)
5.18.030: REGISTER OF BUSINESS; OPEN TO INSPECTION:
The register so kept by the pawnbroker shall at all times be kept open to the
inspection of the chief of police and sheriff of Okmulgee County, or the deputy
of either, any police officer or constable, the city attorney of the city and
the district attorney or his deputy, of Okmulgee County. The pawnbroker shall
upon request show and exhibit to such person or officer for inspection, any
article or articles purchased, taken or received by him. (Ord. 1931 § 2, 2009)
5.18.040: RECEIVING PROPERTY FROM MINORS:
No pawnbroker shall purchase or receive in pledge or on deposit any article or
property of or from a minor or owned by any minor unless he shall first obtain
the consent, in writing, of the custodial parent or guardian of such minor.
(Ord. 1931 § 2, 2009)
5.18.050: HOURS OF BUSINESS:
   A.   No "pawnbroker", as defined in section
5.18.010 of this chapter, and doing business in the city, shall keep open,
purchase, take or receive on deposit from any person or persons any article or
thing of value between the hours of seven o'clock (7:00) P.M. and seven o'clock
(7:00) A.M. of the succeeding day; provided that these places of business may
remain open on Saturdays of each week until ten thirty o'clock (10:30) P.M.,
but on these days no article or other thing of value shall be purchased, taken
or received on deposit after the hour of seven o'clock (7:00) P.M.; provided
that no such establishment shall at any time be open for transaction of any
business on Sunday.
   B.   It is unlawful for any person, persons, firm or corporation to transact
any business as "pawnbroker" in the city except during the hours when such
establishments are permitted to be open as provided in this section. (Ord. 1931
§ 2, 2009)
5.18.060: PENALTY:
Any person who engages in any business, profession, trade, or occupation, or
exercises any privilege, for which a license is required by this chapter,
without a valid license as thereby required, or who shall violate any provision
of this chapter, shall be guilty of an offense and, upon conviction, shall be
fined as provided in section
1.12.010 of this code. Violation of this chapter shall also be grounds for
revocation or suspension of license granted. (Ord. 1931 § 2, 2009)
CHAPTER 5.24
AMBULANCE BUSINESS
SECTION:
5.24.010: License; Required
5.24.020: Defined
5.24.030: License; Fee
5.24.040: Equipment Conformance With Standards
5.24.050: Public Liability Insurance
5.24.060: Personnel Training
5.24.070: Proof Of Standards Conformance
5.24.080: License; Nontransferable
5.24.090: License; Granting
5.24.100: Penalty
5.24.010: LICENSE; REQUIRED:
From and after January 14, 1975, no person, firm or corporation shall engage in
the operation of an ambulance business within the city without first procuring
a license to do so. As a condition precedent to procuring a license to operate
an ambulance service within the city, the following requirements set out in
this chapter shall be complied with. (Ord. 1931 § 2, 2009)
5.24.020: DEFINED:
"Ambulance business", for the purposes of this chapter, is defined as the
operation of vehicles within the city by a person, corporation or entity
holding itself out to the public as providing transportation and facilities for
transporting injured, ill or sick persons, furnishing health preserving
medicines and facilities, and providing such transportation within or without
the city limits. (Ord. 1931 § 2, 2009)
5.24.030: LICENSE; FEE:
An ambulance license fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00) annually shall be
paid to the city, and, subject to other requirements herein made, a license
shall then be issued by the city. (Ord. 1931 § 2, 2009)
5.24.040: EQUIPMENT CONFORMANCE WITH STANDARDS:
Medical and scientific equipment with which each ambulance unit is equipped
shall conform to the minimum suggested standards as provided by the American
College of Surgeons committee on trauma, and as required by the emergency
medical services division of the state department of health. All vehicles shall
also conform to the above standards with the exception that a minimum headroom
of fifty four inches (54") shall be deemed adequate. The community development
department shall require satisfactory proof that the provisions and
requirements of this chapter have been met before issuing a license to the
applicant. (Ord. 1931 § 2, 2009)
5.24.050: PUBLIC LIABILITY INSURANCE:
   A.   No ambulance unit shall be placed in operation until there has been
posted with the city a policy of public liability insurance with limits as
follows:
      1.   Death and/or injury to one person: Two hundred thousand dollars
($200,000.00).
      2.   Deaths and/or injuries arising from one occurrence: Five hundred
thousand dollars ($500,000.00).
      3.   Property damage resulting from one occurrence: One hundred thousand
dollars ($100,000.00).
   B.   The insurance policy shall include a provision providing that the
insurance coverage will not be canceled or otherwise discontinued except and
until notice in writing is given to the city thirty (30) days in advance of the
date of the discontinuance of the insurance coverage. Any and all ambulance
units upon which insurance coverage, as herein required, has been canceled
shall immediately be taken out of operation and not used again until the city
clerk has been furnished a policy of insurance reinsuring all units upon which
insurance had been canceled. The reinsurance policy shall conform to other
requirements set forth in this chapter. (Ord. 1931 § 2, 2009)
5.24.060: PERSONNEL TRAINING:
All personnel engaged in the operation and use of each ambulance shall have
achieved a level of training in the use of medical equipment, adhering to the
suggested standards set forth by the American College of Surgeons committee on
trauma; or shall be actively engaged in such a training program so as to
achieve the suggested level of training within a reasonable time. Personnel
shall also be qualified under all applicable regulations of the emergency
medical services division of the state department of health and the state motor
vehicle code. (Ord. 1931 § 2, 2009)
5.24.070: PROOF OF STANDARDS CONFORMANCE:
The operator shall provide the city with satisfactory proof from the emergency
medical services division of the state department of health, certifying that
vehicles, emergency equipment, personnel training, and methods of operation
conform to suggested standards set forth by the American College of Surgeons
committee on trauma, and the minimum requirements of state regulations. (Ord.
1931 § 2, 2009)
5.24.080: LICENSE; NONTRANSFERABLE:
Licenses granted pursuant to the provisions of this chapter shall be
nontransferable. (Ord. 1931 § 2, 2009)
5.24.090: LICENSE; GRANTING:
Licenses granted pursuant hereto may be revoked by the issuing authority for
cause without notice and without cause upon the giving of thirty (30) days'
notice by the issuing authority. (Ord. 1931 § 2, 2009)
5.24.100: PENALTY:
Any person who operates or maintains an ambulance business without a license as
required in section
5.24.010 of this chapter or violates any provision of this chapter shall be
guilty of an offense and, upon conviction, shall be fined as provided in
section
1.12.010 of this code. Violation of this chapter shall also be grounds for
revocation or suspension of license granted. (Ord. 1931 § 2, 2009)
CHAPTER 5.26
ALARMS AND ALARM BUSINESSES
SECTION:
5.26.010: Alarm Businesses
5.26.020: Fee For Answering False Alarms
5.26.010: ALARM BUSINESSES:
   A.   "Alarm business" means any business in which the owners or employees
engage in the activity of altering, installing, leasing, maintaining,
repairing, replacing, selling or servicing alarm systems.
   B.   There are specifically authorized alarm businesses that employ an
answering service providing among its services the service of receiving on a
continuous basis through trained employees, emergency signals from alarm
systems, and thereafter immediately relaying the message by live voice to the
communication center of the city of Okmulgee. (Ord. 1931 § 2, 2009)
5.26.020: FEE FOR ANSWERING FALSE ALARMS:
There is imposed a fee for police or fire department response to false alarms.
For the first two (2) false alarms in any calendar year there shall be no
charge. For each response by the police thereafter, there shall be a fee of
twenty five dollars ($25.00). For each response by the fire department
thereafter, there shall be a fee of one hundred twenty five dollars ($125.00).
All such fees and all such responses shall be cumulative. (Ord. 1931 § 2, 2009)
CHAPTER 5.28
TAXICABS; LIMOUSINES
SECTION:
5.28.010: Definitions
5.28.020: License; Required
5.28.030: Inspection Required
5.28.040: License; Fees
5.28.050: Application; Contents; Title Certificate Display
5.28.060: Application; Hearing
5.28.070: Liability Insurance Required
5.28.080: Designation
5.28.090: Stands; Location And Marking
5.28.100: Rate Schedule
5.28.110: Unlawful Acts; Grounds For Revocation
5.28.120: Driver's License; Nontransferable
5.28.130: Driver's License; Revocation Or Suspension
5.28.140: Continuous Service Required
5.28.150: Equipment Required
5.28.160: License; Cause For Suspension
5.28.010: DEFINITIONS:
LIMOUSINE: When used in this chapter, a chauffeur driven vehicle for hire,
designed to accommodate seven (7) or more passengers excluding the chauffeur,
classified by the manufacturer as a limousine or stretched to accommodate more
passengers than in its original design, which is contracted for in advance and
operated on a fixed fare basis.
TAXICAB: Shall include any motor vehicles for hire, designed to carry ten (10)
persons or less, operated upon any street or highway, on call or demand,
accepting or soliciting passengers indiscriminately for transportation for hire
between such points along streets or highways as may be directed by the
passenger or passengers being transported. This classification shall not
include: a) motor buses running on established routes, b) funeral and ambulance
vehicles, c) motor vehicles transporting students to or from the public school
system when under contract or employment with a public, private, or parochial
school board or comparable governing body, or d) motor vehicles operated by the
owner where the cost of operation is shared by fellow workers between their
houses and the place of regular daily employment if not operated for more than
two (2) trips per day. (Ord. 1931 § 2, 2009)
5.28.020: LICENSE; REQUIRED:
No person, firm or corporation, or any owner, agent, employee or driver shall
operate or permit to be operated a motor vehicle as a taxicab/limousine unless
the proper city license has been issued to the owner thereof and the person
operating the vehicle has been licensed under the provisions of this chapter.
(Ord. 1931 § 2, 2009)
5.28.030: INSPECTION REQUIRED:
Each taxicab/limousine shall be inspected by the chief of police or the chief's
designee before a license or renewal of license shall be issued for such
taxicab/limousine, to ensure that each has the proper safety/operating
equipment required by this code and state law. (Ord. 1931 § 2, 2009)
5.28.040: LICENSE; FEES:
The license fee for each taxicab/limousine shall be set by resolution of the
city council and be payable on an annual basis. Every such license shall expire
on June 30 next following its issuance. Such license shall not be assignable
nor the fee prorated. The license fee shall be in addition to all other fees
required by the state. (Ord. 1931 § 2, 2009)
5.28.050: APPLICATION; CONTENTS; TITLE CERTIFICATE DISPLAY:
   A.   A written application to operate a taxicab/limousine shall be filed by
the owner of the vehicle or vehicles, or his agent, duly verified and stating
the following facts:
      1.   Name and address of applicant; if a partnership, the names and
addresses of all partners; if a corporation, the names and addresses of the
officers of the corporation;
      2.   Address of principal place of business;
      3.   Full description of each motor vehicle to be used as a taxicab/
limousine including motor and serial number, make and body style;
      4.   Trade name and identifying markings (if any) under which business
will be conducted and location of proposed cab stand(s) and garage(s) if a
taxicab;
      5.   Proof of insurance on all vehicles in an amount not less than twenty
five thousand dollars' ($25,000.00) bodily injury coverage for one person,
fifty thousand dollars' ($50,000.00) bodily injury coverage for two (2) or more
persons in any one accident, and twenty five thousand dollars' ($25,000.00)
property coverage.
   B.   The state title certificate for each listed vehicle shall be displayed
at the time of application. (Ord. 1931 § 2, 2009)
5.28.060: APPLICATION; HEARING:
Upon the filing of an application with the city clerk, the same shall be
referred to the license review board for hearing. The license review board
shall consist of the chief of police, the city clerk, the fire marshal, the
public works director, and the building official. The chief of police shall
serve as chairman and the city clerk shall serve as secretary of said board.
Upon the receipt of an application the city clerk shall call a meeting of the
license review board to pass upon said application at a date not to exceed
thirty (30) days from the date of the application. The city clerk shall cause
notice of said meeting to be posted at the city hall for at least ten (10) days
prior to said meeting date. The license review board shall, at the hearing,
grant license to the applicant if applicant shows by proper proof that public
convenience, necessity, and welfare require such service, or additional
service, proposed to be rendered by the applicant, provided said applicant has
complied with all other requirements of this chapter. Provided, that no showing
of necessity or convenience shall be necessary as to limousines. (Ord. 1931 §
2, 2009)
5.28.070: LIABILITY INSURANCE REQUIRED:
For the duration of the license for any taxicab/limousine, the owner shall
maintain and periodically file with the city clerk an insurance policy
providing liability insurance coverage for each and every vehicle owned, leased
or operated by him with a same or better coverage as specified in section
5.28.050 of this chapter, the coverage to be effective whether the taxicab/
limousine was, at the time of the accident, being used by the owner, his agent,
employee or any other person with his consent. The insurance policy shall
further provide that the same cannot be canceled until ten (10) days' written
notice has been given to the city clerk of intention to cancel the same. Should
the insurance be canceled and the applicant fail to procure other insurance
within ten (10) days of the notice of cancellation, the license issued shall
terminate. The policy of insurance shall carry the name of the owner and the
model and body style and motor or serial number of each vehicle so insured. The
policy shall provide for continuing liability thereunder notwithstanding any
recovery thereon and provide that until the policy is revoked upon notice to
the city clerk as provided in this chapter, the insurance company shall not be
relieved from liability for nonpayment of premiums, nor by virtue of insolvency
or bankruptcy of the insured. (Ord. 1931 § 2, 2009)
5.28.080: DESIGNATION:
Every person owning and operating a taxicab or taxicabs under license from the
city shall have the word "taxicab", "taxi", or "cab" in at least two inch (2")
letters painted on each side and the rear thereof, unless such word appears in
the trade name thereof, and shall have a serial body number assigned to each
cab operated similarly painted thereon. (Ord. 1931 § 2, 2009)
5.28.090: STANDS; LOCATION AND MARKING:
The city manager may designate such locations as taxi stands as considered
appropriate and the same shall be clearly marked. It is unlawful for any
vehicle other than a licensed taxicab to stand or park in such taxi stands, and
no location that is not designated by the city manager as a taxi stand shall be
utilized by taxicabs for such purpose. (Ord. 1931 § 2, 2009)
5.28.100: RATE SCHEDULE:
Each operator of a taxicab business under the provisions of this chapter shall
annually file with the city clerk a schedule of rates to be charged for
conveying passengers within the city, and it is unlawful to charge, collect or
receive any greater sum than the sum so stated; provided, that it is not
forbidden for the passenger to voluntarily give and the driver to receive a tip
in addition to the applicable rate. Such schedule of rates may be amended,
changed and refiled at any time during the year. (Ord. 1931 § 2, 2009)
5.28.110: UNLAWFUL ACTS; GROUNDS FOR REVOCATION:
It is unlawful and grounds for revocation of any taxicab/limousine license
issued under the provisions of this chapter for any licensee to do or permit
any of the following acts to be done:
   A.   Use any vehicle for the transportation of untaxed or improperly taxed
alcoholic beverages or cigarettes, or to facilitate prostitution;
   B.   Misrepresent any fact stated in the application for license;
   C.   Commit an assault or deception in an attempt to collect more than the
established rate schedule;
   D.   Fail to obtain, furnish proof of, and maintain liability insurance
coverage as required by this chapter. (Ord. 1931 § 2, 2009)
5.28.120: DRIVER'S LICENSE; NONTRANSFERABLE:
Every person employed for the purpose of operating, or who does operate, a
taxicab/limousine for hire within the city shall apply for a driver's license
for such purpose. The application shall include a copy of the applicant's
driving history obtained from the applicable state authority or a tag office,
and the applicant shall be subject to a background check to review any criminal
history. The application shall be filed with the city clerk, together with the
payment of the license fee as set by resolution of the city council. Such
license shall be issued upon proof of a reasonably safe driving record, the
lack of a criminal history involving intoxicants, criminal sexual conduct, or
violence. The license shall expire June 30 of each year, and shall not be
transferable. (Ord. 1931 § 2, 2009)
5.28.130: DRIVER'S LICENSE; REVOCATION OR SUSPENSION:
   A.   A taxicab/limousine driver's license may be revoked by the chief of
police for any of the following causes:
      1.   Upon conviction or violation of any federal law or state law
pertaining to felonies or involving moral turpitude;
      2.   For operating a taxicab/limousine in violation of the Oklahoma
alcoholic beverage control act, or under the influence of any intoxicants;
