   D.   It shall be unlawful for any person to fail or refuse the request of an
animal control officer or a police department representative to honor a warrant
from the court to deliver any animal which:
      1.   Has been declared a nuisance by a court of competent jurisdiction;
or
      2.   Is suspected of having or being exposed to rabies; or
      3.   Is a dangerous animal.
   E.   It shall be an offense for any person to stake, confine or pasture any
animal on any public school ground or other public property, or on any railroad
right of way or any property without the consent of the person owning or
controlling such property.
   F.   It shall be unlawful for any person to stake or confine an animal in
the front yard of any platted lot, unless said animal is confined by a fence of
sufficient height and strength as to prevent the animal’s escape. This
subsection expressly shall not prohibit the pasturing of herbivorous livestock
on agriculturally zoned property, or on unplatted and undeveloped property,
regardless of zoning:
      1.   If the owner of the property has given consent, and
      2.   If confined by a fence typically used for livestock. (Ord. 2176 § 1,
2022: Ord. 1877 § 2, 2006)
6.08.090: NUMBER OF ANIMALS ALLOWED IN RESIDENTIAL AREAS:
It shall be unlawful for any person to keep more than four (4) mammals that are
over four (4) months of age in any one location zoned for residential use. It
shall be unlawful for any person to keep more than one litter of offspring at
any one time for the first four (4) months following their birth. (Ord. 1951 §
1, 2010)
6.08.100: ANIMAL WASTE:
The owner of every animal shall be responsible for the removal of any excreta
deposited by his animal(s) on public walks, streets, alleys, parks,
recreational areas, other public areas, or private property. Manure shall be
hauled outside the city in a manner which does not jeopardize the public
health, or shall be spread evenly upon the ground and turned under at once or
as soon as the weather permits. (Ord. 1877 § 2, 2006)
6.08.110: ANIMAL CARE:
It is unlawful for any owner or keeper of an animal within the city of Okmulgee
to fail to provide his animals with sufficient, wholesome and nutritious food;
water in sufficient quantities; proper air and ventilation; shelter space and
protection from the weather; veterinary care when needed to prevent suffering;
and other humane care and treatment when required. (Ord. 1877 § 2, 2006)
6.08.120: CRUELTY TO ANIMALS:
   A.   It is unlawful for any owner or keeper of an animal within the city of
Okmulgee to wilfully, maliciously, or knowingly treat an animal in a cruel or
inhumane manner; to knowingly allow another person to treat an animal in a
cruel or inhumane manner; or to neglect an animal in a cruel or inhumane
manner. Specifically, no person shall:
      1.   Beat, torment, overload, overwork, or otherwise abuse an animal.
      2.   Cause, instigate, or permit any dogfight, cockfight, bullfight, or
other combat between animals or between animals and humans.
      3.   Keep a house, pit or other place used for fights between animals.
      4.   Crop a dog's ears, or dock a dog's tail, or neuter any dog or cat,
except when done by a licensed veterinarian.
      5.   Expose any known poisonous substance, whether mixed with food or
not, so that the same shall be liable to be eaten by any animal, provided, that
it shall be lawful for a person to expose on his own property common rat poison
or insecticide.
      6.   Anchor an animal on a lead or fence an animal in such a way that it
cannot reach shelter from rain or sun.
      7.   Deny an animal kept within the city adequate food and water.
   B.   Any person who, as the operator of a motor vehicle, strikes a domestic
animal shall stop at once and render such assistance as may be possible and
immediately report such injury or death to the animal's owner. In the event the
owner cannot be ascertained and located, such operator shall at once report the
accident to the Okmulgee police department. (Ord. 1877 § 2, 2006)
CHAPTER 6.12
LICENSING, VACCINATIONS, AND TAGS
SECTION:
6.12.010: Licenses And Tags
6.12.020: Permits For Commercial Animal Establishments
6.12.030: License And Permit Issuance And Revocation
6.12.040: Retrieving Identification From Dead Animals
6.12.050: Licenses Outside City Limits
6.12.010: LICENSES AND TAGS:
Any person owning, keeping, harboring or having custody within the city of a
dog or cat over six (6) months of age shall obtain an annual license as
follows:
   A.   Written application for licenses shall be submitted to the city at
locations designated by the city manager and shall include the name and address
of the applicant, a description of the animal, a copy of the rabies certificate
issued by a licensed veterinarian or antirabies clinic, proof of sterilization
(if applicable), and payment of the license fee.
   B.   Applications for a license must be made within thirty (30) days after
obtaining a dog or cat over six (6) months of age, or within fifteen (15) days
of the expiration of the previous license.
   C.   License fees shall not be required for certified service dogs or
certified governmental dogs used in law enforcement, however, all other
requirements for a license shall apply; a copy of the certificate of training
for the intended service or an affidavit attesting to the training shall be
included in the application.
   D.   Licensed animals shall wear a collar or harness at all times when off
the premises of the owners. The durable tag issued by the city upon issuance of
a license shall be affixed by the owner to the collar or harness. The failure
of an animal to wear a collar or harness when off the premises of the owner
shall be prima facie evidence of the failure of the owner to license the
animal.
   E.   The license fee shall be established by resolution of the city council.
   F.   Any license issued for an animal is not transferable to any other
animal, and should be surrendered upon the death of the animal for which it was
issued. (Ord. 1877 § 2, 2006)
6.12.020: PERMITS FOR COMMERCIAL ANIMAL ESTABLISHMENTS:
   A.   No person, partnership, corporation, or other entity shall operate a
commercial animal establishment or animal shelter without first obtaining a
permit in compliance with this section.
   B.   Any permit applicant shall submit the application to the city at
locations designated by the city manager, and shall provide for humane care of
all animals within its custody and conform to all provisions of this title and
other applicable laws.
   C.   After a permit applicant has shown the willingness and ability to
comply with this title, a permit shall be issued upon payment of the fee as
established by resolution of the city council. Categories are as follows:
      1.   Kennel with capacity of fewer than ten (10) dogs or cats.
      2.   Kennel with capacity of ten (10) or more, but fewer than fifty (50)
dogs and cats.
      3.   Kennel for fifty (50) or more dogs and cats.
      4.   Pet shop.
      5.   Riding stable.
      6.   Animal auction.
      7.   Zoological park.
      8.   Circus.
      9.   Grooming shop.
      10.   Petting zoo.
   D.   The permit period shall begin with the calendar year and shall run for
one year. Renewal applications may be made as early as one hundred eighty (180)
days prior to the start of the calendar year, and must include proof of a
current permit at the time of filing for renewal. Persons applying for a permit
during the permit year shall be required to pay a prorated fee as determined by
the city manager or his designee.
   E.   Every facility regulated by this title shall be considered a separate
enterprise, requiring separate permits.
   F.   Persons operating kennels for the breeding of dogs or cats may elect to
license such animals individually.
   G.   No animal permit fee is required of any veterinary hospital, animal
shelter or government operated zoological park.
   H.   Failure to obtain a permit before opening any facility covered in this
section shall result in a fine as established by resolution of the city
council.
   I.   Any person who has a change in the category under which a permit was
issued shall be subject to reclassification and readjustment of the permit fee.
(Ord. 1877 § 2, 2006)
6.12.030: LICENSE AND PERMIT ISSUANCE AND REVOCATION:
   A.   As to commercial facilities:
      1.   After an application is filed, the city shall inspect any commercial
facility prior to issuing the permit. The city may revoke any permit or license
if the person holding the permit or license refuses or fails to comply with any
section contained in this title, other regulations promulgated by the city of
Okmulgee, any law governing the protection and keeping of animals, or if any
animal is determined by the animal control officer, a police officer, the city
manager or his designee to be a "dangerous animal" as defined in this title.
      2.   It shall be a condition of the issuance of any permit or license
that the city shall be permitted to inspect all animals and the public portions
of the commercial premises where animals are kept at any time during daylight
hours, and shall, if permission for such inspection is refused, seek a warrant
to enforce the inspection. Any search when the premises are not open for
business, or any search during nighttime hours, or any search of a private
residence shall require a warrant.
      3.   Any person having been denied a license or permit for a commercial
facility may not reapply for a period of thirty (30) days; each reapplication
shall be accompanied by a fee as established by resolution of the city council.
   B.   As to all licenses and permits:
      1.   Any person whose permit or license is revoked, shall, within ten
(10) days thereafter, remove the animal from the city of Okmulgee or otherwise
humanely dispose of all animals owned, kept, or harbored in accordance with
state law. No part of the permit or license fee shall be refunded.
      2.   If the applicant has withheld or falsified any information on the
application, the city shall refuse to issue a permit or license.
      3.   No person who has been convicted of cruelty to animals shall be
issued a permit or license to operate a commercial animal establishment.
      4.   No person who has been convicted of cruelty to animals shall be
issued a license to own a dog or a cat for a period of at least one year
following conviction. (Ord. 1877 § 2, 2006)
6.12.040: RETRIEVING IDENTIFICATION FROM DEAD ANIMALS:
An attempt shall be made to retrieve any city license pet tags on every dead
dog and cat picked up by the city of Okmulgee. (Ord. 1877 § 2, 2006)
6.12.050: LICENSES OUTSIDE CITY LIMITS:
The licensing of dogs and cats shall be available on a voluntary basis to those
persons living outside the city limits of Okmulgee, should those persons desire
to be subject to this chapter, for the purposes of identifying and protecting
their dog(s) or cat(s) from euthanasia in the event that the Okmulgee animal
control officer captures the pet(s) inside the city limits. (Ord. 1877 § 2,
2006)
CHAPTER 6.20
ANIMAL SHELTER AND IMPOUNDMENT
SECTION:
6.20.010: Animal Shelter Established
6.20.020: Animals To Be Impounded; Entry On Property
6.20.030: Impoundment, Description, Notice
6.20.040: Breaking Into Animal Shelter
6.20.050: Fees For Impoundment
6.20.060: Reclamation Of Impounded Animals
6.20.070: Disposition Of Impounded Animals
6.20.080: Rabies Control; Action
6.20.090: Apprehension Of Animals
6.20.010: ANIMAL SHELTER ESTABLISHED:
A city animal shelter is hereby established. It shall be under the immediate
control of such person or organization as may be officially designated. The
person in charge of the animal shelter shall provide humane care and proper
sustenance for all animals impounded. The city may contract with another agency
for the use of an animal shelter maintained by the agency. (Ord. 1877 § 2,
2006)
6.20.020: ANIMALS TO BE IMPOUNDED; ENTRY ON PROPERTY:
The animal control officer, a police officer, or such other officer or employee
of the city of Okmulgee as the city manager may authorize, shall take into
custody and impound any animal found at large or in violation of any provisions
of the ordinances of the city. The animal control officer, a police officer, or
such other officer or employee of the city of Okmulgee as the city manager may
authorize, shall also take into custody and impound any animal that is trapped
by a property owner after the animal was found on the property owner's land. In
taking an animal into custody under authority of this title, the animal control
officer or other employee may enter onto open areas of private property to gain
custody of the animal. (Ord. 1877 § 2, 2006)
6.20.030: IMPOUNDMENT, DESCRIPTION, NOTICE:
   A.   The animal control officer, upon receiving any animal, shall make a
complete registry, entering the type, breed, color, and sex of such animal;
whether or not the animal is licensed; and the date of impoundment. If an
animal is licensed, he shall enter the name and address of the owner and the
number of the license tag.
   B.   It is the duty of the animal control officer to keep all animals
impounded for a minimum of seventy two (72) hours unless reclaimed by the owner
as described below. All inquiries concerning lost or impounded animals shall be
directed to the animal control officer. If an impounded animal is licensed or
if the owner of an impounded animal is known to the animal control officer, the
animal control officer shall give notice to the owner, by mail or telephone or
posting on the front door of the residence, that unless the animal is reclaimed
as provided in this chapter, it will be disposed of. If any animal shall not
have been redeemed within the expiration of seventy two (72) hours following
the notice, it may be destroyed or otherwise humanely disposed of. Any
unlicensed animal required by law to be licensed or whose owner cannot be
located may be disposed of in a humane manner. Any animal that appears to be
suffering from rabies, hydrophobia, mange or other infectious disease, or any
animal that is severely injured, shall not be released but may be forthwith
destroyed in a humane manner.
   C.   Any captured animal that is clearly feral may be forthwith destroyed in
a humane manner.
   D.   The animal control officer or a designee shall keep complete and
accurate records for the care, feeding, veterinary treatment, and disposition
of all animals impounded at the shelter.
   E.   Owners of impounded animals may also be proceeded against for violation
of any applicable section of this title. (Ord. 1877 § 2, 2006)
6.20.040: BREAKING INTO ANIMAL SHELTER:
No unauthorized person shall:
   A.   Break or attempt to break into the animal shelter, or take or let out
any animal kept therein;
   B.   Take or attempt to take from any officer or employee of the city of
Okmulgee or from any contracted agent of the city of Okmulgee any animal taken
into custody as provided in this title; or
   C.   In any manner interfere with or hinder an officer, employee, or agent
of the city of Okmulgee in the discharge of his duties relating to the taking
into custody and impounding of animals as provided in this title. (Ord. 1877 §
2, 2006)
6.20.050: FEES FOR IMPOUNDMENT:
   A.   The City Council by Resolution and/or Ordinance shall determine the
fees to be charged for impounding and keeping animals.
   B.   Any person redeeming an impounded animal shall pay a forty dollars
($40.00) impoundment fee and ten dollars ($10.00) per day housing fee per
animal to the city clerk or his/her designee and present receipt for payment to
the animal control officer or person in charge of the pound before the latter
releases the animal. Any veterinary expenses incurred for the benefit of the
impounded animal are the responsibility of the animal's owner and shall be paid
by the owner with evidence of payment presented to the city clerk or his/her
designee prior to release of the animal to the owner. (Ord. 1877 § 2, 2006;
amd. Ord. 2148, 2021)
6.20.060: RECLAMATION OF IMPOUNDED ANIMALS:
Reclamation of impounded animals may be made as provided below:
   A.   The party desiring to reclaim an animal shall present to the animal
control officer or his designee, satisfactory proof of ownership of the animal
reclaimed and a valid city license for said animal.
   B.   The owner must provide proof that the animal is currently vaccinated
for rabies. If the owner cannot provide proof that the animal is currently
vaccinated, he may post a bond with the city clerk or his/her designee in an
amount established by resolution of the Okmulgee city council, and have the
animal vaccinated within three (3) days. After the animal is vaccinated as
described above, the owner may provide proof of vaccination to the city clerk
or his/her designee and receive a refund of the bond amount.
   C.   The owner shall pay the applicable pound fee and show evidence to the
animal control officer or his designee that the fee has been paid. The animal
control officer or his designee shall thereupon release the reclaimed animal to
the party.
   D.   The city of Okmulgee shall automatically revoke all licenses issued to
animal owners against whom three (3) or more violations of this title have been
assessed in a twelve (12) month period whether or not the violations involve
the same animal, and the owner shall, within ten (10) days thereafter, humanely
dispose of all animals owned, kept, or harbored in accordance with state law.
No part of the license fees shall be refunded. Failure of the owner to humanely
dispose of all animals within the ten (10) days allowed shall result in
confiscation of the animals for immediate disposition by the city.
   E.   Any intact, licensed animal for which a second citation is issued for
"animal at large" shall be spayed/neutered at the owner's expense. Any intact,
unlicensed animal that is impounded for any violation shall be spayed/neutered
at the owner's expense. Before reclaiming the animal from the animal control
officer, the owner shall post a bond with the city clerk or his/her designee in
an amount established by resolution of the Okmulgee city council and shall have
the animal spayed/neutered within thirty (30) days. After the animal has been
spayed/neutered as described above, the owner may provide proof of that fact to
the city clerk or his/her designee and receive a refund of the bond amount. If
such proof of spaying/neutering is not provided, regardless of the reason, the
owner shall forfeit the posted bond. (Ord. 1877 § 2, 2006)
6.20.070: DISPOSITION OF IMPOUNDED ANIMALS:
   A.   At the end of the seventy two (72) hour period prescribed in this
chapter, animals that have not been claimed and redeemed by their owners shall
be disposed of in one of the following manners:
      1.   The animal shall be placed with a humane society or other animal
shelter facility.
      2.   The animal may be adopted by private individuals upon the following
conditions:
         a.   Application of the required license for the animal, if the new
owner is a resident of the city of Okmulgee.
         b.   Written agreement that, if the animal is not already sterilized,
it will be sterilized within thirty (30) days for adult animals or by a
specified date for pups and kittens, that the animal will be vaccinated against
rabies within three (3) days for adult animals or within a specified date for
pups and kittens, and deposit of funds with the releasing agency to ensure that
the adopted animal will be spayed or neutered.
      3.   The animal shall be humanely euthanized by an approved method, and
the carcass disposed of in an approved manner.
   B.   Animals of no apparent value taken into custody, as provided in this
chapter, shall be destroyed in a humane manner by the officer or employee of
the city in charge of such animal or by the animal control officer, and shall
not be impounded in the animal shelter.
   C.   The animal control officer may euthanize any animal if it has been
surrendered to the animal shelter. The animal control officer or police officer
may destroy any animal that is so sick or injured that its cure is considered
by the animal control officer or police officer to be impracticable or if death
is imminent. In either of such events, such euthanization or destruction may be
done immediately, without notice or any waiting period. Anyone surrendering an
animal shall provide proof of his or her identity before the animal will be
accepted. (Ord. 1877 § 2, 2006)
6.20.080: RABIES CONTROL; ACTION:
   A.   Any rabies suspected animal shall be securely and separately confined
for observation for a period of ten (10) days. The confinement and observation
shall be at the Okmulgee animal shelter, or, at the discretion of the owner,
the animal may be confined in a veterinary hospital. Confinement at either
location and all veterinary charges including, if required, but not limited to,
euthanasia and/or lab analysis of animal remains for evidence of rabies shall
be at the owner's expense. Boarding kennels shall not be considered proper
confinement facilities. The owner must immediately surrender the rabies
suspected animal to the animal control officer or his designee. In the event
the owner wishes to have the animal held for observation at a veterinary
hospital, the animal will be transported to the veterinary hospital of the
owner's choice (within Okmulgee County) by a representative of the Okmulgee
animal shelter. Any person failing to surrender a rabies suspected animal, or
any person removing the rabies suspected animal from the city limits of
Okmulgee, is guilty of an offense. If, upon examination by a veterinarian, the
animal has no signs of rabies at the end of the impoundment period, it may be
released to the owner or, in case of a stray, it shall be disposed of in
accordance with applicable laws. In either event, the veterinarian shall make a
written report of the disposition of the animal to the city manager and the
animal control officer. At the end of the ten (10) day observation period, the
animal control officer, the city manager, or his designee shall notify any
person bitten by a rabies suspected animal whether such animal exhibited
symptoms or indications of rabies. If within the period of impoundment the
animal dies or exhibits symptoms or indications of rabies, it shall be examined
by a veterinarian for clinical diagnosis. Any animal diagnosed with rabies
shall then be properly euthanized by a veterinarian. The head of any rabies
suspected animal that dies shall be submitted to the state health department
laboratory for confirmation of diagnosis. In this event, the animal control
officer, the city manager, or his designee shall immediately notify any person
bitten of the diagnosis.
   B.   Any domestic dog or cat which is not effectively immunized against
rabies virus encephalitis and is exposed to rabies through an animal known to
be rabid shall be euthanized immediately by the veterinarian in charge or the
animal control officer in a manner which will preserve the head for analysis;
or such nonimmunized, rabies exposed dog or cat shall be strictly quarantined
and observed for a period of not less than six (6) months, and such animal
shall be immunized against rabies at least thirty (30) days prior to release.
Expenses for quarantine and immunization shall be borne by the owner or other
person responsible for the animal. (Ord. 1877 § 2, 2006)
6.20.090: APPREHENSION OF ANIMALS:
   A.   The animal control officer, police officer, or such other officer or
employee of the city as the city manager may authorize shall take into custody
and impound any animal running at large in violation of any provision of the
ordinances of the city, may enter upon the open premises of the owner or other
open private premises to take such animal into custody, and, if with reasonable
effort an animal illegally at large cannot be caught, may kill it, either on or
off private premises.
   B.   Notwithstanding any of the above provisions, should any dangerous
animal be found running at large constituting an immediate hazard to the
public's safety, and circumstances make the capture or seizure of such animal
impractical or impossible, or, should any animal found running at large elude
capture in spite of the exercise of reasonable efforts by responsible city
officials, then, in that event, such animal may be slain or destroyed by the
animal control officer or police officer using due regard for the safety and
welfare of the public in the selection of the method and manner of such
destruction or slaying.
   C.   It shall be an offense for any person within the city limits of the
city of Okmulgee to fail or refuse to deliver to the animal control officer
upon demand any unlicensed dog or cat, vicious animal, animal which is a
nuisance, rabies suspected animal, dog or cat found at large, or any animal the
keeping or harboring of which is declared to be an offense. (Ord. 1877 § 2,
2006)
CHAPTER 6.24
CONTRACT LICENSING
SECTION:
6.24.010: Contract Licensing; Agreements With Veterinarians
6.24.010: CONTRACT LICENSING; AGREEMENTS WITH VETERINARIANS:
The city of Okmulgee may enter into agreements with local veterinarians to
collect the fees and issue licenses pursuant to this title. The veterinarian
may keep two dollars ($2.00) of the amount collected to offset bookkeeping and
other costs associated with this program. The veterinarian shall be required to
keep records of such transactions on a form provided by the office of animal
control and said records shall be turned over to the animal control officer on
a weekly basis along with the balance of the fees collected. The animal control
officer shall submit all fees collected to the finance department of the city
of Okmulgee along with copies of all forms submitted by the veterinarians.
(Ord. 1877 § 2, 2006)
TITLE 7
SOCIAL SERVICES
Prevention Of Discrimination   7.04
CHAPTER 7.04
PREVENTION OF DISCRIMINATION
SECTION:
7.04.010: Declaration Of Purpose; Construction
7.04.020: General Definitions
7.04.030: Discrimination In Employment; Definitions; Unlawful Acts; Exceptions
7.04.040: Discrimination In Public Accommodations; Definitions; Unlawful Acts
7.04.050: Discrimination In Housing; Definitions; Unlawful Acts; Exceptions
7.04.060: Enforcement, Powers And Duties
7.04.070: Complaints; Procedure
7.04.080: Penalty
7.04.010: DECLARATION OF PURPOSE; CONSTRUCTION:
   A.   In furtherance of its obligation to advance the general welfare of the
city, the city council is cognizant of its duty to give all citizens the
opportunity to reach their full potential. The city council therefore declares
that any inhibiting conditions caused by racial, ethnic, sexual, familial, or
religious factors are matters of concern to the city and threaten the rights
and privileges of its citizens and the institutions of a free and democratic
society.
   B.   This chapter shall be construed according to the fair import of its
terms. (Ord. 2026, 2014)
7.04.020: GENERAL DEFINITIONS:
In this chapter, unless the context otherwise requires, the following
definitions apply:
DISCRIMINATORY PRACTICE: A practice designated as discriminatory under the
terms of this chapter.
NATIONAL ORIGIN: Includes the national origin of an ancestor.
PERSON: Includes one or more individuals, associations, corporations, joint
apprenticeship committees, joint stock companies, labor unions, legal
representatives, mutual companies, partnerships, receivers, trusts, trustees,
unincorporated organizations, or any other legal or commercial entity,
including the city or any of its agencies. (Ord. 2026, 2014)
7.04.030: DISCRIMINATION IN EMPLOYMENT; DEFINITIONS; UNLAWFUL ACTS; EXCEPTIONS:
   A.   Definitions: In this chapter the terms contained in this section apply
unless the context otherwise requires:
   EMPLOYER: Any person who employs five (5) or more employees, exclusive of
the parents, spouse, or children of such person, including the city, its
departments, boards, commissions, and authorities, and any other governmental
agency within its jurisdiction, but excluding any religious, fraternal, or
sectarian organization which is not supported in whole or part by any
governmental appropriations.
   EMPLOYMENT: Does not include the employment of individuals in domestic
service.
   EMPLOYMENT AGENCY: Any person regularly undertaking with or without
compensation to procure opportunities for employment or to procure, recruit,
refer or place employees.
   LABOR ORGANIZATION: Any organization which exists for the purpose in whole
or in part of collective bargaining or of dealing with employers concerning
grievances, terms or conditions of employment, or of other mutual aid or
protection in relation to employment.
   B.   Unlawful Acts: It is an unlawful employment practice, except where
based upon applicable national security regulations established by the United
States, by the state, or by any political subdivision of the state having
jurisdiction in the city:
      1.   For any employer to refuse to hire any person or otherwise to
discriminate against any person with respect to hiring, tenure, compensation,
promotion, discharge or any other terms, conditions or privileges, directly or
indirectly related to employment, because of race, color, sex, religion, family
status, ancestry, national origin or place of birth;
      2.   For any employer, employment agency or labor organization to
establish, announce or follow a policy of denying or limiting, through a quota
system or otherwise, the employment of membership opportunities of any person
or group of persons because of race, color, sex, religion, family status,
ancestry, national origin or place of birth;
      3.   For any employer, labor organization, employment agency or any joint
labor-management committee controlling apprentice training programs to deny to
or withhold from any person the right to be admitted to or participate in a
guidance program, an apprenticeship training program, an on the job training
program or any other occupational training program because of race, color, sex,
religion, family status, ancestry, national origin or place of birth;
      4.   For any employer, employment agency or labor organization to require
of any applicant for employment or membership any information concerning race,
color, sex, religion, family status, ancestry, national origin or place of
birth;
      5.   For any employer, employment agency or labor organization to publish
or circulate, or to cause to be published or circulated, any notice or
advertisement relating to employment or membership which indicates any
discrimination because of race, color, sex, religion, family status, ancestry,
or national origin or place of birth;
      6.   For any employment agency to fail or refuse to classify properly or
refer to employment or otherwise to discriminate against any person because of
race, color, sex, religion, family status, ancestry, national origin or place
of birth;
      7.   For any employer substantially to confine or limit recruitment or
hiring of employees, with intent to circumvent the spirit and purpose of this
chapter, to any employment agency, employment service, labor organization,
training school, training center or any other employee referring source which
serves persons who are predominantly of the same race, color, sex, religion,
ancestry, national origin or place of birth;
      8.   For any labor organization to discriminate against any person in any
way which would deprive or limit his employment opportunities or otherwise
adversely affect his status as an applicant for employment or as an employee
with regard to tenure, compensation, promotion, discharge, or any other terms,
conditions, or privileges directly or indirectly related to employment because
of race, color, sex, religion, family status, ancestry, national origin, or
place of birth;
      9.   For any employer, employment agency or labor organization to
discriminate against any person because he has made a valid complaint,
testified or assisted in any legal manner in any investigation or proceeding
under this chapter;
      10.   For any person, whether or not an employer, employment agency or
labor organization, to aid, incite, compel, coerce or participate in the doing
of any act declared to be an unlawful employment practice by this chapter, or
to obstruct or prevent enforcement of the provisions of this chapter, or to
attempt directly or indirectly to commit any act declared by this chapter to be
an unlawful employment practice.
   C.   Exceptions: It is not a discriminatory practice:
      1.   For an employer to hire and employ an employee, or an employment
agency to classify or refer for employment an individual, for a labor
organization to classify its membership or to classify or refer for employment
an individual, or for an employer, labor organization, or joint labor-
management committee controlling an apprenticeship or other training or
retraining program to admit or employ an individual in the program on the basis
of his race, color, religion, family status, sex, or national origin if race,
color, sex, religion, family status, ancestry, national origin or place of
birth is a bona fide occupational qualification reasonably necessary to the
normal operation of the business or enterprise; or
      2.   For a school, college, university, or other educational institution
to hire and employ an employee of a particular religion if the school, college,
university, or other educational institution is, in whole or substantial part,
owned, supported, controlled or managed by a particular religion or by a
particular religious corporation, association, or society, or if the curriculum
of the school, college, university, or other educational institution is
directed toward the propagation of a particular religion;
      3.   To apply different standards of compensation or different terms,
conditions, privileges or responsibilities of employment pursuant to a bona
fide seniority or merit system, or a system which measures earnings by quantity
or quality of production or to employees who work in different locations, if
the differences are not the result of an intention to discriminate because of
race, color, sex, religion, family status, ancestry, national origin or place
of birth; or
      4.   To give and to act upon the results of a professionally developed
ability test if the test, its administration, or action upon the results is not
designed, intended, or used to discriminate because of race, color, sex,
religion, family status, ancestry, national origin or place of birth;
      5.   Nothing contained in this chapter requires an employer, employment
agency, labor organization, or joint labor-management committee subject to this
chapter to grant preferential treatment to an individual or to a group because
of race, color, sex, religion, family status, ancestry, national origin or
place of birth of the individual or group on account of an imbalance which may
exist with respect to the total number or percentage of persons of any race,
color, sex, religion, family status, ancestry, national origin or place of
birth employed by an employer, referred or classified for employment by an
employment agency or labor organization, or admitted to or employed in an
apprenticeship or other training or retraining program, in comparison with the
total number or percentage of persons of the race, color, sex, religion, family
status, ancestry, national origin or place of birth, in the state or community,
section, or other area, or in the available work force in the state or
community, section, or other area. It is not a discriminatory practice,
however, for a person subject to this chapter to adopt and carry out a plan to
eliminate or reduce imbalance with respect to race, color, sex, religion,
family status, ancestry, national origin or place of birth, if the plan has
been filed with the commission under regulations of the commission, and the
commission has not disapproved the plan;
      6.   Notwithstanding any other provisions of this chapter, it is not an
unlawful employment practice because of sex to differentiate in employment,
compensation, terms, conditions or privileges of employment between male and
female employees if such differences are otherwise required or permitted by the
laws of the state or by the provisions of the federal civil rights act of 1964,
as amended, or by the provisions of section 6(d) of the federal fair labor
standards act of 1938, as amended; nor is it an unlawful plan to provide for
the retirement of female employees at a younger age than male employees, or to
provide differences in annuity, death and survivors' benefits between widows
and widowers of employees. (Ord. 2026, 2014)
7.04.040: DISCRIMINATION IN PUBLIC ACCOMMODATIONS; DEFINITIONS; UNLAWFUL ACTS:
   A.   "Public accommodation" includes any place, business or activity which
is open to, accepts or solicits the patronage of the general public or offers
goods, services or recreation to the general public.
   B.   It is an unlawful public accommodation practice:
      1.   For the owner, lessee, proprietor, manager, superintendent, agent or
employee of any business or place of public accommodation, resort, recreation
or amusement to:
         a.   Refuse, withhold from or deny to any person because of his race,
color, sex, religion, family status, ancestry, national origin or place of
birth, either directly or indirectly, any of the accommodations, advantages,
facilities, services or privileges, products or goods of such place of public
accommodation, resort, or amusement; or
         b.   Publish, circulate, issue, display, post or mail, either directly
or indirectly, any written or printed communication, notice, or advertisement
to the effect that any of the accommodations, advantages, facilities, goods,
products, services and privileges of any such place shall be refused, withheld
or denied to any person of any particular race, color, sex, religion, family
status, ancestry, national origin or place of birth is unwelcome,
objectionable, or not acceptable, desired or solicited;
      2.   For any person to aid, incite, compel, coerce or participate in the
doing of any act declared to be an unlawful public accommodations practice
under this chapter. (Ord. 2026, 2014)
7.04.050: DISCRIMINATION IN HOUSING; DEFINITIONS; UNLAWFUL ACTS; EXCEPTIONS:
   A.   Definitions:
   ACCOMMODATION, HOUSING:
      1.   A building, structure or portion thereof which is used or occupied,
or is intended, arranged or designed to be used or occupied as a home,
residence or sleeping place by a person, by a family, or by a group of persons
living together; or
      2.   A parcel of real property or lot available for the construction of a
housing accommodation.
   DWELLING: Any building, structure, or portion thereof which is occupied as,
or designed or intended for occupancy as a residence by one or more families,
and any vacant land which is offered for sale or lease for the construction or
location thereon of any such building, structure, or portion thereof.
   FAMILY: Includes a single individual.
   LENDING INSTITUTION: Any bank, insurance company, savings and loan
association, or any other person regularly engaged in the business of lending
money or guaranteeing loans.
   OWNER: The owner, coowner, lessee, sublessee, mortgagee, assignee, manager,
agent, or any other person having the right of ownership or possession or the
authority to sell, rent, or lease any housing accommodation, or any person
having an equitable or security interest in any housing accommodation,
including the city and its departments, boards, commissions, and authorities.
   REAL ESTATE BROKER: Any natural person, partnership, corporation, or other
association which for a fee or other valuable consideration manages, sells,
purchases, exchanges, or rents, or negotiates, or offers or attempts to
negotiate the sale, purchase, exchange or rental of the real property of
another, or holds itself out as engaged in the business of managing, selling,
purchasing, exchanging or renting the real property of another, or collects
rent for the use of the real property of another, and includes real estate
salesmen or agents or any other person employed by a real estate broker to
perform or to assist in the performance of his business.
   B.   Unlawful Acts: It is an unlawful housing practice, except as otherwise
provided in this section:
      1.   After the making of a bona fide offer for any owner, real estate
broker, or any other person to refuse to sell, lease, sublease, rent, assign or
otherwise transfer, or to refuse to negotiate for the sale, lease, sublease,
rental assignment or other transfer of the title, leasehold or other interest
in any housing accommodation to any person, or to represent that any housing
accommodation is not available for inspection, sale, lease, sublease, rental,
assignment or other transfer when in fact it is so available, or otherwise to
deny or withhold any housing accommodation (after the making of a bona fide
offer) from any person because of race, color, sex, religion, family status,
disability, ancestry, national origin or place of birth, or to discriminate
against, segregate or assign quotas to any person or group of persons in
connection with the sale, lease, sublease, rental, assignment or other transfer
of title, leasehold, or other interest in any housing accommodation;
      2.   For any person, including any owner or real estate broker, to
include in the terms, conditions or privileges of any sale, lease, sublease,
rental assignment or other transfer of any housing accommodation any clause,
condition or use or occupancy of such housing accommodation because of race,
color, sex, religion, family status, disability, ancestry, national origin or
place of birth;
      3.   For any person including any owner or real estate broker, to
discriminate in the furnishing of any facilities or services for any housing
accommodation because of race, color, sex, religion, family status, disability,
ancestry, national origin or place of birth;
      4.   For any person, including any owner or real estate broker, to make,
print, publish, circulate, issue or display or cause to be made, printed,
published, circulated, issued or displayed any communication, notice,
advertisement or sign of any kind relating to the sale, rental, lease,
sublease, assignment, transfer or listing of a housing accommodation or
accommodations which indicates any preference, limitation, specification or
discrimination based on race, color, sex, religion, family status, ancestry,
disability, national origin or place of birth;
      5.   For any person, including any bank, banking organization, mortgage
company, insurance company or other financial or lending institution, or any
agent or employee thereof to whom application is made for financial assistance
for the purchase, lease, acquisition, construction, rehabilitation, repair or
maintenance of any housing accommodation or housing accommodations:
         a.   After the making of a bona fide offer or application, to
discriminate against any person or group of persons because of race, color,
sex, religion, family status, disability, ancestry, national origin or place of
birth of such person or group of persons or of the prospective occupants or
tenants of such housing accommodation in the granting, withholding, extending,
modifying, restriction discriminating against or requiring any other person to
discriminate against any person in the renewing, or in the rates, terms,
conditions, or privileges of any such financial assistance, or in the extension
of services in connection therewith, or
         b.   To use any form of application for such financial assistance or
to make any record of inquiry in connection with applications for such
financial assistance which indicates, directly or indirectly, any limitation,
specification or discrimination as to race, color, sex, religion, family
status, disability, ancestry, national origin or place of birth, or any intent
to make any such limitation, specification or discrimination;
      6.   For any real estate broker or real estate salesman or agent, or any
other person for business or economic purposes, to induce, directly or
indirectly, or to attempt to induce directly or indirectly, the sale or rental
or the listing for sale or rental of a housing accommodation by representing
that a change has occurred or will or may occur with respect to the racial,
religious or ethnic composition of the street, the block, neighborhood or area
in which said housing accommodation is located;
      7.   For any person, whether or not a real estate broker, real estate
salesman or agent, owner or lending institution to aid, incite, compel, coerce
or participate in the doing of any act declared to be an unlawful housing
practice under this chapter, or to obstruct or prevent enforcement or
compliance with the provisions of this chapter or any rule, regulation or order
of the commission, or to attempt directly or indirectly to commit any act
declared by this chapter to be an unlawful housing practice.
   C.   Exceptions: Nothing in this chapter shall:
      1.   Bar any religious or sectarian institution or organization, or any
charitable or educational organization which is operated, supervised or
controlled by or in connection with a religious or sectarian organization, or
any bona fide private or fraternal organization from limiting admission to or
giving preference to persons of the same religion or sect, or to members of
such private or fraternal organization, or from making such selection as is
calculated by such organization to promote the religious or sectarian
principles or the aims, purposes or fraternal principles for which it is
established or maintained; or
      2.   Require an owner to offer property to the public at large before
selling or renting it, nor shall this chapter prohibit owners from giving
preference to prospective tenants or buyers for any reason other than of race,
color, sex, religion, family status, disability, ancestry, national origin or
place of birth; or
      3.   Apply to the rental of a portion of a dwelling containing
accommodations for not more than four (4) families, one of which is the
residence of the owner;
      4.   Apply to any single-family house sold or rented by an owner;
provided, that such private individual owner does not own more than three (3)
such single-family houses at any one time; provided, further, that in the case
of the sale of any such single-family house by a private individual owner not
residing in such house at the time of such sale or who was not the most recent
resident of such house prior to such sale, the exemption granted by this
subsection shall apply only with respect to one such sale within any twenty
four (24) month period; and provided, further, that such bona fide private
individual owner does not own any interest in, nor is there owned or reserved
on his behalf, under any express or voluntary agreement, title to or any right
to all or a portion of the proceeds from the sale or rental of more than three
(3) such single-family houses at any one time; and provided, further, that the
sale or rental of any such single-family house shall be excepted from the
application of this chapter only if such house is sold or rented:
         a.   Without the use in any manner of the sales or rental facilities
or the sales or rental services of any real estate broker, agent, or salesman
or of such facilities or services of any person in the business of selling or
renting dwellings, or of any employee or agent of any such broker, agent,
salesman, or person, and
         b.   Without the publication, posting, or mailing, after notice of any
advertisement or written notice in violation of the provisions of this section.
Nothing in this provision prohibits the use of attorneys, escrow agents,
abstractors, title companies, and other such professional assistance as
necessary to perfect or transfer the title. (Ord. 2026, 2014)
7.04.060: ENFORCEMENT, POWERS AND DUTIES:
The city manager shall have those powers and duties to police and enforce the
provisions of this chapter as are set out in this section; provided that these
duties may be delegated to an individual or a committee of three (3) to five
(5) persons, with a majority of any committee service as a quorum. A majority
vote of the membership of the committee shall be required to take any formal or
official action. The city manager or the designee shall have the responsibility
and it shall be its duty to:
   A.   Receive, investigate and seek the satisfactory adjustment of complaints
charging unlawful practices, as set forth in this chapter;
   B.   Receive and investigate other complaints of discrimination against any
person because of race, color, sex, religion, family status, disability,
ancestry, national origin or place of birth, and to seek the satisfactory
adjustment of such complaints. Any complaint filed under this subsection which
the commission believes may constitute a violation of a law of the United
States Of America or the state of Oklahoma may be reported to appropriate state
or federal agencies;
   C.   Study and investigate by means of public hearing or otherwise any
conditions having an adverse effect on intergroup relations in the city and to
study the problems of prejudice, intolerance, bigotry and discrimination as
they affect the public safety and general welfare of the city;
   D.   Institute and conduct educational and other programs to promote the
equal rights and opportunities of all persons, regardless of their race, color,
sex, religion, family status, ancestry, national origin or place of birth, and
to promote understanding among persons and groups of different races, colors,
sexes, religions, family status, ancestries, national origin or place of birth.
In the performance of these duties, the city manager may cooperate with
interested citizens, private agencies and agencies of the federal, state and
local government;
   E.   Issue publications and reports of investigations and research in the
field of human relations;
   F.   Advise and make recommendations to the city council regarding the
employment and contractual practices of the city government;
   G.   Render, as necessary, a written report of its activities and
recommendations to the city council;
   H.   Recommend legislation to promote and ensure equal rights and
opportunities for all persons regardless of their race, color, sex, religion,
family status, disability, ancestry, national origin, or place of birth. (Ord.
2026, 2014)
7.04.070: COMPLAINTS; PROCEDURE:
   A.   A complaint charging that any person has engaged or is engaging in any
unlawful practice as set forth in this chapter may be made by an aggrieved
person in accordance with such procedures as the city administration may
prescribe.
   B.   The complaint shall be in writing, signed and verified by the aggrieved
person and including the names and addresses of the person or persons alleged
to have committed the unlawful practice and the particulars thereof and such
other information as may be required.
   C.   There shall be a prompt and full investigation of each complaint of a
questionable practice and the findings shall be reported to the city council
within thirty (30) days after receiving the complaint. All investigations shall
remain confidential in order to protect all parties involved.
   D.   If the investigation report determines that there is no basis for the
allegations in a complaint, the complaint shall be dismissed and the
complainant notified in writing. Within ten (10) days from the receipt of such
notice, the complainant or his attorney may file with the city clerk a request
for review, and the city shall provide the complainant and his attorney an
opportunity to appear before the city council in public session. After such a
review, the city council may reverse the decision, or sustain the dismissal of
the complaint, and there shall be no further review of such decision.
   E.   If the investigation report determines that probable cause exists for
the allegations made in the complaint, the city manager shall attempt to
eliminate the unlawful practice by means of private conferences or meeting with
all parties. Neither the city manager, the party nor their representative nor
other persons appearing at or participating in such conferences or meetings
shall make public the details of such informal proceedings.
   F.   If in the case of any complaint, the city manager fails to eliminate
the questionable or unlawful practice charged in the complaint by the means of
informal proceedings, the city manager may make a detailed report and
recommendations to the city council. The city council shall within thirty (30)
days take action upon the recommendation of the city manager by:
      1.   Returning the recommendation to the administration for further
study, investigation and recommendation;
      2.   Rejecting the recommendations;
      3.   Accepting the recommendation of the city manager, and forwarding it
to the city attorney for appropriate legal action in municipal court.
   G.   Initiation of any complaint under this chapter without foundation in
fact, or initiated for malicious purpose, or in bad faith shall be a violation
of this chapter and such persons shall be subject to the penalties as provided
in section
1.12.010 of this code.
   H.   In the event the respondent refuses or fails to comply with any rule of
the city or violates any of the provisions of this chapter, the city shall
certify the case and the entire record of its proceedings to the council for
appropriate legal remedy. (Ord. 2026, 2014)
7.04.080: PENALTY:
Any person, firm, corporation, or association who violates any provision of
this chapter or any rule or regulation pertaining thereto adopted by the
committee shall be subject to a fine as provided in section
1.12.010 of this code. (Ord. 2026, 2014)

RESTAURANTS

8.04.010: DEFINITIONS:
The following definitions shall apply in the interpretation and the enforcement
of this chapter:
EMPLOYEE: Any person who handles food or drink during preparation or serving,
or who comes in contact with any eating or cooking utensils, or who is employed
in a room in which food or drink is prepared or served.
HEALTH OFFICER: The duly authorized official employed or otherwise assigned the
duties of licensing, or inspection, or enforcement of any code or provision of
law relating to the public health and the wholesomeness of food, by the
Okmulgee County health department.
ITINERANT RESTAURANT: One operating for a temporary period in connection with a
fair, carnival, circus, public exhibition, or other similar gathering.
RESTAURANT: Restaurant, coffee shop, cafeteria, short order cafe, luncheonette,
tavern, sandwich stand, soda fountain, and all other eating or drinking
establishments, as well as kitchens or other places in which food or drink is
prepared for sale elsewhere.
UTENSILS: Includes any kitchenware, tableware, glassware, cutlery, utensils,
containers, or other equipment with which food or drink comes in contact during
storage, preparation, or serving. (Ord. 1923 § 1, 2008: prior code § 613)
8.04.020: PERMIT; REQUIRED:
It is unlawful for any person who does not possess a current and unrevoked
permit from the Okmulgee County health officer to operate a restaurant in the
city of Okmulgee. Such permit shall be posted in a conspicuous place. (Ord.
1923 § 2, 2008)

(Rep. by Ord. 1923 § 3, 2008)

(Rep. by Ord. 1923 § 3, 2008)
