8.56.010: AMBULANCE SERVICE CHARGE:
To secure funds with which to provide the citizens and inhabitants of the City
with ambulance and other emergency medical services, directly or contractually,
there is established an ambulance service charge whereby each family living
unit within the limits of the City shall be levied and assessed a monthly
charge of five dollars ($5.00), each and every month hereafter. (Ord. 2127,
2019)
8.56.020: FAMILY LIVING UNIT; DEFINITION:
The term "family living unit" includes, but is not limited to, single-family
residences, trailer coaches, single living units in duplexes, rooming houses,
apartments and other multi-family dwellings, but shall not include hotels,
motels or nursing homes. (Ord. 1262 § 1, 1975)

(Rep. by Ord. 1860 § 1, 2005)

bills of the City to the water account which services the family living unit,
and payment of said charge shall be due from, and the responsibility and
obligation of, the holder or owner of said water account. Payment of said
charge shall be governed by and subject to the terms, conditions, penalties and
requirements of section
13.04.280 of this Code. (Ord. 1309 § 1, 1976: Ord. 1262 § 1, 1975)
CHAPTER 8.60
DILAPIDATED BUILDINGS
SECTION:
8.60.010: Definitions
8.60.020: Removal Of Dilapidated Buildings; Procedure; Notice; Public Hearing
8.60.030: Right Of Entry
8.60.040: Cost; Billing
8.60.050: Lien; Civil Remedies
8.60.060: Right Of Appeal
8.60.010: DEFINITIONS:
For the purposes of this chapter:
DILAPIDATED BUILDING:
   A.   A structure which through neglect or injury lacks necessary repairs or
otherwise is in a state of decay or partial ruin to such extent that said
structure is a hazard to the health, safety, or welfare of the general public.
   B.   A structure which is unfit for human occupancy due to the lack of
necessary repairs and is considered uninhabitable or is a hazard to the health,
safety, and welfare of the general public.
   C.   A structure declared by the municipal governing body to constitute a
public nuisance.
OWNER: The owner of record as shown by the most current tax rolls of the county
treasurer. (Ord. 2081, 2016)
8.60.020: REMOVAL OF DILAPIDATED BUILDINGS; PROCEDURE; NOTICE; PUBLIC HEARING:
   A.   A hearing may be held before the city manager or his/her designee to
determine if any property is dilapidated and has become detrimental to the
health, safety, or welfare of the general public and the community, or if said
property creates a fire hazard which is dangerous to other property.
   B.   That at least fifteen (15) days prior to such hearing, notice that a
building is to be torn down or removed shall be given to the property owner.
A copy of the notice shall be:
      1.   Posted on the property to be affected; and
      2.   Sent by certified mail with return receipt requested to the property
owner at the address shown by the current year's tax rolls in the office of the
county treasurer; and
      3.   Sent by regular mail to any mortgage holder on said property as
shown by the records in the office of the county clerk to the last known
address of the mortgagee; and
      4.   Provided, that if neither the property owner or mortgage holder can
be located, notice may be given by publication 1 ; such notice may be published
once not less than ten (10) days prior to any hearing, or in the alternative,
notice may be given by first class mail to the property owner and mortgage
holder.
   C.   Upon a finding that the condition of the property constitutes a
detriment or a hazard and that the property would be benefited by the removal
of such conditions, the city manager or his/her designee may cause the
dilapidated building to be torn down and removed, and such official shall fix
reasonable dates for the commencement and completion of the work. The municipal
clerk shall immediately file a notice of lien with the county clerk describing
the property, the findings at the hearing, and stating that the city claims a
lien on said property for destruction and removal costs.
   D.   If the property owner should fail to cause the work to be performed
within the dates established, the representative of the community development
department may proceed to have such work done. (Ord. 2017, 2014: Ord. 1647 § 2,
1989: Ord. 1350 § 3, 1978)
 
Notes
1 1. As defined in 11 OS § 1-102(7).
8.60.030: RIGHT OF ENTRY:
In the event the work is not performed by the property owner within the dates
established, the agents of the city are granted the right of entry on the
property for the performance of the necessary work as a governmental function.
(Ord. 1647 § 3, 1989: Ord. 1350 § 4, 1978)
8.60.040: COST; BILLING:
If the city dismantles or removes the dilapidated building, the cost to the
property owner shall not exceed the actual costs of the labor, maintenance, and
equipment required, and if done on a private contract basis, the contract shall
be awarded to the lowest and best bidder. The representative of the community
development department shall determine the actual cost of the dismantling and
removal and any other expenses that may be necessary in conjunction therewith,
including the cost of notice and mailing. The city clerk shall forward a
statement of the actual costs and a demand for payment of such costs, by
certified mail with return receipt requested to the property owner, and to any
mortgage holder at the last known address of the mortgagee. Upon payment to the
city for costs incurred, the city clerk shall file a release of lien. (Ord.
2017, 2014)
8.60.050: LIEN; CIVIL REMEDIES:
In the event payment is not received within six (6) months from the date of the
mailing of the statement to the owner of such property, the city clerk shall
forward a certified statement of the amount of the cost to the county
treasurer, and such costs shall be levied on the property and collected by the
county treasurer as are other taxes authorized by law. The cost and the
interest thereon shall be a lien against the property from the date the notice
of the lien is filed with the county clerk. Said lien shall be coequal with the
lien of ad valorem taxes and all other taxes and special assessments and shall
be prior and superior to all other titles and liens against the property. The
lien shall continue until the cost is fully paid. At any time prior to
collection as provided for in this section, the city may pursue any civil
remedy for collection of the amount owing and interest thereon. Upon receiving
payment, the city clerk shall forward to the county treasurer a notice of such
payment and shall direct discharge of the lien. (Ord. 1647 § 5, 1989: Ord. 1750
§ 6, 1978)
8.60.060: RIGHT OF APPEAL:
Any property owner shall have the right to appeal an order of the city manager
or his/her designee to the city council; provided, that such appeal shall be
taken by filing written notice of appeal with the city clerk within ten (10)
days after such order is rendered. (Ord. 2017, 2014)
CHAPTER 8.64
GARBAGE AND OTHER REFUSE
SECTION:
8.64.010: Refuse System
8.64.020: Unauthorized Storage, Scattering Or Dumping Declared Nuisance
8.64.030: Fees; Billing And Payment
8.64.040: Dead Animal Removal
8.64.050: City Right To Contract; Exclusive
8.64.060: Burning Unlawful; Violation Declared Nuisance
8.64.070: Waste Material And Construction Debris; Owner Responsibility
8.64.080: Unauthorized Handling, Disposal Or Transportation
8.64.010: REFUSE SYSTEM:
That to provide a suitable, effective, and efficient system of garbage and
refuse storage and collection the following system is adopted.
   A.   1. The City shall furnish one polycart container to each residence or
family living unit located upon designated container routes, and sanitation
service shall be street side only. It shall be the responsibility of the
consumer to place the container on the street against the curb or the edge of
the street on the day and time designated for pick-up, and to remove the
container from street side on the same day following pick-up. Carry-out service
shall be provided to residents who are physically unable to place polycart
containers on the street. The City may require a doctor's certification of
physical limitation or disability prior to furnishing carry-out service.
      2.   The City shall work with commercial consumers to determine the
number of dumpsters needed and the level of service desired. Thereafter, the
City is to provide a dumpster in such quantity or quantities as agreed upon.
The dumpster shall be placed, and thereafter kept, at a location assigned by
the City. In the event a commercial consumer's needed level of service is
insufficient to justify the use of a dumpster, the consumer will be provided a
polycart as the refuse container. The sharing of dumpsters is prohibited, and
exceptions to this prohibition may be granted solely on the written approval of
the Public Works Director or his designee.
   B.   Polycart containers and dumpsters are, and shall remain, the exclusive
property of the City, and shall remain at the assigned location regardless of
changes in ownership or occupancy of the premises. The consumer shall be
responsible for damage to or loss of the polycart/dumpster provided for use by
the consumer, other than normal and reasonable wear and tear. Polycarts/
dumpsters that are lost, damaged or destroyed through neglect, abuse or
improper use of the consumer shall be repaired or replaced by the City at the
expense of the consumer, and such expense shall be added or billed to the
consumer's utility bill. The billing for such repair or replacement may be had
by lump sum on a single monthly utility billing, or may be prorated with
installment payments over several utility billing periods, but not to exceed
twelve (12) months, at the option of the City and if it appears a lump sum
billing would create a substantial hardship.
   C.   Where polycarts are provided by the City, consumers shall use the
polycarts as their first means of disposing of refuse. An additional charge,
equal to one month's service, will be added to the consumer's utility bill for
each special pick-up provided.
   D.   Consumers other than single-family living units may be served by
polycarts, multiple polycarts, or may be served by commercial type dumpsters
furnished by the City and placed by the City at selected locations on or in the
immediate vicinity. The decision as to which type service shall be provided
shall be exclusively that of the City.
   E.   It shall be the duty of each person utilizing the refuse system to
deposit all garbage and trash from such person's premises in the polycarts and/
or dumpsters as provided by the City for collection, and to keep the polycarts/
dumpsters in a sanitary condition that does not jeopardize public health and
safety. Every person placing garbage or small items of trash in any container
provided by the City shall drain all liquids from such garbage and trash and
bag or contain it in some manner before placing it in such container. It shall
be the duty of each person utilizing the refuse system to provide a suitable
closable container for the disposal of hypodermic syringes, needles, and other
items of refuse capable of causing injury during normal pick up and handling by
the sanitation workers. Such containers shall be adequate to prevent the
needles or any sharp edges from penetrating the external surface of the trash
bag during pick up.
   F.   It is unlawful to place large domestic items, including, but not
limited to, television sets, computer monitors and central processing units,
copiers, fax machines, wood, tree limbs, furniture, major appliances, tires,
and cable, in dumpsters or polycarts. It is unlawful to place flammable or
hazardous materials including, but not limited to, flammable liquids or gases,
oil, batteries, and paint in dumpsters or polycarts.
   G.   Consumers can obtain the use of additional polycarts upon payment of a
fee of fifty dollars ($50.00). Provided, that a single family living unit may
not have more than three (3) polycarts in use.
   H.   It is unlawful and a misdemeanor to place refuse of any type in the
polycart or dumpster of another consumer without the specific authorization of
that consumer.
   I.   It is unlawful to place lumber, furniture, or major appliances in
polycarts or dumpsters as a part of routine refuse pick up; however, consistent
with the City of Okmulgee's recycling policy, lumber, furniture, and certain
major appliances may be placed curbside for a monthly "bulky item" pick up
service provided by the Public Works Department when the person responsible for
the residential account has first called public works to arrange for the
special pick up. This service is limited to no more than four (4) "bulky item"
pick ups per residential account holder in any calendar year, and each pick up
is limited to not more than three (3) bulky items. Commercial accounts are not
eligible for "bulky item" pick ups. (Ord. 2121, 2018: Ord. 1980, 2011: Ord.
1819 § 1, 2003: Ord. 1576 § 1, 1986: Ord. 1466 § 1, 1983: Ord. 1401 § 3, 1981)
8.64.020: UNAUTHORIZED STORAGE, SCATTERING OR DUMPING DECLARED NUISANCE:
   A.   Storage of garbage and trash in containers prescribed by this chapter
and the regular collection thereof by the City upon payment of fees and charges
provided in this chapter is essential to the efficient operation of the City
and for the prevention of disease and protection of public health. Scattering
of garbage or trash, storage of trash or garbage except in containers as
provided by this chapter, or the accumulation of garbage or trash by reason of
nonpayment of fees or charges for its removal, is hereby declared to be a
public nuisance and a violation of this chapter.
   B.   Under no circumstances shall garbage or trash be dumped or stored on
any street or in any alley or on any lot without being placed in proper
containers as prescribed herein; nor shall waste material and debris from
construction repair work, leaves, trees or tree trimmings be dumped or stored
on any street or in any alley. (Ord. 1401 § 4, 1981)
8.64.030: FEES; BILLING AND PAYMENT:
For the purpose of defraying the expense of collection, removal and disposal of
garbage and refuse, the following sanitation rates, fees or charges shall be
levied and assessed:
   A.   Residential consumers using polycarts shall be charged a monthly fee
for each container at the rate listed for the corresponding time period, in
accordance with the following schedule:
 
Time Period            Rate
Effective July 1, 2018 $16.00
Effective July 1, 2019 17.00
Effective July 1, 2020 18.00
 
   B.   Where multi-family living units are served by multiple containers,
consumers shall pay a monthly rate, fee or charge for each container equal to
that listed in subsection A of this section for the corresponding time period
in accordance with the schedule listed therein, and shall be computed at the
appropriate rate for the corresponding time period multiplied by eighty percent
(80%) of the number of multi-family living units so served so as to allow for
vacant units.
   C.   All consumers served by dumpsters shall pay a fee for each dumpster
multiplied by the number of collections per week picked up during the billing
period at the following rates listed for the corresponding time period:
 
COMMERCIAL
(Effective July 1, 2023)
Dumpster $70.00
 
   All commercial customers provided a polycart for service shall pay a rate
equal to one-half (1/2) the rate charged for a dumpster.
   D.   Notwithstanding any other provision of this section, the City Manager
shall have authority to negotiate a sanitation contract with any establishment
or concern which has twenty (20) or more refuse containers in service, or which
has more than sixty (60) cubic yards of refuse for removal per day; any
contract so negotiated is subject to the approval of the City Council.
   E.   Billing for the sanitation charge shall be made on the monthly water
bills of the City to the water account which provides water service for the
family living unit, establishment or concern which receives the garbage and
refuse removal, and payment shall be due from, and the responsibility and
obligation of, the holder or owner of said water account. Payment of said
charge shall be governed by and subject to the terms, conditions, penalties and
requirements of section
13.04.280 of this Code. Provided, that should any person, establishment or
other concern which receives garbage and refuse collection by the City not be a
water user, the City Manager shall cause suitable billing and statement
procedures to cover such person, establishment or other concern.
   F.   Notwithstanding any other provisions of this section, residential
consumers of the garbage and refuse collection system that are located outside
the City limits shall be charged two (2) times the charges hereinabove set
forth for residential consumers within the City limits.
   G.   A residential consumer requesting a special pick-up of refuse at a time
other than the regularly scheduled pick-up time shall have a fee equal to one
month's service added to the consumer's utility bill for each such special
pick-up. Consumers receiving dumpster service who request a special pick-up at
a time other than the regularly scheduled pick-up time shall have a fee equal
to one month's single dumpster, single pick-up service added to the consumer's
utility bill for each such special pick-up. (Ord. 2194, 2023: Ord. 2121, 2018:
Ord. 2115, 2018: Ord. 2019, 2014: Ord. 1980, 2011: Ord. 1965, 2010: Ord. 1819 §
2, 2003: Ord. 1792 § 1, 1999: Ord. 1624 § 1, 1987: Ord. 1576 § 2, 1986: Ord.
1462 § 1, 1983: Ord. 1442 § 1, 1982: Ord. 1433 § 1, 1981: Ord. 1427 § 1, 1981:
Ord. 1401 § 5, 1981)
8.64.040: DEAD ANIMAL REMOVAL:
   A.   The bodies of any dead animals within the City shall be promptly
removed. In the case of animals weighing less than one hundred (100) pounds,
the City shall assist the owner of the animal or the person in lawful
possession of the property where the animal's body was found, if the
responsible person places the animal in a box, sack, or other receptacle before
collection, and then notifies the animal control officer that a pick up of the
animal is requested; such a pick up shall be without charge. In the case of
animals weighing one hundred (100) pounds or more, the owner of the animal or
the person in possession of the property where the animal's body was found
shall pay the charges for the removal; said charges shall be set in advance by
resolution of the City Council or executive order of the City Manager, provided
that the amount must be posted at the animal shelter and available for
inspection at City Hall.
   B.   It shall be unlawful and an offense for any person to place or throw
any dead animal in or upon any street, alley, sidewalk, public park, or any
other public place within the City of Okmulgee. (Ord. 1877 § 1, 2006: Ord. 1401
§ 6, 1981)
8.64.050: CITY RIGHT TO CONTRACT; EXCLUSIVE:
The City, through its duly authorized agents, servants or employees, shall have
an exclusive right to collect garbage and trash within the City, and it is
unlawful for any person, firm or corporation, except as otherwise provided in
this chapter, to collect such garbage or trash, or either of them, in the City.
(Ord. 1401 § 7, 1981)
8.64.060: BURNING UNLAWFUL; VIOLATION DECLARED NUISANCE:
It is unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to burn any refuse anywhere
within the City without first obtaining a permit to do so from the Chief of the
Fire Department or the City Manager. If a permit is obtained, the burning shall
be done in strict compliance with the directions given in connection with the
granting of the permit. This section declaring the burning of refuse unlawful
is necessary for the proper protection of the health and property of the
citizens of the City, and the violation of this section is a public nuisance
and a violation of this chapter. (Ord. 1401 § 8, 1981)
8.64.070: WASTE MATERIAL AND CONSTRUCTION DEBRIS; OWNER RESPONSIBILITY:
Natural soil, earth, sand, clay, gravel, loam, stones, bricks, brickbats,
plaster, portland cement, glass and glassware, and all other noncombustible
materials, and the debris from the construction or repair of buildings,
structures, or dwellings, shall be removed by the owner, tenant or contractor
at his or their expense; and such waste material or debris must not be stored
in the garbage and refuse containers provided by the City under this chapter.
(Ord. 1401 § 9, 1981)
8.64.080: UNAUTHORIZED HANDLING, DISPOSAL OR TRANSPORTATION:
It is unlawful for any person to dump, place or bury in any lot, land or street
or any alley within the City any refuse; and it is unlawful for any person to
transport any refuse upon any street within the City except as otherwise
provided for in this chapter. (Ord. 1401 § 10, 1981)
CHAPTER 8.66
JUNKYARD AND SCRAP METAL PROCESSING FACILITY CONTROL
SECTION:
8.66.010: Declarations And Findings
8.66.020: Definitions
8.66.030: Prohibition On Operation Of Junkyards Or Facilities
8.66.040: Removal Of License Tags And Penalty
8.66.050: Screening Required
8.66.060: Violations; Penalties
8.66.070: Violations As Public Nuisance; Abatement
8.66.080: Rules, Regulations And Policies
8.66.090: Limitations Upon Parking Certain Vehicles; Penalties
8.66.010: DECLARATIONS AND FINDINGS:
For the purpose of promoting the public safety, health, welfare, convenience
and enjoyment of public travel, to protect the public investment in public
highways, and to preserve and enhance the scenic beauty of lands bordering
public highways, it is hereby declared to be in the public interest to regulate
and restrict the establishment, operation, and maintenance of junkyards and
scrap metal processing facilities in areas adjacent to the portions of the
Oklahoma primary systems within the city in accordance with the Oklahoma
junkyard and scrap metal processing facility control act in title 69, Oklahoma
Statutes, section 1251 et seq. (the "act"), and this chapter. The city council
hereby finds and declares that junkyard and scrap metal processing facilities
which do not conform to the requirements of this chapter are public nuisances.
(Ord. 1771 § 1, 2001)
8.66.020: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this chapter:
AUTOMOBILE GRAVEYARD: Any establishment or place of business which is
maintained, used or operated for storing keeping, buying or selling wrecked,
scrapped, ruined or dismantled motor vehicles or motor vehicle parts.
COMMISSION: The transportation commission of the Oklahoma department of
transportation.
DEPARTMENT: The Oklahoma department of transportation.
JUNK: Old scrap copper, brass, rope, rags, batteries, paper, trash, rubber
debris, waste, or junked, dismantled or wrecked automobiles, or parts thereof,
iron, steel, and other old or scrap ferrous or nonferrous material.
JUNKYARD: An establishment or place of business which is maintained, operated
or used for storing, keeping, buying or selling junk, or for the maintenance or
operation of an automobile graveyard, and the term shall include garbage dumps
and sanitary fills.
PRIMARY SYSTEM: That portion of connected main highways as officially
designated by the state of Oklahoma and/or the department within the city
including, but not limited to, U.S. Highway 75 and 62 and State Highway 56 and
Loop 56, or as may hereafter be so designated, by the transportation
commission, and approved by the secretary of transportation, pursuant to the
provisions of title 23, United States Code, "Highways".
SCRAP METAL PROCESSING FACILITY: An establishment having facilities used
primarily for processing iron, steel or nonferrous metals and whose principal
product is such iron, steel or scrap for sale for remelting purposes only, the
processor being considered a manufacturer. (Ord. 1771 § 1, 2001)
8.66.030: PROHIBITION ON OPERATION OF JUNKYARDS OR FACILITIES:
No person, firm or corporation shall establish, operate or maintain a junkyard
or scrap metal processing facility, any portion of which is within one thousand
feet (1,000') of the nearest edge of the right of way of any primary highway.
(Ord. 1771 § 1, 2001)
8.66.040: REMOVAL OF LICENSE TAGS AND PENALTY:
Any person, firm or corporation or employee of any person, firm or corporation
in the business of dismantling or salvaging any part or parts of junked or
salvaged motor vehicles shall remove all license tags attached to said junked
or salvaged motor vehicles within ten (10) days from receipt of said vehicle.
Any person in violation of this section shall be guilty of an offense and shall
be punished by a fine of not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more
than two hundred dollars ($200.00), plus court costs and each day an offense
continues to occur shall be deemed to constitute a separate offense. (Ord. 1771
§ 1, 2001)
8.66.050: SCREENING REQUIRED:
Any junkyard or scrap metal processing facility in existence on the effective
date hereof which is within one thousand feet (1,000') of the nearest edge of
the right of way and visible from the main traveled way of any highway on the
primary system shall be screened by the person, firm or corporation operating
said junkyard or scrap metal processing facility in the manner and at locations
required by the city in accordance with written plans submitted to and approved
by the representative of the community development department. (Ord. 2017,
2014)
8.66.060: VIOLATIONS; PENALTIES:
From and after the effective date hereof it shall be unlawful for any person,
firm or corporation to own or construct, establish, operate and/or maintain any
facility which would be in violation of the terms of this chapter, and such
would be a public nuisance. When the city shall determine that any junkyard or
scrap metal processing facility is not fenced or screened as required by this
chapter, the person, firm or corporation owning the property or operating the
junkyard or scrap metal processing facility shall be notified of such violation
and the manner in which compliance with this chapter is required. Such notice
shall be in writing and require the person, firm or corporation owning the
property or operating the junkyard or scrap metal processing facility to comply
with the provisions of this chapter within ninety (90) days from the date of
such notice. Any person, firm or corporation failing to comply with the
provisions of this chapter after the expiration of ninety (90) days from the
date of such notice or the expiration of such time authorized by the city shall
be guilty of an offense and upon conviction thereof shall be fined not less
than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than two hundred dollars ($200.00)
for each day such violation continues after the expiration of the ninety (90)
day notice or extension thereof plus court costs. (Ord. 1771 § 1, 2001)
8.66.070: VIOLATIONS AS PUBLIC NUISANCE; ABATEMENT:
   A.   Violations of the provisions of this chapter shall constitute a public
nuisance, and the city manager or his/her designee is authorized to file an
application or action in Okmulgee County district court requesting issuance of
an order requiring immediate compliance with this chapter and the abatement of
said nuisance at the sole cost of the person, firm or corporation establishing,
operating or maintaining a junkyard or scrap metal processing facility on the
primary system within the city.
   B.   Violations of the provisions of this chapter shall constitute a public
nuisance and a hearing may be held before the city manager or his/her designee
to determine if any owner and/or operator of any junkyard or scrap metal
processing facility has violated or failed to comply with this chapter and has
established, operated or maintained a public nuisance which is detrimental to
the health, safety, or welfare of the general public and the community. At
least fifteen (15) days prior to such hearing, notice shall be given to the
property owner and/or the operator.
A copy of the notice shall be:
      1.   Posted on the property to be affected; and
      2.   Sent by certified mail with return receipt requested to the property
owner at the address shown by the current year's tax rolls in the office of the
county treasurer; and
      3.   Sent by certified mail with return receipt requested to the
operator, if not the property owner, at the last known address of the operator;
and
      4.   Sent by regular mail to any mortgage holder on said property as
shown by the records in the office of the county clerk to the last known
address of the mortgagee; and
      5.   Provided, that if the property owner or mortgage holder and/or
operator cannot be located, notice may be given by publication 1 ; such notice
may be published once not less than ten (10) days prior to any hearing, or in
the alternative, notice may be given by first class mail to the property owner,
mortgage holder and/or operator.
Upon a finding that the property owner and/or operator has violated this
chapter the city manager or his/her designee may issue an order which orders
compliance with this chapter, and such official shall fix reasonable dates for
the commencement and completion of the work. If the property owner and/or the
operator should fail to comply or cause the work to be performed within the
dates established, the city manager or his/her designee may proceed to issue an
order which orders compliance and/or proceed to district court as provided in
subsection A of this section.
Any property owner shall have the right to appeal an order of the
representative of the community development department to the city council;
provided, that such appeal shall be taken by filing written notice of appeal
with the city clerk within ten (10) days after such order is rendered. (Ord.
2017, 2014: Ord. 1771 § 1, 2001)
 
Notes
1 1. As defined in 11 OS § 1-102(8).
8.66.080: RULES, REGULATIONS AND POLICIES:
The city manager or his/her designee is hereby empowered to prescribe
reasonable rules, regulations and policies not inconsistent with this chapter
for the implementation and administration of the junkyard control program
required hereunder. (Ord. 1771 § 1, 2001)
8.66.090: LIMITATIONS UPON PARKING CERTAIN VEHICLES; PENALTIES:
All motor vehicles owned by, leased to, used by or under the control of any
junkyard or scrap metal processing facility, including employees and agents
thereof, are required, when parked, to be parked within the sightproof,
screened area of the junkyard or scrap metal processing facility and not
visible from the main traveled way of the primary system. It shall be unlawful
and an offense for any person, firm or corporation or employee or agent of any
person, firm or corporation owning, operating or maintaining any junkyard or
scrap metal processing facility to park any motor vehicle owned by, leased to,
used by or under the control of any junkyard or metal processing facility, in a
manner contrary to this section and, upon conviction thereof, shall be fined
for each motor vehicle unlawfully parked each day not less than twenty five
dollars ($25.00) nor more than one-half (1/2) of the maximum penalty set forth
in section
1.12.010 of this code, plus court costs, and each day an offense continues
shall be deemed to constitute a separate offense. (Ord. 1867 § 3, 2006: Ord.
1771 § 1, 2001)
CHAPTER 8.68
LANDFILL FEES
SECTION:
8.68.010: Landfill Fees
8.68.010: LANDFILL FEES:
The Okmulgee Municipal Authority operates the Okmulgee landfill. For the
defraying the expense of operation and maintenance of the landfill, the
following fees shall be levied and assessed:
   A.   Refuse-(In County Customers): eleven dollars and twenty-five cents
($11.25) per cubic yard.
   B.   Refuse-(Out of County Customers): fourteen dollars ($14.00) per cubic
yard.
   C.   Concrete: fifteen dollars ($15.00) per ton.
   D.   Brush: three dollars ($3.00) per cubic yard.
   E.   Weight Fee (use of scales only): five dollars ($5.00).
   F.   Transfer Trailer: fourteen dollars ($14.00) per cubic yard.
An Oklahoma Department of Environmental Quality (ODEQ) Solid Waste Fee of
$1.25/ton will be assessed on all loads, and will be prorated on a scale for
loads less than one ton. (Ord. 2219, 2025: Ord. 2163 § 1, 2022: Ord. 2144, 9-
21-2021)
CHAPTER 8.70
OPEN BURNING
SECTION:
8.70.010: Definitions
8.70.020: Allowable Open Burning
8.70.030: Prohibited Open Burning
8.70.040: General Conditions And Requirements For All Open Burning
8.70.050: Permits Required
8.70.060: Permit Fees
8.70.070: Acquiring A Permit
8.70.075: Free Burn Permit
8.70.080: Burn Permit Revocation
8.70.090: Violation; Penalties
8.70.100: Relation To The International Fire Code
8.70.010: DEFINITIONS:
COMBUSTIBLE MATERIALS: Any substance which will readily burn.
DOMESTIC REFUSE: Any refuse produced during normal daily household operations.
LAND CLEARING OPERATION: The uprooting, cutting, or clearing of vegetation in
preparation for construction or change of land use of any type.
LAND MANAGEMENT: Activities that improve the condition of a land area or reduce
the threat of uncontrolled wildfires.
MAINTENANCE OF AGRICULTURAL PARCELS: The burning of agricultural land in
preparation for planting, removing unwanted growth, destroying of pests, or
improving the land.
OPEN BURNING: The burning of any materials wherein products of combustion are
emitted directly into the ambient air without passing through a stack or
chimney from an enclosed chamber. For the purpose of this definition, a chamber
shall be regarded as enclosed, when, during the time combustion occurs, only
apertures, ducts, stacks, flues or chimneys necessary to provide combustion air
and permit the escape of exhaust gas are open.
OPEN PIT INCINERATOR: A pit for combustible material to be placed in for
burning, accompanied by a device that would deliver air to the area of
combustion, in order to increase the amount of air introduced to the fire and
increase the efficiency of the fire, therefore producing less smoke and more
complete combustion of the wood products involved. (Ord. 1903 § 1, 2007)
8.70.020: ALLOWABLE OPEN BURNING:
Open burning will be allowable for the following reasons and/or purposes:
   A.   Recreational fires, campfires, bonfires, fires that are a part of
ceremonial occasions, or fires for the noncommercial preparation of food, with
the following provisions:
      1.   All bonfires require a permit and shall not be more than five feet
by five feet by five feet (5' x 5' x 5') in dimension and shall burn for less
than three (3) hours. A bonfire shall consist of seasoned, dry wood. No
gasoline or other liquid hydrocarbon fuels shall be used for ignition.
      2.   Campfires are not permitted in residentially zoned areas. Campfires
require a permit and approval of the fire marshal's or fire inspector's office.
      3.   Barbecue grills or other wood burning grills are allowed at public
park and recreation facilities if approved by the park, events, and recreation
department. All fires on publicly owned park and recreation property shall be
attended at all times by at least one individual, until the fire is completely
extinguished.
      4.   Fires used for food preparation purposes, fueled solely by wood,
charcoal, and gas and confined within a metal or masonry appliance designed for
such use are allowed without a permit, provided:
         a.   The fires are supervised,
         b.   The size of fire does not present a fire spread danger, and
         c.   The fires are being used expressly for the preparation of food.
Food preparation fires are not permitted directly on the ground, unless the
containment is approved by the fire marshal's or fire inspector's office.
      5.   Barbecuing on combustible decks or balconies at multistory apartment
complexes is not allowed unless noncombustible surfaces are in place to prevent
embers or ashes from contacting combustible materials. Noncombustible surfaces
are to be above, below and adjacent to the site.
   B.   Land management fires set by an approved state or local agency
specifically for management of forests or rangelands.
   C.   Land clearing operations set for the specific reason of clearing land
for construction, provided:
      1.   All land clearing operations will be conducted in an approved open
pit, with induced air, when conducted within one hundred fifty (150) to three
hundred feet (300') upwind of any occupied structures or as approved by the
fire marshal.
      2.   No land clearing operation burning shall be permitted less than one
hundred fifty feet (150') to any occupied structure.
      3.   If operations are proposed less than three hundred feet (300') of
any occupied structures, all adjoining occupied property owners must consent in
writing prior to consideration of the permit being issued.
      4.   Land clearing operations with distances of five hundred feet (500')
or more to occupied structures may be conducted aboveground when approved by
the fire marshal's or fire inspector's office.
      5.   During land clearing and maintenance operations burning is
restricted to the hours between sunrise and sunset. At sunset, the fires must
be extinguished or covered to eliminate any residual smoke. The fire marshal's
or fire inspector's office may grant an earlier start time, provided that
weather conditions are favorable.
      6.   Land clearing operations shall be conducted so as to reduce the
amount of wood to be burned during the operation.
   D.   Prevention or control of disease or pests as approved by the state or
local health department.
   E.   Fire for the purpose of training public and industrial fire department
personnel.
   F.   Elimination of fire hazards that cannot be abated by any other means.
   G.   Maintenance of agricultural land parcels five (5) acres or greater.
      1.   Areas to be burned for agricultural purposes must be confined by
plowing or tilling the perimeter to a width acceptable to the fire marshal's or
fire inspector's office.
      2.   Burning of tree and vegetation waste on parcels greater than five
(5) acres for property maintenance is allowed by permit, so long as the
byproducts do not adversely affect surrounding occupants. The fire marshal's or
fire inspector's office shall decide as to whether or not the amount of
material to be burned falls under this provision or will be deemed as a land
clearing operation. (Ord. 2082, 2016: Ord. 1903 § 1, 2007)
8.70.030: PROHIBITED OPEN BURNING:
All open burning for the following reasons is prohibited:
   A.   Burning of domestic refuse.
   B.   Burning of yard debris, construction/demolition material, or any
materials other than wood and vegetation. (Ord. 1903 § 1, 2007)
8.70.040: GENERAL CONDITIONS AND REQUIREMENTS FOR ALL OPEN BURNING:
   A.   Open burning may be conducted with the following provisions:
      1.   No public nuisance is or will be created.
      2.   The burning is controlled so that a traffic hazard is not created as
a result of the air contaminants being emitted.
      3.   The burning is conducted so that ambient air quality of the general
area as well as the surrounding city is not adversely affected.
      4.   Any open burning shall be constantly attended until the fire is
extinguished. At least one portable fire extinguisher with a minimum 4-
A rating, two (2) portable fire extinguishers with a minimum 2-A rating each,
or other approved on site fire extinguishing equipment, such as dirt, sand,
water barrel, garden hose or water truck, shall be available for immediate
utilization.
      5.   Distances from any oil and gas well locations. The minimum distance
for open burning from oil and gas wells will be one thousand feet (1,000'),
unless a risk analysis is performed and approved by the oil and gas leaseholder
and the fire marshal's or fire inspector's office.
      6.   For burning piles or areas in excess of five feet (5') in height and
five feet (5') in width on any side, distances from any electric and overhead
utilities shall be a minimum of one hundred fifty feet (150'). For burning
piles or areas less than five feet (5') in height and five feet (5') in width
on any side or within a container of less than five feet (5') in height or
width, distance from any electric or overhead utility shall be at least twenty
five feet (25').
      7.   For burning piles or areas in excess of five feet (5') in height and
five feet (5') in width on any side, distances from any public roadway must be
at least three hundred feet (300'). Permission to burn shall be obtained each
day before burning is to take place. To receive permission to burn on any given
day, between the hours of eight o'clock (8:00) A.M. and sunset, the applicant
must contact the fire marshal's or fire inspector's office prior to commencing
the burning. If burning is to take place between sunrise and eight o'clock (8:
00) A.M., the permit holder must contact the fire marshal's or fire inspector's
office the day before, during office hours to receive permission for the
following morning.
For burning piles or areas less than five feet (5') in height and five feet
(5') in width on any side or within a container of less than five feet (5') in
height or width, distances from roadways or structures must be fifty feet
(50'), unless permission is granted by fire marshal for approved container
burning within up to fifteen feet (15') of a roadway or structure. Permission
to burn shall be obtained each day before burning is to take place. To receive
permission to burn on any given day, between the hours of eight o'clock (8:00)
A.M. and sunset, the applicant must contact the fire marshal's or fire
inspector's office prior to commencing the burning.
      8.   The fire department shall order the extinguishment of any open
burning that creates or adds to a hazardous or objectionable situation. Permit
holders are required to extinguish the fire upon the order of the fire
department or if the fire escapes the confined area of the burn pile or
container. Failure of a permit holder to extinguish a fire will result in the
fire department extinguishing the fire, at the permit holder's expense at a
rate currently set for fire runs outside of the city limit.
      9.   Wind speed must be less than ten (10) miles per hour and the ceiling
has to be a minimum of a 4, or one thousand (1,000) to three thousand feet
(3,000'), as indicated by the national weather service.
      10.   The burn permit site and the materials to be burned are subject to
inspection at any time during the thirty (30) day permit period by any officer
of the Okmulgee fire department.
   B.   The risk analysis shall be presented in written form for review to the
oil and gas leaseholder and the fire marshal's or fire inspector's office. If
the risk analysis states that a minimal hazard exists, then the minimum
distance can be reduced to five hundred feet (500'). The risk analysis should
state any requirements on the burning or site conditions for the burn permit
holder. The risk analysis shall be conducted by a qualified company or person
(s) and be approved in writing by a company representative for the oil well
site affected.
   C.   The risk analysis may be performed by the following person(s):
      1.   Field operations and safety coordinator for the oil company
affected, if trained in fire behavior/prevention.
      2.   Person or persons trained and certified by a nationally recognized
independent organization accredited in fire behavior/prevention.
      3.   A private fire protection engineer.
      4.   Person(s) trained in hazardous materials operations. (Ord. 2082,
2016)
8.70.050: PERMITS REQUIRED:
The following burning activities require a permit from the fire marshal's or
fire inspector's office:
   A.   Bonfires.
   B.   Campfires.
   C.   Ceremonial fires.
   D.   Clearing land for construction.
   E.   Prevention or control of disease or pests.
   F.   Fire department training.
   G.   Elimination of hazards.
   H.   Maintenance of agricultural and land parcels five (5) acres or greater.
(Ord. 1903 § 1, 2007)
8.70.060: PERMIT FEES:
No fee shall be charged for fires set for the training of public firefighters,
whether for paid or volunteer departments. The fee for burn permits shall be
set by the city manager for:
   A.   Bonfires, campfires, or ceremonial fires.
   B.   Land clearing operations for the specific purpose of clearing land for
construction, and an additional three hundred fifty dollar ($350.00) deposit
shall be paid, against which the fire marshal's or fire inspector's office will
charge time for responding to complaints on said burn.
   C.   Prevention or control of disease or pests, the elimination of hazards,
or the maintenance of agricultural and land parcels five (5) acres or greater.
(Ord. 1903 § 1, 2007)
8.70.070: ACQUIRING A PERMIT:
   A.   A permit must be obtained from the fire marshal's or fire inspector's
office.
   B.   Applications for permits shall be submitted to the fire marshal's or
fire inspector's office a minimum of one week (7 days) prior to the desired
date of burning, during regular business hours.
   C.   All permits shall be requested by and issued to the owner, or the agent
of the owner, of the land upon which the open burning is to take place.
Individuals representing themselves as an "agent of the owner" shall have
sufficient written documentation.
   D.   Permits shall be good for a period of thirty (30) days. However, the
fire marshal's or fire inspector's office may extend the period for an
additional thirty (30) days, if in the opinion of the fire marshal's or fire
inspector's office there was not an adequate number of days to accomplish the
burning for which the permit was issued. (Ord. 1903 § 1, 2007)
8.70.075: FREE BURN PERMIT:
All persons and organizations participating in the designated "Keep Okmulgee
Beautiful Week" will be allowed to apply for a burn permit at no charge. All
persons applying for a permit shall be required to conform to all rules and
regulations in this title. Dates for the event will be determined by the city
of Okmulgee on an annual basis. (Ord. 2056, 2015)
8.70.080: BURN PERMIT REVOCATION:
The fire department shall retain the authority to revoke any burn permit at any
time due to weather conditions, excessive and justifiable complaints,
noncompliance with this chapter, and any time it is deemed in the best interest
of the city of Okmulgee. Permit fees will be returned in cases where the
revocation is based on conditions outside the control of the owner or agent of
the owner. Any person in possession of a burn permit which has been revoked
shall be entitled to a postdeprivation hearing before the city manager or a
designee, to determine whether or not the conditions causing the revocation
have been corrected, or if additional safeguards may be adequate to allow the
burn at a later date. (Ord. 1903 § 1, 2007)
8.70.090: VIOLATION; PENALTIES:
It is an offense to fail to comply with any of the provisions of this chapter,
and on conviction shall be punishable as set forth in section
1.12.010 of this code. (Ord. 1903 § 1, 2007)
8.70.100: RELATION TO THE INTERNATIONAL FIRE CODE 1 :
This chapter shall be interpreted as an amendment to and in addition to the
requirements of section 308 of the international fire code. (Ord. 2043, 2014:
Ord. 1903 § 1, 2007)

1 1. See also
  chapter 8.32 of this title.
CHAPTER 8.74
SMOKING IN PUBLIC PLACES AND INDOOR WORKPLACES
SECTION:
8.74.010: Definitions
8.74.020: Smoking In Certain Places; Exemptions
8.74.030: Measures To Prevent Smoking In Public Places
8.74.040: Penalties
8.74.050: Use Of Tobacco On Or Within Public Property Prohibited
8.74.010: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this chapter:
EDUCATIONAL FACILITY: A building owned, leased or under the control of a public
or private school system, college or university.
HEALTH FACILITY: An entity which provides health services, including, but not
limited to, hospitals, nursing homes, long term care facilities, kidney disease
treatment centers, health maintenance organizations and ambulatory treatment
centers.
INDOOR WORKPLACE: Any indoor place of employment or employment type service for
or at the request of another individual or individuals, or any public or
private entity, whether part time or full time and whether for compensation or
not. Such services shall include, without limitation, any service performed by
an owner, employee, independent contractor, agent, partner, proprietor,
manager, officer, director, apprentice, trainee, associate, servant or
volunteer. An indoor workplace includes work areas, employee lounges,
restrooms, conference rooms, classrooms, employee cafeterias, hallways, any
other spaces used or visited by employees, and all space between a floor and
ceiling that is predominantly or totally enclosed by walls or windows,
regardless of doors, doorways, open or closed windows, stairways, or the like.
The provisions of this definition shall apply to such indoor workplace at any
given time, whether or not work is being performed.
MEETING: As defined in the Oklahoma open meeting act.
PUBLIC BODY: As defined in the Oklahoma open meeting act.
PUBLIC PLACE: Any enclosed indoor area where individuals other than employees
are invited or permitted.
RESTAURANT: Any eating establishment regardless of seating capacity.
SMOKING: The carrying by a person of a lighted cigar, cigarette, pipe or other
lighted smoking device; such device to include, but not be limited to,
electronic cigarettes or comparable devices used to deliver nicotine or
comparable products through inhalation.
STAND ALONE BAR, STAND ALONE TAVERN, AND CIGAR BAR: An establishment that
derives more than sixty percent (60%) of its gross receipts, subject to
verification by competent authority, from the sale of alcoholic beverages and
low point beer and no person under twenty one (21) years of age is admitted,
except for members of a musical band employed or hired as provided in 37
Oklahoma Statutes section 537, subsection B, paragraph 2 and that is not
located within, and does not share any common entryway or common indoor area
with, any other enclosed indoor workplace, including a restaurant. (Ord. 2023,
2014: Ord. 1924 § 1, 2008)
8.74.020: SMOKING IN CERTAIN PLACES; EXEMPTIONS:
   A.   Except as specifically provided in the smoking in public places and
indoor workplaces act, no person shall smoke in a public place, in any part of
a zoo to which the public may be admitted, whether indoors or outdoors, in an
indoor workplace, in any vehicle providing public transportation, at a meeting
of a public body, in a nursing facility licensed pursuant to the nursing home
care act, or in a childcare facility licensed pursuant to the Oklahoma child
care facilities licensing act. A nursing facility licensed pursuant to the
nursing home care act may designate smoking rooms for residents and their
guests. Such rooms shall be fully enclosed, directly exhausted to the outside,
and shall be under negative air pressure so that no smoke can escape when a
door is opened and no air is recirculated to nonsmoking areas of the building.
   B.   1. Except as otherwise provided in this subsection B, an educational
facility which offers an early childhood education program or in which children
in grades kindergarten through 12 are educated shall prohibit smoking, the use
of snuff, chewing tobacco or any other form of tobacco product in the buildings
and on the grounds of the facility by all persons including, but not limited
to, full time, part time, and contract employees, during the hours of seven
o'clock (7:00) A.M. to four o'clock (4:00) P.M., during the school session, or
when class or any program established for students is in session.
      2.   Career and technology centers may designate smoking areas outside of
buildings, away from general traffic areas and completely out of sight of
children under eighteen (18) years of age, for use by adults attending training
courses, sessions, meetings or seminars.
      3.   An educational facility may designate smoking areas outside the
buildings for the use of adults during certain activities or functions,
including, but not limited to, athletic contests.
   C.   Nothing in this section shall be construed to prohibit educational
facilities from having more restrictive policies regarding smoking and the use
of other tobacco products in the buildings or on the grounds of the facility.
   D.   A private residence is not a "public place" within the meaning of the
smoking in public places and indoor workplaces act except that areas in a
private residence that are used as a licensed childcare facility during hours
of operation are "public places" within the meaning of the smoking in public
places and indoor workplaces act.
   E.   Smoking is prohibited on all real property owned in fee by the city,
including all public parks and playgrounds, all public buildings and all public
parking lots. This shall not be interpreted to prohibit smoking on the
easements of the city such as streets and sidewalks which are immediately
adjacent to private property. Smoking is prohibited on any street or the
sidewalk which is completely within a public park or playground, or is
immediately contiguous to a public building or public parking lot. Smoking is
also prohibited within all public vehicles and within all public buildings,
which are owned by the city or any of its agencies, trusts, and
instrumentalities.
   F.   An employer not otherwise restricted from doing so may elect to provide
smoking rooms where no work is performed except for cleaning and maintenance
during the time the room is not in use for smoking, provided each smoking room
is fully enclosed and exhausted directly to the outside in such manner that no
smoke can drift or circulate into a nonsmoking area. No exhaust from a smoking
room shall be located within fifteen feet (15') of any entrance, exit or air
intake. If smoking is to be permitted in any space exempted in subsection G of
this section or in a smoking room pursuant to subsection H of this section,
such smoking space must either occupy the entire enclosed indoor space or, if
it shares the enclosed space with any nonsmoking areas, the smoking space shall
be fully enclosed, exhausted directly to the outside with no air from the
smoking space circulated to any nonsmoking area, and under negative air
pressure so that no smoke can drift or circulate into a nonsmoking area when a
door to an adjacent nonsmoking area is opened. Air from a smoking room shall
not be exhausted within fifteen feet (15') of any entrance, exit or air intake.
   G.   This section shall not prohibit smoking in:
      1.   Stand alone bars, stand alone taverns or cigar bars;
      2.   The room or rooms where licensed charitable bingo games are being
operated, but only during the hours of operation of such games;
      3.   Up to twenty five percent (25%) of the guestrooms at a hotel or
other lodging establishment;
      4.   Retail tobacco stores predominantly engaged in the sale of tobacco
products and accessories and in which the sale of other products is merely
incidental and in which no food or beverage is sold or served for consumption
on the premises;
      5.   Workplaces where only the owner or operator of the workplace, or the
immediate family of the owner or operator, performs any work in the workplace,
and the workplace has only incidental public access;
      6.   Workplaces occupied exclusively by one or more smokers, if the
workplace has only incidental public access. "Incidental public access" means
that a place of business has only an occasional person, who is not an employee,
present at the business to transact business or make a delivery. It does not
include businesses that depend on walk in customers for any part of their
business;
      7.   Private offices occupied exclusively by one or more smokers;
      8.   Workplaces within private residences, except that smoking shall not
be allowed inside any private residence that is used as a licensed childcare
facility during hours of operation;
      9.   A facility operated by a post or organization of past or present
members of the armed forces of the United States which is exempt from taxation
pursuant to section 501(c)(8), 501(c)(10) or 501(c)(19) of the internal revenue
code, 26 USC section 501(c)(8), 501(c)(10) or 501(c)(19), when such facility is
utilized exclusively by its members and their families and for the conduct of
post or organization nonprofit operations except during an event or activity
which is open to the public;
      10.   Any outdoor seating area of a restaurant; provided, smoking shall
not be allowed within fifteen feet (15') of any exterior public doorway or any
air intake of a restaurant; and
      11.   Medical research or treatment centers, if smoking is integral to
the research or treatment.
   H.   Restaurants shall be totally nonsmoking or may provide nonsmoking areas
and designated smoking rooms. Food and beverage may be served in such
designated smoking rooms which shall be in a location which is fully enclosed,
directly exhausted to the outside, under negative air pressure so smoke cannot
escape when a door is opened, and no air is recirculated to nonsmoking areas of
the building. No exhaust from such room shall be located within twenty five
feet (25') of any entrance, exit or air intake. Such room shall be subject to
verification for compliance with the provisions of this subsection by the state
department of health. (Ord. 2023, 2014: Ord. 1924 § 1, 2008)
8.74.030: MEASURES TO PREVENT SMOKING IN PUBLIC PLACES:
The state or local governmental agency or the person who owns or operates a
public place shall, at a minimum, do the following in order to prevent smoking
in public places:
   A.   Post signs at entrances to places where smoking is prohibited which
state that smoking is prohibited or that the indoor environment is free of
tobacco smoke; and
   B.   Ask smokers to refrain from smoking upon observation of anyone
violating the provisions of this act. (Ord. 1924 § 1, 2008)
8.74.040: PENALTIES:
When a person is convicted of violating any portion of this chapter, the
municipal court shall impose a fine of not more than fifty dollars ($50.00) for
the first offense within a one year period, one hundred dollars ($100.00) for
the second offense within a one year period, and two hundred dollars ($200.00)
for a third or subsequent offense within a one year period. Each day a
violation is continuing shall constitute a separate offense. (Ord. 1924 § 1,
2008)
8.74.050: USE OF TOBACCO ON OR WITHIN PUBLIC PROPERTY PROHIBITED:
The use of tobacco in any form in which it is chewed or ingested is prohibited
on all real property owned in fee by the city, including all public parks and
playgrounds, all public buildings and all public parking lots. The use of
tobacco in any form in which it is chewed or ingested is also prohibited within
all public vehicles and within all public buildings, which are owned by the
city or any of its agencies, trusts, and instrumentalities. The city should
promptly post appropriate signage on all city owned buildings and parks, but
the presence of signage is not a prerequisite to enforcement of this section.
(Ord. 2023, 2014)
CHAPTER 8.75
GRAFFITI REMEDIATION
SECTION:
8.75.000: Legislative Intent
8.75.010: Definitions
8.75.020: Declaration Of Nuisance
8.75.030: Graffiti Prohibited
8.75.040: Graffiti Removal Standards
8.75.050: Notice To Owner
8.75.060: Abatement Plan
8.75.070: Consent By Owner
8.75.080: Appeals
8.75.090: Appeals To The City Council
8.75.100: Statement Of Cost To Be Sent (Rep. by Ord. 2131, 2020)
8.75.110: Cost To Be Determined
8.75.120: Enforcement
8.75.130: Administrative Fees (Rep. by Ord. 2131, 2020)
8.75.140: Penalty
8.75.000: LEGISLATIVE INTENT:
The purpose of this chapter is to provide a procedure for removal of graffiti
from surfaces on public or private property in order to reduce blight and
deterioration within the incorporated areas of the city and to protect the
public health and safety. The city council hereby makes the following findings:
   A.   Unsightly graffiti on public and private property within the city is
detrimental to the beauty of our community;
   B.   Graffiti on public and private property within the city is often
related to criminal street gang activity, with graffiti being used to convey
information to gang members and mark gang territory;
   C.   Gang related graffiti often provides a catalyst for gang related
criminal violence within the city;
   D.   Gang related graffiti constitutes a growing blight on and a substantial
detriment to the health and safety of the residents of our community;
   E.   Even when graffiti is not gang related, it still contributes to the
deterioration of property values in the area; and
   F.   By reason of the foregoing findings, graffiti constitutes a public
nuisance to our community. (Ord. 2034, 2014)
8.75.010: DEFINITIONS:
   A.   For the purposes stated in section
8.75.000 of this chapter:
   GRAFFITI: Any unauthorized inscription, word, figure, picture, or design
that is sprayed, marked, posted, pasted or otherwise affixed, drawn, or painted
on any surface of public or private property. Graffiti shall not mean a sign as
defined in this code or the ordinances of the city. This chapter shall not be
construed to prohibit easily removable chalk markings on public sidewalks and
streets such as the markings used in connection with traditional children's
games. This chapter shall not be construed to prohibit commercial advertising
on commercial property or artistic murals, either of which are actually
commissioned in advance by the owner of the property; provided that the
existence of such a commission is an affirmative defense of the owner in any
graffiti abatement action under this chapter.
   RESPONSIBLE PERSON: Person responsible for causing or maintaining a public
nuisance or a violation of this code or applicable state codes. The term
includes, but is not limited to, a property owner, tenant, person with a legal
interest in real property or person in possession of real property. (Ord. 2034,
2014)
8.75.020: DECLARATION OF NUISANCE:
   A.   The council hereby declares that graffiti on public or private property
within the city constitutes a public nuisance to the detriment of the city and
its inhabitants and visitors. (Ord. 2034, 2014)
8.75.030: GRAFFITI PROHIBITED:
   A.   To the extent not otherwise provided for by state law, it is unlawful
for any person to place graffiti upon any public or private property within the
city of Okmulgee.
   B.   It is unlawful for any responsible person to maintain graffiti that has
been placed upon any surface within that person's control, possession, or
ownership when the graffiti is visible from a public street, property or right
of way.
   C.   It is unlawful for any responsible person to allow graffiti to remain
for more than twenty (20) days upon any surface within that person's control,
possession, or ownership when the graffiti is visible from a public street,
property or right of way after being notified by the city that such graffiti
exists. (Ord. 2034, 2014)
8.75.040: GRAFFITI REMOVAL STANDARDS:
   A.   When graffiti is painted over, the color used to paint over the
graffiti shall be similar to the original color of the surface, or the surface
shall be completely repainted with a new color which is aesthetically
compatible with existing colors and architecture.
   B.   The removal shall not leave shadows and shall not follow the pattern of
the graffiti such that letters or similar shapes remain apparent on the surface
after graffiti markings have been removed.
   C.   If the area is heavily covered with graffiti, the entire surface is to
be repainted.
   D.   Graffiti shall be removed or covered completely in a manner that
renders it inconspicuous. (Ord. 2034, 2014)
8.75.050: NOTICE TO OWNER:
   A.   The code enforcement officer may cause property within the municipal
limits to be cleaned of graffiti in accordance with the following procedure:
      1.   At least twenty (20) days' notice shall be given to the owner of the
property by mail at the address shown by the current year's tax rolls in the
county treasurer's office: and notice, if applicable, shall be given to the
tenant inhabiting the property; such notices shall be given before the Code
Enforcement Officer takes action. The notice shall order the property owner to
abate the graffiti as defined in section
8.75.040 of this chapter, and the notice shall further state that unless such
work is performed within twenty (20) days of the date of the notice the work
shall be done by the City of Okmulgee Employees or agents of the City are
granted the right of entry on the property for the abatement of graffiti and
performance of the necessary duties as a governmental function of the City of
Okmulgee, so long as these employees or agents do not have to remove a locked
gate or enter an enclosed structure.
      2.   At the time of mailing of notice to the property owner and tenant
(if applicable), the code enforcement officer shall obtain a receipt of mailing
from the postal service, which receipt shall indicate the date of mailing and
the name and address of the intended recipient.
      3.   Notice shall be given by posting a copy of the notice on the
property at least one time not less than twenty (20) days prior to any action
by the municipality. (Ord. 2034, 2014; amd. Ord. 2131, 2020)
8.75.060: ABATEMENT PLAN:
The owner of the property and the code enforcement officer may agree to an
abatement plan within ten (10) days from the date of the code enforcement
officer's notice. Such abatement plan shall be in writing, signed and dated by
the owner of the property and the code enforcement officer. Should any owner
fail to comply with an abatement plan and it is beyond the twenty (20) day
notice, the city of Okmulgee shall have the right to abate the property without
further notice to the owner. Employees or agents of the city shall have right
of entry to abate the property. (Ord. 2034, 2014)
8.75.070: CONSENT BY OWNER:
The owner of the property may give written consent to the city authorizing the
abatement of graffiti. By giving written consent, the owner waives the owner's
right to any notice or appeal hearing by the city of Okmulgee. (Ord. 2034,
2014)
8.75.080: APPEALS:
   A.   Any property owner aggrieved by any notice or order of the city of
Okmulgee may request a hearing by the city council. Such hearing request shall
be taken within ten (10) days from the date of the administrative officer's
notice by filing with the city clerk a written request for hearing specifying
the grounds thereof. Failure to request a hearing within the ten (10) day
period will act as a waiver of the property owner's right to a hearing by the
city council, and may result in the city of Okmulgee abating the property.
   B.   A request for hearing stays all further actions concerning graffiti on
that property by the code enforcement officer.
   C.   The city council shall hear the matter and receive information thereon,
including anything which may be presented by the owner of the premises,
personally or by agent or attorney. The city council may affirm, reverse or
modify the notice or order of the code enforcement officer.
   D.   If the city council determines that the condition specified in section
8.75.030 of this chapter exists upon such premises, it shall order the property
to be cleaned of any graffiti necessary to abate the condition found to exist.
   E.   Upon a finding that the condition of the property constitutes a
detriment or hazard, and that the property would be benefited by the removal of
such conditions, the employees or agents of the City of Okmulgee are granted
the right of entry on the property for the abatement of graffiti and
performance of the necessary duties as a governmental function of the City of
Okmulgee. (Ord. 2034, 2014; amd. Ord. 2131, 2020)
8.75.090: APPEALS TO THE CITY COUNCIL:
After the hearing and appeal time has expired or the City Council has entered
its order, the work ordered to be performed under Section
8.75.040 of this chapter may be done by the employees of this city, or it may
be let by contract to the lowest and best bidder, in the manner for letting
other contracts by public bid. (Ord. 2034, 2014; amd. Ord. 2131, 2020)
8.75.100: REPEALED:
Repealed by Ord. 2131, 2020
8.75.110: COST TO BE DETERMINED:
The City shall determine the actual cost of such cleaning and mowing and any
other expenses as may be necessary in connection therewith, including the cost
of notice and mailing, but ultimately all graffiti abatements are to be
completed at the expense of the City of Okmulgee. (Ord. 2034, 2014; amd. Ord.
2131, 2020)
8.75.120: ENFORCEMENT:
The code enforcement officer shall enforce this chapter and shall have the
authority to issue citations to any person, firm, or corporation, which
violates, in any manner, this chapter. (Ord. 2034, 2014)
8.75.130: REPEALED:
Repealed by Ord. 2131, 2020
8.75.140: PENALTY:
   A.   Any person, firm or corporation who is the owner or otherwise in
possession or control of property located within the city limits who violates
any of the provisions of this chapter shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor
and shall be punishable by fines as determined by the municipal judge as
described in section
1.12.010 of this code. Each day that a violation exists shall constitute a
separate violation. (Ord. 2034, 2014)
