13.04.010: UTILITY BILLING OFFICE, COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT DEPARTMENT, AND WATER
AND SEWER DEPARTMENT; DUTIES:
The utility billing office under the direction of the utility billing
supervisor shall have responsibility for all ordinary financial operations of
city utilities as a business enterprise related to billing for monthly utility
services. The community development department shall have responsibility for
all financial operations of the city utilities as to the collection of impact
fees and fees for taps, materials costs, and line extensions when cost is borne
by the ordinary financial operations of the utility systems. Each office or
department shall also be responsible for the keeping of proper accounts. The
water and sewer department of public works shall have responsibility for all
functions regarding the control, operation, repair, maintenance, and
improvement of the physical plant of the utility systems. The city manager
shall regulate the interrelationships among the utility billing office, the
community development department, and the water and sewer department insofar as
it is not regulated by ordinance. (Ord. 2017, 2014)
13.04.020: SERVICE CONNECTIONS; APPLICATION PROCEDURE:
Any person desiring to have a premises connected with the water supply system
of the city shall make application therefor at the utility billing office upon
a form to be furnished for that purpose. The application shall contain the
description of the premises where such water is to be used, shall be signed by
the person desiring water service or his duly authorized agent, shall be filed
in the utility billing office, and shall state the number of "family living
units" to be serviced by said connection as said term is defined by section
13.04.270 of this chapter. There shall be no temporary connections made. There
shall be a transfer fee assessed and paid at time of transfer in the amount of
twenty dollars ($20.00) for each transfer of service. (Ord. 1977, 2011)
13.04.030: WATER SERVICE CONTRACT PROVISIONS:
The application for water service shall contain a contract on the part of the
person making the application:
   A.   To pay for the water consumed at the rate prescribed by ordinance at
the time the water is consumed;
   B.   To recognize the right of the city to change the rate by ordinance or
council resolution at any time;
   C.   To recognize the right of the city temporarily to discontinue water
service at any time without notice to the consumer, to install, repair or
remove a water meter or for any other proper cause;
   D.   Stating that the contract is subject to all the ordinances in effect at
the time of making the contract and as they may be amended as to the effective
date thereafter;
   E.   Stating that the city shall not be responsible for any damage by water
or other cause resulting from defective plumbing or appliances, and that the
fact that an agent of the city has inspected plumbing or appliances shall not
be pleaded as a basis for recovery in case of damage to the premises from
defective plumbing or appliances installed by the owner or occupant of such
premises;
   F.   Providing that the city shall not be liable for damages resulting from
the interruption or failure of the supply of water, regardless of the cause
thereof; and that such failure for any reasonable period of time shall not be
held to constitute a breach of contract on the part of the city nor relieve the
consumer from performing the obligations of his contract;
   G.   Providing that the deposit required by section
13.04.040 of this chapter, as may be amended, or so much thereof as may be
necessary, may be retained by the city and applied by the city on any unpaid
"utility charge" as that term is defined in section
13.04.280 of this chapter; and providing further that unless the water deposit
is claimed by the consumer within six (6) months after the account is no longer
furnished water by the city, then the consumer forfeits all right, title or
interest in and to the same deposit and the same shall become the sole property
of the city. (Ord. 1977, 2011)
13.04.040: DEPOSITS:
At the time of making application and signing the contract for water service,
the applicant shall deposit with the water office, the following sums:
   A.   For a residence, house, apartment or office, the sum of one hundred
dollars ($100.00) if the water account is in the name of the owner of said
premises; if the water account is in the name of a person other than the owner
of said premises, the sum of one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00);
   B.   For any commercial establishment, other than an office, private club,
beer hall or place of amusement, the sum of one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00)
or three (3) month average of previous occupant's usage;
   C.   For a private club, beer hall or place of amusement, the sum of two
hundred dollars ($200.00);
   D.   For an industrial user an amount equal to ten percent (10%) of the
estimated annual water bill of said user as determined by the city manager;
   E.   Notwithstanding any other provision contained in this title, if the
consumer applying for an account has previously held an account with the city,
and said applicant has in the past established a bad credit history with the
city by having on three (3) occasions either attempted to pay the account with
a check which was dishonored by the bank on which it was drawn, or has not paid
the account by the due date of payment, or has moved without making a final
payment at a previous location, then the city shall require the payment of all
outstanding balances and bank fees plus the higher of the normal deposit or a
deposit equal to one-fourth (1/4) of the estimated yearly utility charge, as
determined by the utility billing supervisor. Further, if a consumer with an
existing account has established a bad credit history with the city, as above
set forth, said consumer shall be required to increase the existing deposit to
an amount equal to one-fourth (1/4) of the annual utility charge of said
customer, if the amount so computed is greater than the standard deposit
required for said customer, and the failure to pay the increased deposit shall
give the city authority to terminate the water service to such consumer. (Ord.
1977, 2011)
13.04.050: INSTALLATION FEES:
   A.   Standard Installation Of Water Service: Standard installation of water
service shall include a tap on a city water main and installation of an
appropriately sized meter. The water meter shall be placed at a location within
the right of way or easement but outside of the portion of any street, alley,
or driveway devoted to vehicular traffic. Standard installation of water
service includes the typically necessary street cut and street cut repair.
Connection of the private service line for the property to be served to the
water meter is the responsibility of the property owner and must be performed
by a licensed plumber at the property owner's expense.
      1.   Residential Water Service: The fee for standard installation of
residential water service performed by employees of the water and sewer
department shall be as follows:
         a.   Three-fourths inch (3/4") line and meter within the city limits:
One thousand four hundred sixty five dollars ($1,465.00);
         b.   Three-fourths inch (3/4") line and meter outside the city limits:
One thousand six hundred fifteen dollars ($1,615.00);
         c.   One inch (1") line and meter within the city limits: One thousand
five hundred forty dollars ($1,540.00);
         d.   One inch (1") line and meter outside the city limits: One
thousand six hundred ninety dollars ($1,690.00);
         e.   One and one-half inch (11/2") line and meter within the city
limits: One thousand nine hundred seventy dollars ($1,970.00);
         f.   One and one-half inch (11/2") line and meter outside the city
limits: Two thousand one hundred twenty dollars ($2,120.00).
      2.   Nonresidential Water Service: The fee for standard installation of
nonresidential (commercial, industrial, multi- family residential, etc.) water
service performed by employees of the water and sewer department shall be as
follows:
         a.   Three-fourths inch (3/4") line and meter: Same fee as residential
installation above;
         b.   One inch (1") line and meter: Same fee as residential
installation above;
         c.   One and one-half inch (11/2") line and meter: Two thousand six
hundred seventy dollars ($2,670.00);
         d.   Two inch (2") line and meter: Three thousand four hundred thirty
five dollars ($3,435.00);
         e.   Three inch (3") line and meter: Four thousand seven hundred forty
dollars ($4,740.00);
         f.   Four inch (4") line and meter: Six thousand five hundred thirty
dollars ($6,530.00);
         g.   Five inch (5") line and meter: Six thousand eight hundred thirty
dollars ($6,830.00);
         h.   Six inch (6") line and meter: Seven thousand eight hundred sixty
dollars ($7,860.00);
         i.   Eight inch (8") line and meter: Eight thousand three hundred ten
dollars ($8,310.00);
         j.   Larger than eight inch (8") meter and line: Actual cost.
      3.   Two Water Service Lines: When water service installation is
requested for the concurrent installation of two (2) water service lines each
of which is one inch (1") or less in size and both are to serve a single
location on a single property, the fee for such dual service line installation
shall be as follows:
         a.   Two (2) 3/4-inch water service lines and meters: Two thousand two
hundred sixty three dollars ($2,263.00).
         b.   One 3/4-inch water service line and meter and one 1-inch water
service line and meter: Two thousand three hundred thirty nine dollars
($2,339.00).
         c.   Two (2) 1-inch water service lines and meters: Two thousand four
hundred eighty nine dollars ($2,489.00).
      4.   CBD District Installation Fees For Multi-Family Redevelopment
Projects: Due to the significant number of vacant buildings, and the number of
multi-story buildings with activity solely on the ground floor, the city
desires to provide incentives to redevelop the various buildings in the CBD
zoning district. This incentive should aid the city in reducing blight in the
CBD district, provide expanded and new uses for the existing structures,
support new construction or remodeling of these buildings in order to adapt
them for more productive uses, and support various economic redevelopment
efforts in the historic portions of the downtown area. Therefore, the city
manager is hereby authorized to negotiate a discount to be applied in the form
of a partial refund of the installation fee for development and redevelopment
of the buildings in the CBD zoning district on the following conditions:
         a.   For those installations converting one or more upper stories of
CBD buildings into apartments which will have meter service, the discount
refund of part of the service fee for each such residential service must not
exceed one-half (1/2) of the service fee set forth in subsection A2 of this
section for multi-family residential;
         b.   The city manager may also negotiate for a reduced bond on the
proposed sidewalk cut required under section
12.04.010 of this code in an amount adequate to pay the city for the
anticipated costs of sidewalk repair by city crews, and in an amount not to be
less than one thousand two hundred dollars ($1,200.00);
         c.   All such meter service for such multi-family residential units
must be located in a single vault serving a single building;
         d.   Each such meter service must be for a line of three inches (3")
or less;
         e.   All street cuts, sidewalk cuts, and similar demolition must be
performed by the city to a level and quality meeting or exceeding city
standards, and the sidewalk bond shall be used to pay for the city's repair of
the sidewalk, including equipment, labor and materials;
         f.   All service fees under subsection A2 of this section must be paid
in full, and the negotiated discount shall then be returned to the developer
following inspection and approval by the city of the meter vault, sidewalk
repairs and street repairs.
   B.   Installation In Excess Of Normal Requirements: In the event the
installation of water service requires material, equipment, and labor above
normal requirements, the person, firm or corporation requesting such service
shall be required to pay, in addition to the regular installation fee, the full
cost of the labor, equipment, and material which is required over and above
normal installation requirements, and shall further be required to pay an
additional amount equal to ten percent (10%) of said additional material,
equipment, and labor cost to cover the expense of supervision necessitated by
said installation.
   C.   Contract Installation Of Water Services And Water Lines:
      1.   Installation of water service for major development projects may be
accomplished by contract when approved by both the water and sewer department
supervisor and the public works director. In such cases, installation of the
water service line and meter can/box/vault as well as any necessary street
repairs must comply with city of Okmulgee design standards. Contract work
performed must be inspected and accepted by the water and sewer department
supervisor or his designated representative. The fee for inspection of a
service line installation shall be as follows:
         a.   Three-fourths inch (3/4") to two inch (2") water service
installation: Twenty five dollars ($25.00) per water service installed.
         b.   Any water service installation larger than two inches (2"): Two
hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) per water service installed.
      2.   When water service installation is performed by contract, an order
for water meter installation only shall be placed with the community
development department for required water meters. The installed water meter(s)
remains the property of the city of Okmulgee. The fee charged for water meter
installation only shall be as follows:
         a.   Residential (single-family unit):
            (1)   Three-fourths inch (3/4") meter: Two hundred eighty five
dollars ($285.00);
            (2)   One inch (1") meter: Three hundred forty five dollars
($345.00);
            (3)   One and one-half inch (11/2") meter: Five hundred seventy
five dollars ($575.00).
         b.   Nonresidential (commercial, industrial, multi-family residential,
etc.):
            (1)   Three-fourths inch (3/4") meter: Two hundred eighty five
dollars ($285.00);
            (2)   One inch (1") meter: Three hundred forty five dollars
($345.00);
            (3)   One and one-half inch (11/2") meter: One thousand two hundred
fifty five dollars ($1,255.00);
            (4)   Two inch (2") meter: One thousand nine hundred fifty dollars
($1,950.00);
            (5)   Three inch (3") meter: Two thousand four hundred thirty
dollars ($2,430.00);
            (6)   Four inch (4") meter: Four thousand one hundred ten dollars
($4,110.00);
            (7)   Five inch (5") meter: Four thousand one hundred ten dollars
($4,110.00);
            (8)   Six inch (6") meter: Five thousand fifty five dollars
($5,055.00);
            (9)   Larger than six inch (6") meter: Actual cost of meter.
      3.   Construction of water lines by contract must receive advance
authorization by the water and sewer department supervisor and the public works
director and must be inspected and have work accepted by the water and sewer
department supervisor or his designated representative. Contractors performing
such construction must comply with all city of Okmulgee design standards and
all Oklahoma department of environmental quality (ODEQ) requirements. The fee
for city inspection of water line construction shall be one dollar twenty cents
($1.20) per linear foot with a minimum fee of two hundred fifty dollars
($250.00).
   D.   Approval Needed For Installation Of Water Service Outside City Limits:
The city manager or his designee must approve the installation of all water
service installed outside and beyond the incorporated limits of the city prior
to the installation of the water service by the water and sewer department of
the city.
   E.   Fire Suppression Sprinkler System Fee: The fee for inspection of newly
installed or modified fire suppression sprinkler systems shall be two hundred
dollars ($200.00).
   F.   Rate Increases: Hereafter, rate increases shall be made effective by
the adoption of a resolution, and may not be changed more often than
semiannually. (Ord. 2047, 2014: Ord. 2041, 2014: Ord. 1981, 2011: Ord. 1977,
2011)
13.04.060: INSTALLATION OF DEDUCT WATER METERS:
Installation of deduct water meters may be requested by account holders whose
primary meter is larger than three-fourths inch (3/4"). Such water meters are
installed for the purpose of deducting from the total amount of water passing
through the primary meter that portion which is utilized for special purposes
(e.g., landscape irrigation systems, commodity production, fire protection,
etc.) that do not contribute to the sanitary sewer system load. That deduction
is for the purpose of determining accurately the appropriate amount to be
billed for sanitary sewer service. By requesting the installation of a deduct
water meter, the account holder automatically grants authorization and access
for city employees to inspect and read the deduct water meter. When approved by
the city manager, a deduct water meter may be installed in accordance with city
standards by the account holder at the account holder's expense. That meter
shall remain the property of the installing account holder. (Ord. 1977, 2011)
13.04.070: REINSTALLATION CHARGE POLICY:
Notwithstanding any language to the contrary in section
13.04.050 of this chapter, in all cases where the city has been paid for water
service installation to a given specifically designated property, and
thereafter it becomes necessary by inadequacies of the main to which the
connection is made, or increased use of water, or inadequacy of original
installation to reinstall water services to that property while disconnecting
the original service, then and in that event, the consumer desiring the change
in point of service for water shall make application to the department of
community development. The consumer shall be charged one-half (1/2) the normal
installation fee for water service installation of the size required, and any
remaining expenses shall be borne by the city as consideration for the benefits
that may accrue to the city. (Ord. 1977, 2011)
13.04.080: RELOCATION OF WATER METER:
Should it become necessary to relocate a water meter because of exposure of the
meter to traffic damage, conflict with new construction, or any other valid
reason, the expense of the relocation shall be borne as described below:
   A.   If the meter relocation is at the request of and for the benefit of the
serviced property owner alone, the cost, equal to the established tapping fee
for that size meter, shall be borne entirely by the requesting property owner.
   B.   If the meter relocation is initiated at the request of city staff for
the primary benefit of the city, the cost shall be borne entirely by the city.
   C.   If the meter relocation, regardless of the initiator of the request,
clearly provides a substantial benefit to both the affected property owner and
the city, the cost of the relocation shall be shared equally by the property
owner and the city. (Ord. 1977, 2011)
13.04.090: ONE SERVICE TO EACH PREMISES:
Other than a separate meter solely for irrigation, no premises shall be allowed
to have more than one service connection unless a special permit therefor shall
be given by the director of public works. Every separate premises supplied by
city water must have its own separate service connection and meter with the
city main; and the premises so supplied must not be allowed to supply water to
any other premises. (Ord. 1977, 2011)
13.04.100: PREVIOUS DEBTS; PAYMENT REQUIRED BEFORE RECONNECTION:
If any water consumer ceases to be a water consumer by reason of moving or
leaving the district where the city has jurisdiction and be indebted to the
city for water in any amount, should the same consumer again become a user of
water or seek again to have a water connection, the utility billing office
shall enforce collection for any sum due the city for water not having been
paid, and shall refuse the connection until all such claims are paid. (Ord.
1977, 2011)
13.04.110: SERVICE LINES; MAINTENANCE:
Water service lines from the city main to the water meter placed in the city
right of way/easement according to standard installation shall be maintained by
and at the expense of the city. (Ord. 1977, 2011)
13.04.120: RESERVED:
(Ord. 1977, 2011)
13.04.130: METERS REQUIRED; PROPERTY OF CITY:
It is unlawful for a plumber or any other person to make a connection to or use
water from the city water system until a meter has been set. All water meters
shall be installed in accordance with city of Okmulgee water meter standards.
All meters shall belong to the city except for those deduct water meters
installed in accordance with section
13.04.060 of this chapter which shall remain the property of the installing
account holder. (Ord. 1977, 2011)
13.04.140: TAMPERING WITH METERS OR WATER SYSTEM APPARATUS:
   A.   In all cases where meters or meter boxes are lost, damaged, or broken
by wilful action or by carelessness or negligence of owners or occupants of
premises, the meters or boxes shall be replaced or repaired at the expense of
the owner or occupant. In case of nonpayment, the water shall be cut off and
will not be turned on until such charges are paid. In the event of a meter
getting out of order or failing to register properly, the consumer shall be
charged on an estimate made by the utility billing supervisor based upon the
average monthly consumption during the last three (3) months when the meter was
in good condition or from what he may consider to be the most reliable data at
his command.
   B.   It is unlawful for any person, unless duly authorized by the supervisor
of the water and sewer department, to disturb, displace, interfere with, cover
up, damage or destroy any water main, water pipe, meter, meter box, machinery,
tool, building, fire hydrant, curb cock, curb box or any other property
belonging to, connected with, or under control of the municipal water supply
system of the city. (Ord. 1977, 2011)
13.04.150: PRIVATE LINES; OWNER RESPONSIBILITY:
All private lines shall be maintained by and at the expense of the owner. When
the water and sewer department notifies the owner that there is a leak in his
private line, the owner shall have the same repaired immediately, and in case
of failure to do so, the water may be cut off until the line has been repaired.
When a new water main is constructed by the city to provide service to existing
account holders, and because of the construction a new water meter is placed to
provide that service, it shall be the responsibility of the account holder to
arrange for connection of his private service line to the newly located meter
at his expense by a licensed plumber. Such connection shall be accomplished
within the time frame determined by the city based upon considerations related
to operation of the city water system. (Ord. 1977, 2011)
13.04.155: PRIVATE LINE SERVICE VALVE; OWNER RESPONSIBILITY:
Each dwelling unit shall be provided with an accessible main shutoff valve by
the property owner or account holder, and such valve shall be located near the
entrance of the water service, and between the city's meter and the nearest
structure served by the water line. This shutoff valve is to be utilized by the
property owner when necessary for plumbing repairs to the dwelling unit.
Failure of the property owner to comply with this requirement will result in a
service charge of forty dollars ($40.00) for each service shutoff performed
within the city's meter box. Failure of the property owner to install an
accessible main shutoff near the entrance of the water service immediately
following an emergency shutoff will result in an additional forty dollars
($40.00) for each subsequent service turnon and turnoff performed by municipal
employees at the property owner's or property resident's request. (Ord. 2009,
2013)
13.04.160: CURB COCK KEYS:
The director of public works may permit any licensed plumber to have a service
key, which he shall keep in his possession and with which he may shut off the
curb cock for the purpose of making repairs on the premises. No person other
than a licensed plumber shall use this key, and plumbers shall leave a curb
cock in the condition in which it was found. (Ord. 1977, 2011)
13.04.170: INSPECTION AUTHORITIES; CREDENTIALS:
   A.   Officers and employees of the water and sewer department and the fire
marshal's office, whose duty it may be to enter upon private premises to make
inspection of pipes and fixtures or attachments used in connection with the
city's water lines, will be provided with a badge, an official city uniform,
and/or other credentials to identify them as officers and employees of the
city. Any city officer or employee so identified shall have free access to the
grounds of any premises supplied with city water under this code, and during
normal business hours to those portions of the structures where water meters or
fire suppression systems are located for the purpose of making any inspection
of a water connection upon the premises. In case any employee is refused
admittance to any premises or is prevented from making such inspection, the
supervisor of the water and sewer department may cause the water to be turned
off from the premises forthwith.
   B.   No person not an officer or employee of the water and sewer department
shall have, wear, or exhibit any badge or credentials of the department. It
shall be the duty of every officer or employee of the water and sewer
department upon resignation or dismissal from the department forthwith to
surrender and deliver to the department at the supervisor's office all badges
and credentials of the department in his possession. (Ord. 1977, 2011)
13.04.180: AUTHORITY TO TURN ON OR SHUT OFF WATER; REQUIREMENTS TO HAVE WATER
RECONNECTED:
When the water service has been shut off from any premises by application or
request of the owner thereof or for the nonpayment of the water bill, including
all charges included thereon, or for any other cause, it shall be unlawful for
any person again to connect such water service except when authorized by the
utility billing supervisor or the city manager. In the event the water service
is connected without authorization, the person so connecting shall be guilty of
an offense against the city, and the city may then shut off the water at the
main or remove a portion of the service connection at the cock; in the event
the city has turned off the water service as in the instance above, then in
that event and before the water service is reinstalled the consumer must pay
all charges prescribed by section
13.04.280 of this chapter as if the water service had been turned off for
nonpayment, including an increase in deposits. (Ord. 1977, 2011)
13.04.190: METER TESTING; CREDIT FOR INACCURACY:
   A.   When the accuracy of a city owned water meter is questioned and the
consumer requests testing of such meter, the consumer will be required to put
up a cash deposit. If the meter in question is one for which the city has the
capability to test the meter at its installed location, the required deposit
shall be one hundred dollars ($100.00). If the meter in question is one for
which such on site testing is not available, the deposit shall be equal to the
meter manufacturer's current charge for testing such meter plus the estimated
cost of shipping the meter to the manufacturer and returning it to the city. If
the test discloses an error against the consumer of more than three percent
(3%) in the meter's registry, the excess of the consumption in the three (3)
previous readings and the amount deposited shall be credited to the consumer's
water account. If the test discloses no error or an error of three percent (3%)
or less, the amount deposited shall be retained by the city.
   B.   All meters owned by the customers shall be tested at regular intervals
upon request of the customer or the department head in charge of the water
service. The cost of testing and transporting the meter to and from the testing
point shall be paid by the consumer. All tests shall be made in accordance with
the procedure described in subsection A of this section.
   C.   Hereafter, deposit increases shall be made effective by the adoption of
a resolution, and may not be changed more often than semiannually. (Ord. 1977,
2011)
13.04.200: FIRE PROTECTION SERVICE; SEPARATE:
Service for fire protection must be fitted for such fixtures only as are needed
for fire protection and entirely disconnected from those used for other
purposes. (Ord. 1977, 2011)
13.04.210: CROSS CONNECTION OR USE OF ANOTHER WATER SUPPLY PROHIBITED:
   A.   No service connection may be allowed from the city water mains to any
premises supplied by water from any other source unless the city manager grants
written permission. The city manager may terminate such permission at any time.
The city manager shall have the power to prescribe reasonable regulations for
the use of water from another source on premises having a connection with the
city water system.
   B.   It is unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to cause a
connection to be made or to allow one to exist for any purpose whatsoever
between the city water supply and any other source of water supply upon his or
its premises. Every person, firm or corporation having any other source of
water supply upon his or its premises is required to make a customer's
declaration of nonexistence of cross connection upon a form supplied by the
utility billing department before being permitted to obtain or continue to use
water from the city water system. City water service shall be discontinued upon
any premises upon which there is found to be a connection between the city
water supply and another water supply; and such service shall not be restored
until such cross connection has been discontinued. (Ord. 1977, 2011)
13.04.220: INTERFERENCE WITH FIRE HYDRANT:
It is unlawful for any person except one duly authorized by the director of
public works, city manager, fire chief, or their designee to:
   A.   Open, turn on or off, tamper with, attach any hose or pipe to, or
connect anything with, any fire hydrant or stopcock belonging to the city; or
   B.   Obstruct access to any fire hydrant by placing around or thereon any
brick, lumber, dirt, vegetation or other matter. (Ord. 1977, 2011)
13.04.230: WATER SHORTAGE; EMERGENCY ACTION:
In case of emergency caused by a shortage of water in the city water system, it
shall be the duty of the city manager immediately to give notice by publication
to the water consumers of the system not to use water obtained from the system
for any purpose other than for strictly domestic use and such other use as he
may designate, so long as the water shortage lasts. Thereafter and until he
proclaims the emergency at an end, it is unlawful for any person, firm or
corporation during the existence of the emergency to use water obtained from
the City water system for the purpose of watering or sprinkling a lawn,
flowerbed, park, hedge or garden, or to use the water for any purpose other
than strictly domestic use and such other uses as he may have designated. (Ord.
1977, 2011)
13.04.240: MAIN EXTENSIONS:
   A.   When one or more property owners desire a larger main or extension of
the main to serve their property, an application shall be made to the City
Manager stating the location and other pertinent data required. The City Water
and Sewer Department shall then make the necessary survey and recommend the
size pipe required for the extension or replacement of the main. The interested
parties shall then enter into a contract with the City which will require the
property owners to put up the estimated amount of the total cost of such main
extension or replacement with the City and the City shall have direct
supervision of the work. All materials shall meet City Water and Sewer
Department specifications. The City may, at its option, choose to accomplish
the project by contract.
   B.   When the job is complete, a final bill shall be made of design and
related costs, labor, equipment, and material used, or, if the project is
accomplished by contract, of the design and related costs and contract amount.
Any difference in cost over the deposit shall be made up by the property
owners. If the total cost is below the amount of the deposit, the difference
shall be refunded to the property owners, and the pipe will then become the
sole property of the City. The City shall maintain the line throughout the life
of the pipe at no charge to the property owners involved.
   C.   A water main shall be considered any water pipe two inches (2") in
diameter or larger. (Ord. 1977, 2011)
13.04.250: SERVICE CHARGES AGAINST CONSUMER:
All charges for water shall be charged against the applicant or consumer. (Ord.
1977, 2011)
13.04.260: RESERVED:
(Ord. 1977, 2011)
13.04.270: CHARGES FOR WATER SERVICE:
   A.   Minimum Charge; Residential: Each family living unit serviced by the
city water system shall be levied and assessed a minimum monthly charge, each
and every month, of eighteen dollars ($18.00) effective July 1, 2025; nineteen
dollars ($19.00) effective July 1, 2026; and twenty dollars ($20.00) effective
July 1, 2027 for the water provided by the city water system. The term "family
living unit" includes, but is not limited to, single-family residences, single
living units in duplexes, rooming houses, apartments and other multiple-family
dwellings, but shall not include the individual rental units in hotels, motels,
nursing homes, or rooming houses or multiple-family dwellings having three (3)
or more family living units if the water is not individually metered.
   B.   Additional Charge; Residential: In addition to the minimum water
charge, there shall be assessed an additional charge to each residential water
account, each and every month, based on the amount of water consumption from
the public water system for each one thousand (1,000) gallons above the basic
first thousand gallons, or any part thereof, which shall be computed by the
following schedule:
   RESIDENTIAL WATER RATES
   Inside City Limits

 Next 10,000 gallons     4.34
 All over 15,000 gallons 4.49

 Next 4,000 gallons      $4.35
 Next 10,000 gallons     4.56
 All over 15,000 gallons 4.71
Effective July 1, 2027     
 Next 4,000 gallons      $4.57
 Next 10,000 gallons     4.79
 All over 15,000 gallons 4.95
 
   C.   Minimum Charge; Commercial: Each commercial establishment or other
concern serviced by the city water system, except an industrial or governmental
user being furnished water service under a special contract with the city,
shall be levied and assessed a minimum monthly charge, each and every month, of
twenty-three dollars ($23.00) for the water provided by the city water system.
The term "commercial establishment or other concern" includes, but is not
limited to, retailers; wholesalers, places where goods or services are
exchanged, bought or sold; places where employment, occupation, profession or
commercial activity is engaged in for gain, benefit, advantage or livelihood;
places of business or employment; governmental offices and facilities; places
of worship and nonprofit businesses; hotels, motels, nursing homes, or rooming
houses or multiple-family dwellings having three (3) or more family living
units if the water is not individually metered. In the event a commercial
establishment, as described above, is connected to the city water system for
unmetered fire protection services only, an access fee of ten dollars ($10.00)
shall be levied each and every month. Hereafter, rate increases shall be made
effective by the adoption of a resolution, and may not be changed more often
than semiannually.
   D.   Additional Charge; Commercial: In addition to the minimum water charge,
there shall be assessed an additional charge for the use of the city water
system to each commercial establishment or other applicable account, each and
every month, based on the amount of water consumption from the city water
system for each one thousand (1,000) gallons above the basic first thousand
gallons, or any part thereof, which shall be computed as follows:
      COMMERCIAL WATER RATES
      Inside City Limits
 
                        Per Thousand Gallons
Effective July 1, 2023:  
Next 4,000 gallons      4.20
Next 45,000 gallons     4.34
Next 30,000 gallons     5.04
All over 80,000 gallons 4.14
 
   E.   Outside City Limits: All water consumers outside of the city limits
shall be charged one and one-half (1½) times the charge of consumers within the
city limits as specified herein, except for heavy industrial users being
furnished water under a contract with the city as provided by ordinance. (Ord.
2220, 2025: Ord. 2195, 2023: Ord. 2113, 2018)
13.04.280: WATER BILL; UTILITY CHARGE; BILLING AND PAYMENT, CONDITIONS AND
PENALTIES; USE OF WATER DEPOSIT:
Billing for the water charge shall be made on the monthly water bills of the
City to the water account which provides water service for the family living
unit, establishment or other concern which is served by the water system. In
addition to the water charge, the water bill shall include thereon the
stormwater utility fee, the ambulance service charge, the sanitation charge,
and the sanitary sewer charge, including any service or delinquency charges as
may hereinafter be imposed by the terms of this title. All of the various
charges included on the water bill, as above set out, shall be referred to
collectively as the "utility charge", and the following shall apply to the
billing and payment of said utility charge:
   A.   The utility charge shall be due and payable on or before the due date
as shown on the water bill.
   B.   Except as provided in this subsection partial payments of the utility
charge will not be accepted after the cutoff date set forth in subsection D of
this section. Provided, however, that the City Council in the event of any
unforeseen occurrence causing, or expected to cause, a substantial increase in
the total amount of any one month's utility billing, may by resolution provide
that the individual bills within said billing period may be paid by
installments over an extended period, never to exceed three (3) months, and
shall prescribe a different due date for said single billing period.
   C.   Payment of the utility charge by a check which is subsequently returned
for any reason, shall result in a twenty five dollar ($25.00) returned check
service charge. This amount plus the amount of the original check and any
accumulated penalties must be paid prior to restoration of service.
   D.   In the event the utility charge is not paid in full by the due date
shown thereon, a delinquency charge of fifteen percent (15%) of the unpaid
balance shall be added to the utility charge. In the event the utility charge
is not paid in full by the expiration of five (5) days after the due date, the
water connection may be cut off by the City. Provided, that the City shall not
attach a late charge on any bill of another governmental entity or public trust
until a thirty (30) day period has elapsed from the issuance of said bill; that
after the elapse of said thirty (30) days without the utility charge being paid
a delinquency charge of fifteen percent (15%) of the unpaid balance shall be
added to the utility charge; and in the event the utility charge is not paid in
full by the expiration of forty (40) days after issuance of the bill, the water
connection may be cut off by the City.
   E.   When a utility account is placed on the delinquent list for the
nonpayment of any utility charge, there will be charged and collected by the
City, in addition to the amount of the past due utility charge and any other
service charges, an additional sum of thirty dollars ($30.00) for being placed
on the delinquent list and/or disconnection of service. In the event that there
has been a history of unauthorized connection to or opening of valves
associated with the meter on the applicable service account, then the City may
remove the meter and place an additional service charge of sixty five dollars
($65.00) on the account for that service; such service charge shall not be made
if a completely new account is created by a new consumer who is not the old
account holder nor a family member or roommate of the old account holder. The
total sum of charges due must be paid in full prior to reconnection. Provided
that if the account holder has never previously been placed on the delinquent
list, and if the delinquency was caused by a financial event unlikely to
reoccur in the normal life of the account holder, the utility billing office
shall have the authority to waive the thirty dollar ($30.00) fee on a single
occasion.
   F.   Adjustments to water service charges shall be made only when: 1) a
faulty meter has given an inaccurate reading; 2) improper reading of a meter
has resulted in an improper charge; or 3) a newly discovered leak is found that
is not attributable to the actions or omissions of the property owner, and
which results in a charge that is at least three hundred percent (300%) of the
average bill for water usage at that property over the immediately preceding
three (3) months. No more than one adjustment will be made to an account in any
twelve (12) consecutive month period, and no more than one month's bill shall
be adjusted on any account. All adjustments on the water bill shall require
payment of the average bill over the preceding three (3) months, plus fifty
percent (50%) of any discrepancy that is not caused by the City or its agents.
This adjustment shall be in lieu of any adjustment to the sanitary sewer
charges which may be given due to discrepancies in the water bill, at the
customer's option.
   G.   For a utility account holder whose water service is provided by a
provider other than the City of Okmulgee, in the event the account has been
placed on the delinquent list for the nonpayment of any utility charge, the
following actions may be taken in addition to action specified in subsection E
of this section:
      1.   The account holder's sanitary sewer service line will be
disconnected from the City's sanitary sewer main and plugged. The expense of
that work will be added to the account holder's utility account.
      2.   The account holder's water provider will be notified that the water
service should be discontinued in accordance with Oklahoma Department of
Environmental Quality (ODEQ) requirements unless the property owner has
connected the facility's sewer system to a septic system or other approved
sewer system which was installed by an ODEQ approved installer.
      3.   Reconnection of the property's sanitary sewer service line to the
City of Okmulgee's sanitary sewer system will be allowed only if the City
Manager gives approval and the following actions are accomplished:
         a.   All past due amounts are paid in full to the City by the property
owner.
         b.   The current sanitary sewer tap fee for connection to the City's
sanitary sewer system is paid to the City by the property owner.
         c.   The property owner has a licensed plumber accomplish the
reconnection of the private sanitary sewer main at the property owner's
expense. (Ord. 2031, 2014: Ord. 2009, 2013: Ord. 1991, 2012: Ord. 1977, 2011)
13.04.290: DRILLING OF WATER WELLS PROHIBITED:
It is prohibited to drill a well for water within the City limits of Okmulgee
without the written authorization of the City Manager to do so. (Ord. 1977,
2011)
13.04.300: CONNECTION BETWEEN CITY WATER SUPPLY AND OTHER SOURCES PROHIBITED:
It is unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to cause a connection to be
made or to allow one to exist for any purpose whatsoever, between the City
water supply and any other source of supply. (Ord. 1977, 2011)
13.04.310: OTHER SYSTEMS PROHIBITED FROM CONNECTION WITH CITY WATER SYSTEM:
No private or public water system shall have a direct connection with City
water system. (Ord. 1977, 2011)
CHAPTER 13.08
WATER LINES OUTSIDE CITY
SECTION:
13.08.010: Payment And Fees
13.08.020: Cross Connections And Other Unauthorized Uses
13.08.030: Consumers On Private Lines Bound By Ordinances
13.08.010: PAYMENT AND FEES:
All persons originally agreeing to pay or fund the building of private water
lines shall pay into the hands of the treasurer of the city their proportionate
costs as agreed upon between the city and the original persons agreeing and
contracting to build the water line; and shall also pay in addition thereto the
usual fee for tapping the water line or lines, which payment shall not include
the installation of any lateral lines or lines running into private property. A
master meter shall be installed at the point where the private water line taps
into the public main. The parties to the agreement shall be jointly responsible
for the payment of the charges for the water as shown on the master meter;
however, this obligation may be satisfied by the individual users of water by
payments of the charges for their individual use as determined, plus a pro rata
cost of water from leaks in the private line. However, the city reserves the
right to collect any unpaid charges in full as reflected on the master meter,
from the persons receiving service from the private line, even if they have
previously paid a smaller share. (Ord. 1977, 2011)
13.08.020: CROSS CONNECTIONS AND OTHER UNAUTHORIZED USES:
The original users or any subsequent user of such private water lines hereby
affected shall not grant, give, sell or assign to any person the right or
privilege of connection to the water lines unless such person has agreed in
writing to be jointly and severably responsible for the payment of the charges
as shown on the master meter. (Ord. 1977, 2011)
13.08.030: CONSUMERS ON PRIVATE LINES BOUND BY ORDINANCES:
All consumers receiving service on private lines which draw water from the
city's system shall be contractually bound by all city ordinances concerning
use of water, cost of taps, one user per tap, water deposit and all other
ordinances of general applicability pertinent to such use. (Ord. 1977, 2011)
CHAPTER 13.12
SEWER SERVICE
SECTION:
13.12.010: Council Findings Of Fact

13.12.090: Discharge Of Groundwater Or Rainwater Prohibited
13.12.100: Repetitive Sewer Releases To The Ground Or To Streams
13.12.010: COUNCIL FINDINGS OF FACT:
The Council of the City finds and determines as follows:
   A.   The sanitary sewage system of the City is a public utility and requires
considerable outlay of funds for maintenance and operation; such outlay is a
recurring expense to the City.
   B.   The cost of maintenance and operation of the sanitary sewage system has
been borne by the proceeds received from the operation of other public
utilities and other sources of income other than from the sanitary sewage
system.
   C.   Cities in the State of Oklahoma have such authority as is granted by
the Legislature of the State as the same relates to the raising of funds with
which to furnish services to their citizens.
   D.   The sanitary sewage system of the City should bear its proportionate
share of the cost of administration of the City, as well as the cost of its own
operation, and a reasonable profit.
   E.   Under the laws of the State of Oklahoma, all monies received by public
utilities must be paid into the General Fund of the City and spent under
budgets. (Ord. 1977, 2011)
13.12.020: RESERVED:
(Ord. 1977, 2011)
13.12.030: SANITARY SEWER CHARGE:
   A.   Minimum Charge; Residential: Each family living unit serviced by the
City sanitary sewer system shall be levied and assessed a minimum monthly
charge, each and every month, of twenty dollars fifty cents ($20.50) effective
July 1, 2018; of twenty one dollars fifty cents ($21.50) effective July 1,
2019; and of twenty two dollars fifty cents ($22.50) effective July 1, 2020;
for the first one thousand (1,000) gallons as measured by the water meter
reading for the use of the City sanitary sewer system. The term "family living
unit" includes, but is not limited to, single-family residences, single living
units in duplexes, rooming houses, apartments and other multiple-family
dwellings, but shall not include the individual rental units in hotels, motels,
nursing homes, or rooming houses or multiple- family dwellings having three (3)
or more family living units if the water is not individually metered.
   B.   Additional Charge; Residential: In addition to the minimum sanitary
sewer charge, there shall be assessed an additional charge for the use of the
City sanitary sewer system to each residential sanitary sewer account, each and
every month, based on the amount of water consumption from the public water
system for each one thousand (1,000) gallons, or any part thereof, over and
above the first one thousand (1,000) gallons of water consumed for the
corresponding time period and which shall be computed by the following
schedule:
      RESIDENTIAL SANITARY SEWER RATES

   C.   Minimum Charge; Commercial: Each commercial establishment or other
concern serviced by the city sanitary sewer system, except an industrial user
being furnished sanitary sewer service under a special contract with the city,
shall be levied and assessed a minimum monthly charge, each and every month, of
twenty-seven dollars fifty cents ($27.50) for the first one thousand (1,000)
gallons as measured by the water meter reading for the use of the city sanitary
sewer system. The term "commercial establishment or other concern" includes,
but is not limited to, retailers; wholesalers; places where goods or services
are exchanged, bought or sold; places where employment, occupation, profession
or commercial activity is engaged in for gain, benefit, advantage or
livelihood; places of business or employment; governmental offices and
facilities; places of worship and nonprofit businesses; hotels, motels, nursing
homes, or rooming houses or multiple-family dwellings having three (3) or more
family living units if the water is not individually metered.
   D.   Additional Charge; Commercial: In addition to the minimum sanitary
sewer charge, there shall be assessed an additional charge for the use of the
city sanitary sewer system to each commercial establishment or other applicable
account, each and every month, based on the amount of water consumption from
the city water system for each one thousand (1,000) gallons, or any part
thereof, over and above the first one thousand (1,000) gallons of water
consumed for the corresponding time period which shall be computed as follows:

   E.   City Manager Has Authority To Negotiate Contracts: Notwithstanding any
other provision of this section, the City Manager shall have authority upon
obtaining the approval of the City Council to negotiate a contract with any
heavy industrial user of the sanitary sewer service to furnish said service
upon terms and rates other than those set out above, if the nature of the
industrial user is deemed of such nature as to be best served upon other terms
and rates and if same can be done in accordance with the guidelines prescribed
by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency and/or the Oklahoma Department of
Environmental Quality.
   F.   Water Consumption Computation: The amount of water consumption to be
used as a basis for computing the sanitary sewer charge for the periods covered
by the July, August, and September billings shall be the lower of the
following:
      1.   Actual consumption; or
      2.   The average of consumption of the account billed for January,
February, and March billing periods of said year.
In case of a new account where no average can be determined, the City Clerk or
the Clerk's designee shall determine a figure based on normal usage of other
similar accounts, to be used in computing the July, August, and September
billing period's sanitary sewer charge. In the event an account is serviced by
a water meter and none of the water consumed is discharged to, or returnable
to, the City sanitary sewer system, and if the consumer so elects, said account
will not be subject to the sanitary sewer charge.
   G.   Adjustments To Sanitary Sewer Charge: Adjustments to the sanitary sewer
charge shall be had and allowed in the same manner and upon the same conditions
as adjustments to water service charges as provided by subsection
13.04.280F of this title. Further, in the event that a consumer shall have a
water leak resulting in a high water usage, the consumer, upon having such
condition certified by an Oklahoma licensed plumber who is registered with the
City, shall be entitled to an adjustment for one billing period; said
adjustment shall be equal to one-half (1/2) of the excess billed for that
period over the average for the preceding three (3) billing periods, or when
there have not been three (3) previous readings the Utility Billing Department
may estimate the average.
   H.   Outside City Limits: All sewer service consumers outside of the City
limits shall be charged one and one-half (11/2) times the charge of consumers
within the City limits as specified herein, except for those under individual
contracts under the authority of subsection E of this section. In the event
that a new sewer service consumer hereafter wants to begin service, but is not
on the City's water utility, such a consumer shall be required to post a
deposit at the time of application for the following sums:
      1.   For a residence, house, apartment or office, the sum of one hundred
dollars ($100.00) if the sewer account is in the name of the owner of said
premises; if the sewer account is in the name of a person other than the owner
of said premises, the sum of one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00);
      2.   For any commercial establishment, other than an office, private
club, beer hall or place of amusement, the sum of one hundred fifty dollars
($150.00) or three (3) month average of previous occupant's usage;
      3.   For a private club, beer hall or place of amusement, the sum of two
hundred dollars ($200.00);
      4.   Notwithstanding any other provision contained in this title, if the
consumer applying for an account has previously held an account with the City,
and said applicant has in the past established a bad credit history with the
City by having on three (3) occasions either paid the amount with a check which
was dishonored by the bank on which it was drawn, or has not paid the account
by the due date of payment, the City shall require a deposit equal to one-
fourth (1/4) of the estimated yearly utility charge, as that term is defined in
section
13.04.280 of this title, as determined by the Utility Billing Supervisor, if
that amount so computed is greater than the standard deposit required for such
consumer as set forth in subsections A through C of this section. Further, if a
consumer with an existing account has established a bad credit history with the
City, as above set forth, said consumer will be required to increase the
existing deposit to an amount equal to one-fourth (1/4) of the annual utility
charge of said consumer, if the amount so computed is greater than the standard
deposit required for said consumer, and the failure to pay the increased
deposit shall give the City authority to refuse sewer service to such consumer
as if the consumer had failed to pay the utility charge itself. (Ord. 2196,
2024: Ord. 2114, 2018: Ord. 2084, 2016: Ord. 1977, 2011)
13.12.040: CITY AND TRUSTS NOT OBLIGATED TO FURNISH SERVICE:
The City and its trusts are not obligated to furnish sanitary sewer service to
any person, firm or corporation, but will furnish such service as is reasonably
within its financial and physical ability to do so. (Ord. 1977, 2011)
13.12.050: BILLING AND PAYMENT:
Billing for the sanitary sewer charge shall be made on the monthly water bills
of the City to the water account which provides water service for the family
living unit, establishment, or concern which is served by the sanitary sewer
system and payment shall be due from and the responsibility and obligation of
the holder or owner of said water account. Payment of said charge shall be
governed by and subject to the terms, conditions, penalties and other
requirements of section
13.04.280 of this title. (Ord. 1977, 2011)
13.12.060: ANNUAL REVIEW OF SANITARY SEWER CHARGE:
The sanitary sewer charge shall be reviewed at least annually and shall be
adjusted as necessary to reflect any increase or decrease in wastewater
treatment costs based on the immediately preceding year's experience. Any funds
collected in excess of those required to pay for operation and maintenance
costs attributable to the sanitary sewer charge, shall be applied to the
sanitary sewer charge system for the following year, and the total operation
and maintenance costs per month shall be adjusted accordingly. (Ord. 1977,
2011)
13.12.070: APPLICATIONS FOR SEWER SERVICE; BACKFLOW PREVENTION DEVICES:
At the time of application for sewer service, the applicant shall be offered a
choice of either: a) installing on the private sewer line an approved type of
backflow prevention device by a licensed plumber or contractor at applicant's
expense, or b) paying an inspection fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) to have an
existing backflow prevention device inspected by the City to determine present
sufficiency, that existing backflow prevention device having been excavated and
exposed for inspection at the applicant's expense. Hereafter, fee increases
shall be made effective by the adoption of a resolution, and may not be changed
more often than semiannually. (Ord. 1977, 2011)
13.12.080: BACKFLOW PREVENTION DEVICES; DESCRIBED:
Backflow prevention devices authorized for installation on private sewer
service lines connecting to the City sanitary sewer system shall include only
such devices that meet the requirements of the International Plumbing Code most
recently adopted by the City and are designed to actually prevent a backflow
and discharge of the sewage through one or more mechanical means, but shall not
include devices which merely allow for pressure relief and spillage of the
sewer's contents. (Ord. 1977, 2011)
13.12.090: DISCHARGE OF GROUNDWATER OR RAINWATER PROHIBITED:
   A.   No person shall open a sewage cleanout cap, or any manhole or similar
access to a public or private sanitary sewer line during or in anticipation of
any storm, rain, or potential flood water event in such a manner that rainwater
or floodwater is allowed to inflow into or otherwise be discharged from the
private property to the sanitary sewer system of the City of Okmulgee.
   B.   Any person acting in violation of any provision of this section shall
be guilty of an offense, and, upon conviction, shall be punished as set forth
in section
1.12.010 of this Code. (Ord. 1977, 2011)
13.12.100: REPETITIVE SEWER RELEASES TO THE GROUND OR TO STREAMS:
   A.   Any person owning or controlling property within the City limits which
property experiences two (2) or more sewage backup or similar events within any
two (2) year period:
      1.   That allows sewage to be released onto the ground from the private
service line, or
      2.   That allows sewage to be released to any stream from the private
service line, shall prevent future releases by installing on the private sewer
line an approved type of backflow prevention device at applicant's expense.
   B.   Any person acting in violation of any provision of this section shall
be guilty of an offense, and, upon conviction, shall be punished as set forth
in section
1.12.010 of this Code. (Ord. 1977, 2011)
CHAPTER 13.16
SEWER PERMITS AND CONNECTION CHARGES
SECTION:
13.16.010: Connection Permit; Required
13.16.020: Connection Permit; Application And Backflow Prevention Devices
13.16.030: Water And Sewer Department And City; Supervision And Obligations
13.16.040: Tapping Sewer Mains; Required Equipment
13.16.045: Main Extensions
13.16.050: Sewer System Fee Schedule
13.16.060: Connection Outside City; Application For Permit
13.16.070: Connection To Existing Sewer; Extension
13.16.080: Connection Outside City; Charges
13.16.090: Size Specification
13.16.100: Connection Permit Issuance; Compliance
13.16.010: CONNECTION PERMIT; REQUIRED:
No person, firm or corporation shall connect or procure to be connected any
plumbing or private drain to the sanitary sewage system of the city unless they
have procured a permit to do so. (Ord. 1977, 2011)
13.16.020: CONNECTION PERMIT; APPLICATION AND BACKFLOW PREVENTION DEVICES:
   A.   Sewer connection permits may be obtained by making application therefor
to the community development department and tendering a permit fee that is set
not more often than semiannually by resolution of the city council or by
executive order of the city manager. Such fee schedule shall be available to
the public and by providing a copy with each application and by including it
with a list of all fees for development within the city.
   B.   At the time of the application, the applicant shall be offered a choice
of either: 1) installing on the private sewer line an approved type of backflow
prevention device at applicant's expense, or 2) paying an inspection fee to
have an existing backflow prevention device inspected by the city to determine
present sufficiency. (Ord. 1977, 2011)
13.16.030: WATER AND SEWER DEPARTMENT AND CITY; SUPERVISION AND OBLIGATIONS:
All connections to the sanitary sewage system shall be made under the
supervision of the city water and sewer department supervisor or his designee.
The city shall not be obligated to, nor be responsible for digging sewer line
ditches, laying sewer tile or pipe up to the point of connection with the
lateral or main, nor for backfilling the ditches after the connection has been
made. (Ord. 1977, 2011)
13.16.040: TAPPING SEWER MAINS; REQUIRED EQUIPMENT:
No person, firm, or corporation shall tap any sewer main of the city sewage
disposal system except and unless they use at the time of making the tap a
"sewer tapping saddle" or a "wye", as prescribed by the city's standard
specification, which devices are used for the purpose of protecting sewage
disposal facilities and lines, and with the view of preventing damage thereto
at the time taps are made. All taps shall be made in accordance with the city's
standard specification for the tapping of sewer mains. No sanitary sewer
service line providing service for a single property shall be connected to a
city sanitary sewer interceptor main without the approval of the city manager.
(Ord. 1977, 2011)
13.16.045: MAIN EXTENSIONS:
   A.   In the event that a potential customer within the city limits desires
to extend the city sanitary sewer system to service a property or properties
previously without sanitary sewer service, application shall be made to the
city manager stating the location and other pertinent data required. The city's
water and sewer department supervisor and the city's engineer will then conduct
a preliminary survey to determine the feasibility of such an extension. If the
extension appears to be feasible and in the best interest of the city, the
interested parties shall then enter into a contract with the city which will
require the property owners to put up the estimated amount of the total cost of
such main extension with the city of Okmulgee, including the connection
authorization and inspection (tap) fee and the impact fee for each expected
connection to the new main, and the city shall have direct supervision of the
design and work, whether performed by contract or by city crew. All materials
and design shall comply with city requirements. The city manager, at his
discretion, may choose to have the potential customer accomplish construction
of the sanitary sewer main by contract subject to compliance with city
requirements and inspection for acceptance by the water and sewer department
supervisor or his designee. The fee for city inspection of sanitary sewer line
construction shall be one dollar twenty cents ($1.20) per linear foot with a
minimum fee of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00).
   B.   When the job is complete, a final bill shall be made of design and
related costs, labor, equipment, and material used, or, if the project is
accomplished by contract, of the design and related costs in addition to
contract costs and any difference in cost over the initial deposit shall be
made up by the property owners. If the total cost is less than the amount of
the deposit, the difference shall be refunded to the property owners. The main
extension will then become the sole property of the city together with a
fifteen foot (15') utility easement using the pipe as the centerline; however,
the individual service lines shall remain the property of the respective
property owners. The city shall maintain the line throughout the life of the
pipe at no charge to the property owners involved. Construction of private
service lines connected to the main extension will be accomplished separately
by the property owners at their expense, and those service lines will remain
the responsibility of the property owners. (Ord. 1977, 2011)
13.16.050: SEWER SYSTEM FEE SCHEDULE:
It is declared to be the policy of the city to charge and collect a connection
authorization and inspection (tap) fee and a sanitary sewer system impact fee
for each and every connection made to the city's sanitary sewer system under
the provisions of this chapter. A "connection" as used in this section is
defined as access to the city's system for one serviced property. The charge
shall be in accordance with the following schedule:
   A.   Unless the city manager directs otherwise, all connections (taps) to
the city sanitary sewer system shall be performed at the expense of the
property owner by plumbers or contractors licensed to perform such work. The
connection authorization and inspection (tap) fee for each connection to the
system shall be two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00).
   B.   In addition to the connection authorization and inspection (tap) fee,
an impact fee shall be paid, based upon the size of water meter servicing any
property within the city limits, in accordance with the following schedule:
3/4 inch residential meter  $ 1,000.00
1 inch residential meter    1,500.00
11/2 inch residential meter 2,000.00
3/4 inch commercial meter   1,200.00
1 inch commercial meter     2,000.00
11/2 inch commercial meter  5,000.00
2 inch commercial meter     8,000.00
3 inch commercial meter     18,000.00
4 inch commercial meter     32,000.00
5 inch commercial meter     50,000.00
6 inch commercial meter     72,000.00
8 inch commercial meter     129,000.00
 
   C.   Hereafter, fee increases shall be made effective by the adoption of
resolution, and may not be changed more often than semiannually. (Ord. 1977,
2011)
13.16.060: CONNECTION OUTSIDE CITY; APPLICATION FOR PERMIT:
Any person, firm or corporation desiring to procure the connection of property
located outside the incorporated limits of the city with the sewer system of
the city shall make application therefor with the city clerk. (Ord. 1977, 2011)
13.16.070: CONNECTION TO EXISTING SEWER; EXTENSION:
   A.   Connection To Existing Sanitary Sewer Mains: The application shall set
forth the legal description of the property and the exact location of the
buildings thereon sought to be served by the sewer connection. The application
shall be reviewed by the water and sewer department supervisor to determine
feasibility of the requested connection and to provide a recommendation to the
city manager. If approved by the city manager, the applicant shall pay the
required connection authorization and inspection (tap) fee and the required
impact fee and shall receive in return authorization to have a plumber connect
the sanitary sewer service line for the property to the city's sanitary sewer
main in accordance with city specifications and as directed by the water and
sewer department supervisor. The connection to the city's main shall be
inspected by the water and sewer department supervisor or his designated
representative.
   B.   Connection Requiring Extension Of The City's Sanitary Sewer Main:
Application for connection to the city's sanitary sewer system involving the
extension of a sanitary sewer main shall be made in accordance with the
procedures described in section
13.16.045 of this chapter. (Ord. 1977, 2011)
13.16.080: CONNECTION OUTSIDE CITY; CHARGES:
All those outside the city limits who are authorized to connect to the city's
sanitary sewer system for service shall be charged one and one-half (11/2)
times the connection authorization and inspection (tap) fee and one and one-
half (11/2) times the impact fee charged for those connecting within the city
limits. (Ord. 1977, 2011)
13.16.090: SIZE SPECIFICATION:
No sewer main shall hereafter be constructed within the incorporated limits of
the city or as an extension to the city's sanitary sewer system outside the
incorporated limits of the city which is less than eight inches (8") in
diameter. (Ord. 1977, 2011)
13.16.100: CONNECTION PERMIT ISSUANCE; COMPLIANCE:
No sewer connection permit shall be issued unless it is determined that such
proposed sanitary sewer complies in all respects with current city
specifications. (Ord. 1977, 2011)
CHAPTER 13.20
SEWER REQUIREMENTS FOR CITY WATER CUSTOMERS
SECTION:
13.20.010: Septic Tanks; Specifications
13.20.020: Septic Tanks; Approval Required For Installation
13.20.030: Subdivision Of Lands; Deed Of Dedication

13.20.010: SEPTIC TANKS; SPECIFICATIONS:
All lots upon which residences or businesses are being built shall be large
enough to accommodate and allow the construction of septic tanks in accordance
with the minimum requirements of the Oklahoma department of environmental
quality (ODEQ) in the event city sanitary sewer lines are not available to
serve the property. Installation or construction of septic tanks shall be
performed by an installer certified by the Oklahoma department of environmental
quality, and documentation of that ODEQ approved installation shall be provided
to the Okmulgee community development department. (Ord. 1977, 2011)
13.20.020: SEPTIC TANKS; APPROVAL REQUIRED FOR INSTALLATION:
Approval shall not be granted for the installation of any septic tank to serve
any property where city sanitary sewer line facilities are available to serve
the property, and connections may reasonably be made thereto, and no water tap
shall be made to the property until sewer line connections have been effected
to serve the property. (Ord. 1977, 2011)
13.20.030: SUBDIVISION OF LANDS; DEED OF DEDICATION:
All lands upon which more than one residence or business will be constructed
shall be subdivided and plotted, and necessary dedication of streets and
utility easements shown thereon in accordance with the laws of the state of
Oklahoma, and the deed of dedication and plot filed for record in the office of
the county clerk of Okmulgee County, Oklahoma, with copies thereof filed in the
office of the city clerk. (Ord. 1977, 2011)
13.20.040: ENFORCEMENT; AUTHORITY AND CONFORMANCE:
The provisions of this chapter remain subject to inspection and enforcement by
state and city officials. Enforcement shall be in accordance with the Oklahoma
Statutes as in such case made and provided and the regulations of the Oklahoma
department of environmental quality as set forth in their adopted regulations.
(Ord. 1977, 2011)
CHAPTER 13.24
DISCHARGING CERTAIN SUBSTANCES INTO SEWER PROHIBITED
SECTION:
13.24.060: Prohibited Discharges
13.24.070: Discharge Of Solids Prohibited
13.24.060: PROHIBITED DISCHARGES:
No person shall discharge, or cause to be discharged, any water, ground water,
roof runoff, subsurface drainage, or any water from downspouts, yard drains,
yard fountains and ponds, septic tanks, or lawn sprays, into any sanitary
sewer. (Ord. 1371 § 3, 1979)
13.24.070: DISCHARGE OF SOLIDS PROHIBITED:
   A.   No person shall discharge, or cause to be discharged, any solid
material into the sanitary sewer of the city, except for ordinary household
wastes as liquids or suspended solids. Prohibited discharges specifically
include any food items that have neither passed through the human digestive
tract nor a garbage grinder disposal system, any packaging materials, any yard
waste, or comparable items that the sanitary sewer was not designed to handle.
   B.   Any person acting in violation of any provision of this section shall
be guilty of an offense, and, upon conviction, shall be punished as set forth
in section
1.12.010 of this code. (Ord. 1898 § 1, 2007)

13.32.010: PURPOSE AND POLICY:
This chapter sets forth uniform requirements for users of the wastewater
collection and publicly owned treatment works (POTW) for the city of Okmulgee
and enables said city to comply with all applicable state and federal laws
including the clean water act (33 USC 1251 et seq.), and the general
pretreatment regulations (40 CFR part 403). The objectives of this chapter are:
   A.   To prevent the introduction of pollutants into the POTW that will
interfere with the operation of the POTW;
   B.   To prevent the introduction of pollutants into the POTW which will pass
through the POTW, inadequately treated, into receiving waters or otherwise be
incompatible with the POTW;
   C.   To ensure that the quality of the wastewater treatment plant sludge is
maintained at a level which allows its use and disposal in compliance with
applicable statutes and regulations;
   D.   To protect POTW personnel who may be affected by wastewater and sludge
in the course of their employment and to protect the general public;
   E.   To improve the opportunity to recycle and reclaim wastewater and sludge
from the POTW;
   F.   To provide for fees for the equitable distribution of the cost of
operation, maintenance and improvement of the POTW; and
   G.   To enable the city to comply with its NPDES permit conditions, sludge
use and disposal requirements and any other federal or state laws to which the
POTW is subject.
This chapter shall apply to all industrial users of the POTW, and authorizes
the issuance of wastewater discharge permits; authorizes monitoring, compliance
and enforcement activities; establishes administrative review procedures;
requires industrial user reporting; and provides for the setting of fees for
the equitable distribution of costs resulting from the program established
herein. (Ord. 1691 § 2, 1992)
13.32.020: ADMINISTRATION:
Except as otherwise provided herein, the city manager shall administer,
implement and enforce the provisions of this chapter. Any powers granted to or
duties imposed upon the city manager may be delegated by the city manager to
other city personnel. (Ord. 1691 § 3, 1992)
13.32.030: DEFINITIONS:
Unless a provision explicitly states otherwise, the following terms and
phrases, as used in this chapter, shall have the meanings hereinafter
designated:
ACT OR THE ACT: The federal water pollution control act, known as the clean
water act, as amended, 33 USC 1251 et seq.
APPROVAL AUTHORITY: The appropriate regional administrator of the U.S. EPA, or
his designee the executive director of the Oklahoma department of environmental
quality (November 19, 1996).
AUTHORIZED REPRESENTATIVE OF THE INDUSTRIAL USER:
   A.   If the industrial user is a corporation, authorized representative
shall mean:
      1.   The president, secretary, treasurer, or a vice president of the
corporation in charge of a principal business function, or any other person who
performs similar policy or decision making functions for the corporation;
      2.   The manager of one or more manufacturing, production, or operating
facilities, provided, the manager is authorized to make management decisions
which govern the operation of the regulated facility including having the
explicit or implicit duty of making major capital investment recommendations,
and initiate and direct other comprehensive measures to assure long term
environmental compliance with environmental laws and regulations; can ensure
that the necessary systems are established or actions taken to gather complete
and accurate information for permit requirements; and where authority to sign
documents has been assigned or delegated to the manager in accordance with
corporate procedures;
   B.   If the industrial user is a partnership, or sole proprietorship, an
authorized representative shall mean a general partner or proprietor,
respectively;
   C.   If the industrial user is a federal, state or local governmental
facility, an authorized representative shall mean a director or highest
official appointed or designated to oversee the operation and performance of
the activities of the government facility, or his/her designee;
   D.   The individuals described in subsections A through C of this definition
may designate another authorized representative if the authorization is in
writing, the authorization specifies the individual or position responsible for
the overall operation of the facility from which the discharge originates or
having overall responsibility for environmental matters for the company, and
the written authorization is submitted to the city.
BIOCHEMICAL OXYGEN DEMAND (BOD): The quantity of oxygen utilized in the
biochemical oxidation of organic matter under standard laboratory procedure,
five (5) days at twenty degrees centigrade (20°C) expressed in terms of mass
and concentration (milligrams per liter [mg/l]).
CATEGORICAL PRETREATMENT STANDARD OR CATEGORICAL STANDARD: Any regulation
containing pollutant discharge limits promulgated by the U.S. EPA in accordance
with sections 307(b) and (c) of the act (33 USC 1317) which apply to a specific
category of industrial users and which appear in 40 CFR chapter I, subchapter
N, parts 405 through 471.
CITY/CONTROL AUTHORITY: The city of Okmulgee or the city council of Okmulgee.
CITY MANAGER: The person designated by the city to supervise the operation of
the POTW, and who is charged with certain duties and responsibilities by this
chapter or his duly authorized representative.
COLOR: The optical density at the visual wave length of maximum absorption,
relative to distilled water. One hundred percent (100%) transmittance is
equivalent to zero (0.0) optical density.
COMPOSITE SAMPLE: The sample resulting from the combination of individual
wastewater samples taken at selected intervals based on an increment of either
flow or time.
ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION AGENCY OR EPA: The U.S. environmental protection
agency or, where appropriate, the term may also be used as a designation for
the regional water management division director or other duly authorized
official of said agency.
EXISTING SOURCE: Any source of discharge, the construction or operation of
which commenced prior to the publication of proposed categorical pretreatment
standards which will be applicable to such source if the standard is thereafter
promulgated in accordance with section 307 of the act.
GRAB SAMPLE: A sample which is taken from a wastestream on a onetime basis
without regard to the flow in the wastestream and without consideration of
time.
INDIRECT DISCHARGE OR DISCHARGE: The introduction of (nondomestic) pollutants
into the POTW from any nondomestic source regulated under section 307(b), (c)
or (d) of the act.
